He also warned the public not to approach the suspect, who may still have the crossbow.\n\nAddressing Mr Clifford directly, the chief superintendent said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe Police and Crime Commissioner for Hertfordshire, Jonathan Ash-Edwards, said the incident has sent \"shockwaves\" through the local community and across Hertfordshire.\n\n\"My thoughts are with the family and friends of the women who have been shockingly killed in this terrible incident in Bushey,\" he added.\n\n\"I am being kept updated by the police and I urge the public to support the police with any information about the whereabouts of the named suspect.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit has also released a statement.\n\n\"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" he said.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://news.stv.tv/world/wife-and-two-daughters-of-bbc-racing-commentator-john-hunt-killed-in-crossbow-attack", "title": "Wife and two daughters of BBC racing commentator killed in crossbow attack", "body": "The wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator have been killed in a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters died in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening.\n\nA massive manhunt has been launched for their suspected killer, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died, in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nPolice have issued a direct plea to Clifford to \"make contact\".\n\nClifford, from Enfield, north London, is wanted over the deaths of the women, aged 25, 28 and 61, who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nChief superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nMr Simpson repeated warnings to the public not to approach the suspect, but to call 999 if they see him.\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed officers searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the search continued.\n\nHertfordshire Police said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nEast of England Ambulance Service said three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle and the Hazardous Area Response Team were also sent to the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable {"uri": "8219199804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:12:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:12:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:12:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.rsvplive.ie/news/uk-world-news/kyle-clifford-crossbow-triple-murder-33215190", "title": "Kyle Clifford: Crossbow triple murder suspect found in cemetery after manhunt", "body": "Kyle Clifford, the suspect of a horrific crossbow massacre that saw three women murdered, has been found in a cemetery yards from his Enfield home in London, police have confirmed.\n\nOfficers said the suspect was found on Wednesday afternoon and is currently receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries. Armed officers and a specialist search dog tracked the 26-year-old down after searching a cemetery near to Rendlesham Road in Enfield, north London.\n\nRead more: Who is the BBC star John Hunt whose family have been killed in 'triple crossbow murder'?\n\nRead more: Jay Slater's mum shares new search update on GoFundMe page including major setback\n\nA local mum-of-two told the Mirror : \"Armed police have been here since around 2.30pm today - it's terrifying. I'm pleased because the schools in Enfield have been in lockdown all day and the kids after-school clubs have all been cancelled.\"\n\nClifford was the subject of a huge manhunt across areas of Herdfordshire and north London after three women were found dead in their home in Hertfordshire following a horrific crossbow attack. The victims were later named as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nMr Hunt is understood to have been working for BBC Racing on Tuesday, and reportedly returned home to discover his wife and two daughters had been fatally injured. Police were called to the property in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm that day.\n\nOfficers arrived on scene with ambulance vehicles, including two air ambulances, to find that the trio had suffered serious injuries. The three women were alive when discovered, however, despite the best efforts of paramedics, all tragically died at the scene a short time later.\n\nCCTV footage later emerged of Clifford fleeing the area with a 3ft crossbow held underneath his right arm as he got into a vehicle and drove away. The same car was found abandoned earlier on Wednesday in Enfield.\n\nClifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was the subject of a huge manhunt around areas of Hertfordshire and North London, where officers believe he was hiding following the murders. According to Sky News, Clifford used to work as a private security guard.\n\nTwo helicopters were seen near Clifford's home in Enfield, flying over the Hilly Fields park opposite his residence, while a nearby primary school kept its pupils in lockdown as a precaution as the search continued. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack on Tuesday night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nMeanwhile, members of the public were warned not to approach the 26-year-old, who was thought to be armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said earlier on Wednesday: \"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford, who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe BBC said in a note to its 5 Live staff: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nTV racing commentator Matt Chapman tweeted: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nHunt's daughter Louise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, MyLondon reported.\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media read: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nThe murders have also sent shockwaves through the community in Bushey, as residents were seen leaving flowers at the scene following the tragic The victims were later named as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nMr Hunt is understood to have been working for BBC Racing on Tuesday, and reportedly returned home to discover his wife and two daughters had been fatally injured. Police were called to the property in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm that day.\n\nOfficers arrived on scene with ambulance vehicles, including two air ambulances, to find that the trio had suffered serious injuries. The three women were alive when discovered, however, despite the best efforts of paramedics, all tragically died at the scene a short time later.\n\nCCTV footage later emerged of Clifford fleeing the area with a 3ft crossbow held underneath his right arm as he got into a vehicle and drove away. The same car was found abandoned earlier on Wednesday in Enfield.\n\nClifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was the subject of a huge manhunt around areas of Hertfordshire and North London, where officers believe he was hiding following the murders. The victims were later named as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nMr Hunt is understood to have been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday, and reportedly returned home to discover his wife and two daughters had been fatally injured. Police were called to the property in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm that day.\n\nOfficers arrived on scene with ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - to find that the trio had suffered serious injuries. The three women were alive when discovered, however, despite the best efforts of paramedics, all tragically died at the scene a short time later.\n\nCCTV footage later emerged of Clifford fleeing the area with a 3ft crossbow held underneath his right arm as he got into a vehicle and drove away. The same car was found abandoned earlier today in Enfield.\n\nClifford, 26, from Enfield in north London was the subject of a huge manhunt around areas of Hertfordshire and North London, where officers believe he was hiding following the murders. According to Sky News, Clifford used to work as a private security guard.\n\nTwo helicopters were seen near Clifford's home in Enfield, flying over the Hilly Fields park opposite his residence, while a nearby primary school kept its pupils in lockdown as a precaution, as the search continued.\n\nEarlier today, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nMeanwhile, members of the public were warned not to approach the 26-year-old, who was thought to be armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said earlier today: \"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe BBC said in a note to its 5 Live staff: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nTV racing commentator Matt Chapman tweeted: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nHunt's daughter Louise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, MyLondon reported.\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media read: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nThe murders have also sent shockwaves through the community in Bushey, as residents were seen leaving flowers at the scene today following the tragic aged 25, 28 and 61 - were found with serious injuries after officers were called to a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire on Tuesday evening.\n\nDespite the efforts of paramedics, the women died at the scene shortly after emergency services arrived, just before 7pm, Hertfordshire Police said.\n\nPolice issue plea to potentially armed triple-murder suspect to 'make contact'\n\nPolice have been searching through the night for 26-year-old Mr Clifford from the Enfield area, with an extensive manhunt now under way in Hertfordshire and north London. He is wanted in connection with the triple murder, police said.\n\nMembers of the public have been urged not to approach him as he may be carrying a crossbow potentially used in the triple murder alongside other weapons, according to police.\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently there is no {"uri": "8218869564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:17:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:17:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:16:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/crossbow-murders-live-kyle-clifford-33212693", "title": "Crossbow murder hunt as BBC star's wife and daughters killed - updates", "body": "BBC commentator John Hunt's wife and daughters were murdered - a manhunt is under way for Kyle Clifford\n\nA manhunt is underway after the wife and daughters of BBC sport commentator John Hunt were murdered in their own home in a leafy Hertfordshire town.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, are thought to have been discovered with fatal injuries by Mr Hunt when he returned to the family home in Bushey from his work at BBC Five Live racing on Tuesday evening. Despite the efforts of emergency services the women all died at the scene.\n\nMain suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is being hunted by police following the gruesome discovery and officers have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nClifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokeswoman for the force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford was \"wanted in connection with murder\". He said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThis is a live story. Hertfordshire Police officers rushed to a home in Bushey, at around 7pm yesterday. All three were pronounced dead at the scene having been found seriously injured.\n\nThis morning (Wednesday, July 10), the force said it has been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the incident. Herts Police say Mr Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or North London and have warned people not to approach him as he may still be armed.\n\nHertfordshire police and crime commissioner Jonathan Ash-Edwards said: \"My thoughts are with the family and friends of the women who have been shockingly killed in this terrible incident in Bushey. It will no doubt send shockwaves through the local community and across Hertfordshire.\n\nBushey 'murder' live: Hunt for Enfield man who may be armed with crossbow after 3 women killed\n\n\"I am being kept updated by the police and I urge the public to support the police with any information about the whereabouts of the named suspect.\"\n\nWhen the 'murders' happened\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, is thought to have killed a mum and her two daughters with a crossbow yesterday (July 9). The trio were 25, 28 and 61 years old and were all pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nWhere did the 'murders' happen?\n\nHertfordshire Police officers rushed to a home on Ashlyn Close, Bushey, at around 7pm yesterday (July 9). A 46-year-old local, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\nWho are the victims?\n\nThe three women 'murdered' with a crossbow in their home in Bushey have been identified. Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, aged 61, 28 and 25 respectively, died following the attack in Ashlyn Close yesterday evening (Tuesday, July 9). They are reportedly the wife and two daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, reports The Telegraph.\n\nWho is Kyle Clifford?\n\nVery little is know about Kyle Clifford or the motivation behind the 'murders'. However the 26-year-old is the main suspect in the Bushey 'murders' and is thought to be armed with a crossbow. If seen, under no circumstance should he be approached.\n\nThe force said it has been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the incident. Herts Police say Mr Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or North London and have warned people not to approach him as he may still be armed.\n\nWhat the Chief Superintendent has said\n\nAddressing Clifford directly earlier, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\" A resident of Ashlyn Close in Bushey where police are investigating the murders of three women said they heard screaming on Tuesday evening as the \"absolutely traumatic\" incident unfolded.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe same resident, 46, said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly. They also saw armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nWhat to do if you see Kyle Clifford\n\nClifford is believed to still be armed with the crossbow and must not be approached under any circumstances. If you think you've seen him, dial 999 immediately.\n\nGet the biggest stories from around London straight to your inbox. {"uri": "8219279155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:24:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/manhunt-know-deadly-crossbow-attack-161653448.html", "title": "How manhunt for crossbow triple murder suspect unfolded", "body": "This article contains details some readers may find distressing.\n\nA triple murder suspect has been captured following the killing of a BBC racing commentator's wife and two daughters on Tuesday.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, was found in the Enfield area by police officers on Wednesday afternoon following a full-scale manhunt in Hertfordshire and north London,\n\nPolice believe Tuesday evening's attack was targeted and carried out with a crossbow, as well as possibly with other weapons.\n\nThree women were were found seriously injured just before 19:00 BST on Tuesday evening in an attack which police believe involved a crossbow.\n\nAll three victims died at the scene in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nA full-scale manhunt has taken place today to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is from Enfield, north London, and used to work as a security guard.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams responded \"at pace\", and were deployed to various locations in north London and the Bushey area of Hertfordshire.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, armed officers and ambulance staff were seen at a cemetery close to where a house was searched in Enfield.\n\nThe cemetery was closed off and an air ambulance was seen nearby.\n\nHertfordshire Police later said that Kyle Clifford had been apprehended \"with no shots fired\" by police. He is receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries.\n\nThey were: Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC commentator John Hunt, and two of their three daughters - Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nDetails are still emerging about the suspect but it is believed that Kyle Clifford left the British Army after a short period of service in 2022.\n\nPolice are treating the killings as a \"targeted incident\", and said they believe the suspect was known to the victims.\n\nHertfordshire Police said shortly after apprehending Mr Clifford that he was found with injuries and is receiving treatment.\n\nThe police warned the public on Wednesday not to approach the suspect, who might have been in possession of a crossbow.\n\nThey also appealed to anyone who was near Ashlyn Close between lunchtime and early evening on Tuesday to get in touch.\n\nOne local councillor, Louise Nicholas, said there was support available for residents affected by what has happened.\n\nHertfordshire Police announced Mr Clifford had been found just before 18:30 on Wednesday, adding that no shots were fired.\n\nDet Insp Justine Jenkins, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said this is an \"incredibly difficult time for the victims' family\".\n\n\"We would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nShe said the investigation \"is moving at pace\" and police have yet to formally identify the victims.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" she added.\n\nJohn Hunt works for BBC Five Live as a racing commentator.\n\nA spokesperson for the channel said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nRacing broadcasters have also been offering their condolences.\n\nOne of them, Matt Chapman, posted on X, saying it was \"impossible to comprehend the pain\".\n\n\"Just know we are all here for you, John. We love you pal - racing loves you,\" he said.\n\nCommentator Mike Vince said on X that his \"heart bleeds\" for Mr Hunt, adding the incident was \"simply shattering\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said its team was \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic deaths\".\n\n\"Our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time,\" it posted on X.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper {"uri": "8218857015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:12:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:12:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:09:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13620111/Wife-two-daughters-BBC-racing-commentator-killed-crossbow-attack.html", "title": "Wife and two daughters of BBC racing commentator killed in crossbow...", "body": "The wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator have been killed in a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters died in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening, PA understands.\n\nA massive manhunt has been launched for their suspected killer, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, who is wanted in connection with the murders of the three women in Bushey (Hertfordshire Constabulary/PA)\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died, in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in an entry on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28.\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\n(PA Graphics)\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson, of Hertfordshire Police, speaks to media outside Hatfield Police Station (Jacob King/PA)\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8220065745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "08:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T08:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T08:32:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/jul/11/police-find-suspect-in-crossbow-killings/", "title": "Police find suspect in crossbow killings", "body": "LONDON -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nFootage from Sky News showed the suspect being carried on a stretcher out of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, which is close to his home and around 17 miles to the east from the site of the killings. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff had massed around the cemetery through the day.\n\nThe public had been urged not to approach Clifford, who the BBC reported had been in the British Army for a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nPolice and emergency services at the scene in Ashlyn Close, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow on Wednesday after three women were killed in a house near London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt. (James Manning/PA via AP)\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police speaks to media outside Hatfield Police Station after an incident in Bushey on Tuesday evening, in Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London. Hertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder. (Jacob King/PA via AP)\n\nA forensic officer at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London. Hertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder. {"uri": "8218819234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:45:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:45:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:45:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10614220/uk-manhunt-crossbow-triple-murder-kyle-clifford/", "title": "Manhunt underway in U.K. for suspected crossbow killer, 3 women dead - National | Globalnews.ca", "body": "A manhunt is underway in the U.K. as police search for a suspect accused of murdering three women with a crossbow in a home north of London.\n\nThe Hertfordshire police are searching for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, who authorities believe killed three women in the town of Bushey on Tuesday evening.\n\nPolice have not named the victims, aged 25, 28 and 61, but said they are believed to be related.\n\nThe BBC has identified the women as the wife and two daughters of BBC radio commentator John Hunt.\n\nAuthorities said they responded to a call at a home in the Ashlyn Close neighbourhood around 7 p.m. local time on Tuesday. First responders discovered three women with serious injuries.\n\nDespite paramedics' best efforts, all of the women died at the scene \"a short time later,\" police said.\n\nThe manhunt for Clifford began Tuesday night and has continued throughout Wednesday morning.\n\nDuring a news conference Wednesday morning, police said the attack was likely \"targeted.\" Authorities revealed that other weapons may have been used in the \"horrific incident,\" as well as a crossbow.\n\n\"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" said Det. {"uri": "8218684939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:22:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:22:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:22:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/inside-kyle-clifford-manhunt-after-33209595", "title": "Inside Kyle Clifford manhunt after 3 murdered - search area and crossbow warning", "body": "A man suspected of killing three women is on the run, and may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nPolice are looking for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, in connection with the deaths of the women who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday. Emergency services, including two air ambulances, were sent to the property, and despite their best efforts to save the women - all believed to be related - they died at the scene.\n\nThe women, aged 25, 28, and 61, were \"targeted\" and attacked with a crossbow and other weapons, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police said. The victims are believed to be the wife and two daughters of BBC 5Live racing commentator John Hunt, the Telegraph reports.\n\nMr Hunt, 58, who is married with three daughters, had reportedly been working on Tuesday evening and when he returned home from his shift, is believed to have raised the alarm to police. The Constabulary has since launched a manhunt to find the suspect and have been looking for him throughout the night and this morning.\n\nThey have warned he may still be in possession of weapons and have asked the public to dial 999 if they see him, and to not approach him. Directly appealing to the suspect, Chief Sup Simpson said: \"Kyle if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact.\" Investigators believe the man could also be in Hertfordshire or around his home in north London.\n\nChief Supt Simpson told reporters: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, also called for anyone with information to come forward. Detective Supt Hall said: \"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon. Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she didn't know the victims well but said they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\" Another neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s, commented: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\" A further resident living in Ashlyn Close said they heard screams from the house located in the quiet cul de sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out.\n\nThe 46-year-old said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors. She added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone. I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths. An East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey. Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\" The manhunt comes after the Tory Government considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nYou can report information online, speak to an operator in the Force Communications Room via the police's online web chat or call the non-emergency number 101, quoting Op Infauna. Alternatively, you can stay anonymous by contacting the independent charity Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or via their untraceable online form.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA huge manhunt was launched after a woman and her two daughters were killed in a horrific crossbow attack. Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC commentator John Hunt, and two of their three daughters - Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28 - were found severely injured inside a home in Hertfordshire.\n\nTragically, they all died of their wounds on Tuesday, July 9. Police quickly established Kyle Clifford, 26, as the prime suspect in the case and officers launched a major operation to locate him.\n\nKyle is the ex-partner of one of the victims. He was found injured but alive yesterday (Wednesday, July 10).\n\nPOLL: Should the DWP be able to monitor benefit claimants' bank accounts?\n\nGet breaking news on BirminghamLive WhatsApp\n\nHere is everything we know so far.\n\nTimeline of manhunt: Police officers were called to Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire, just before 7pm on Tuesday, after a neighbour reported hearing screaming The three women were found seriously injured and died at the scene despite the efforts of paramedics Armed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday at around 8am Police confirmed the killings were \"targeted\" and warned the public not to approach Mr Clifford, saying that he may be in the possession of a crossbow Police helicopters and armed officers were deployed on Wednesday to find the suspect Hertfordshire Police issued a statement just before 6.30pm on Wednesday announcing officers had found and apprehended Clifford in Enfield The force said he was receiving treatment after being found with injuries Who are the victims?\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28. The victims are the wife and children of BBC racing commentator, John Hunt. The couple are believed to have a third daughter, Amy, who reportedly lives in Birmingham.\n\nWhere did the attack happen?\n\nAll three victims died inside a home on Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire at around 7pm on Tuesday, July 9\n\nWhere was Kyle Clifford found?\n\nOn the afternoon of Wednesday, July 10, armed officers and ambulance staff were seen at a cemetery close to where a house was searched in Enfield. The cemetery was closed off and an air ambulance was seen nearby.\n\nHertfordshire Police later said that Kyle Clifford had been apprehended \"with no shots fired\" by police. He is receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries.\n\nWho is Kyle Clifford?\n\nIt is believed that Kyle Clifford left the British Army after a short period of service in 2022. Police are treating the killings as a \"targeted incident\", and said they believe the suspect was known to the victims as he was reportedly one of the daughter's ex-boyfriend.\n\nHertfordshire Police said shortly after apprehending Clifford that he was found with injuries and is receiving treatment. Kyles's brother, Bradley Clifford, is currently serving a life sentence for murdering a teen moped driver.\n\nWhat have the police said?\n\nDet Insp Justine Jenkins, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said this is an \"incredibly difficult time for the victims' family\". She said: \"We would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\nShe said the investigation \"is moving at pace\" and police have yet to formally identify the victims. \"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" she added.\n\nWhat has the BBC said?\n\nA spokesperson for the BBC said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nRacing broadcasters have also been offering their condolences. would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no {"uri": "2024-07-417658763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:53:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:53:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:09:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/uk-police-are-searching-for-a-man-after-wife-daughters-of-bbc-commentator-killed/", "title": "UK Police are Searching for a Man after Wife, Daughters of BBC Commentator Killed", "body": "A forensic officer at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London. Hertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder. (Jacob King/PA via AP)\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/triple-murder-suspect-found-crossbow-173910347.html", "title": "Triple murder suspect found after crossbow deaths of three women", "body": "Triple murder suspect found after crossbow deaths of three women\n\nPA reporters\n\n10 July 2024 at 7:53 pm\n\nTriple murder suspect Kyle Clifford has been found following the crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nClifford, 26, was found in the Enfield area of north London on Wednesday afternoon, Hertfordshire Police said.\n\nHe is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries.\n\nNo shots were fired by police, the force said.\n\nClifford, was wanted in connection with the deaths of Carol Hunt, wife of BBC racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters Hannah and Louise in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nThe force said they believe he was known to the victims.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was located, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nDuring the manhunt for the suspect, the force said they believed he may have been armed with a crossbow and warned the public not to approach him.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the broadcaster said it would provide Mr Hunt with \"all the support we can\".\n\nThe note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice said they were {"uri": "8218810296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:39:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:39:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:39:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/crossbow-triple-murder-horrifying-final-33211126", "title": "Final moments of 'Crossbow' victims - 'screams, tied up and found by dad'", "body": "Three women were tragically murdered last night in their own home, with their suspected killer still on the run.\n\nPolice are searching for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, in connection with the deaths of the mother and two daughters. Police and emergency services, including two air ambulances, were sent to the property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nThe women, who have now been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, were found fatally injured in the house and despite best efforts to save them, the three died at the scene. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, of Hertfordshire Police, said the women were \"targeted\" and attacked with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThey are the wife and two daughters of BBC 5Live racing commentator John Hunt. Mr Hunt, 58, who is married with three daughters, had reportedly been working on Tuesday evening and when he came home from his shift, is believed to have returned to the harrowing scene.\n\nThe father-of-three is said to have been the one to raise the alarm to police. MailOnline claims police sources said the three women were tied up before being shot. Hertfordshire Constabulary has launched a manhunt to find the suspect and have been looking for him throughout the night and this morning. They have warned he may still be in possession of weapons and have asked the public to dial 999 if they see him, and to not approach him.\n\nDirectly appealing to the suspect, believed to still be in Hertfordshire or in north London, Chief Sup Simpson said: \"Kyle if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact.\" He continued: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nA resident living at Ashlyn Close said they heard screams from the house located in the quiet cul de sac where three women died before 'absolute chaos' broke out. The 46-year-old said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\" She said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help. It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone. I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she didn't know the victims well but said they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nA further local, named Riaz, who is in his 50s, commented: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, has called for anyone with information to come forward. Detective Supt Hall said: \"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon. Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nAerial shots of the scene aired on the BBC show a blue and white forensic tent in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul de sac, with a police officer on guard and several police vehicles parked nearby. Local councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey. Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\" The manhunt comes after the Tory Government considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nYou can report information online, speak to an operator in the Force Communications Room via the police's online web chat or call the non-emergency number 101, quoting Op Infauna. Alternatively, you can stay anonymous by contacting the independent charity Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or via their untraceable online form.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", Police are looking for Kyle Clifford, 26, in connection with the incident, which happened in Bushey on Tuesday (July 9).\n\nOfficers and paramedics were called to a property in Ashlyn Close just before 7pm and found three women with \"serious injuries\" on arrival, Hertfordshire Police said. \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene,\" the force added.\n\nThey have since been searching for Clifford, who is from the Enfield area, throughout the night. Here's everything we know so far:\n\nREAD MORE: Wales rugby international dies\n\nREAD MORE: Two children die at same primary school which closed due to infection outbreak\n\nWho were the victims?\n\nIt understood that the victims were the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who according to reports had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home.\n\nHertfordshire Police has not yet confirmed the identities of the victims, but confirmed in a press conference on Wednesday lunchtime that the women were believed to be related to each other and were aged 25, 28 and 61. Join our WhatsApp news community here for the latest breaking news\n\n'Crossbow' believed to be involved\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the incident involved what is \"believed to be a crossbow but other weapons may also have been used.\" He also said the incident was thought to be \"targeted.\"\n\nThe force has warned the public Clifford may still have weapons on him. In an initial public appeal, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThis warning was reiterated in the press conference, with Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson saying \"our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford.\"\n\n'Extensive' police resources deployed\n\nPolice are \"actively seeking\" Clifford, who they believe is could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. \"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area,\" said Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson. \"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident.\"\n\nClifford urged to hand himself in\n\nIn the press conference, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson addressed the suspect directly, telling him: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police via 999.\"\n\nThe force has also urged anyone in the area to come forward with information that could help their investigation. \"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us,\" said Detective Superintendent Rob Hall in a statement.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nPeople can report information that could help this investigation, quoting \"Op Infauna\", by filling out Hertfordshire Police's online reporting form, speaking to an operator in their Force Communications Room via online web chat, or calling 101. {"uri": "2024-07-417801816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:26:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:26:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:05:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police/article_93c1d8a9-8286-5717-abaa-9ff2b94cd62e.html", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "Police and emergency services at the scene in Ashlyn Close, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow on Wednesday after three women were killed in a house near London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but said they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Louise and Hannah, aged 25 and 28 respectively.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford. Enfield is around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should Officers attended alongside colleagues from the East of England Ambulance Service and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries,\" the post said. \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\n\n\"Police have since been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\"\n\nIn a statement included in the post, Rob Hall, detective superintendent of the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said, \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\"\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately,\" Hall said. \"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThat weapon, according to the BBC, is the crossbow that was alleged to have been used in the killings.\n\nJon Simpson, chief superintendent of the Hertfordshire Constabulary, spoke about the horrific incident at a news conference.\n\n\"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident,\" Simpson said.\n\nOne of the victims has been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of the BBC commentator.
