Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28.\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\"\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\"\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no {"uri": "2024-07-417499467", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:33:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:33:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:31:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/manhunt-underway-after-3-women-killed-in-london-crossbow-attack-20240710", "title": "Manhunt underway after 3 women killed in London crossbow attack", "body": "Armed police officers and search teams in north London are on the hunt for Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with an alleged crossbow attack that left three women dead. (Facebook/Herts Police)\n\nPolice in north London are on the hunt for Kyle Clifford, a 26-year-old man wanted in connection with the alleged crossbow murders of three women.\n\nPolice were summoned to a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, on Tuesday evening, where they found three women with serious injuries. The women, aged 25, 28 and 61, are believed to be related. All three died from their injuries.\n\n\"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" said Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit in a statement.\n\nHall said the murder investigation was in its early stages, but police were actively seeking Clifford, who hails from Enfield. He is believed to be in Hertfordshire or North London.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson, the head of local policing for the Hertfordshire Constabulary, said the manhunt involved armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon,\" said Hall.\n\nAccording to the BBC, the weapon used in the incident was a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\n\nHall said police enquiries would continue over the coming days to gain an understanding of the triple murder's full circumstances.\n\n\"...I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 19:00, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us,\" he added.\n\nAdditional police {"uri": "2024-07-417700573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:32:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:32:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:32:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cx02lxg7x7eo", "title": "Manhunt: What do we know about deadly crossbow attack?", "body": "This article contains details some readers may find distressing.\n\nThree women were killed at about 19:00 on Tuesday evening in an attack which police believe involved a crossbow. Officers think that other weapons may also have been used.\n\nAll three victims are reported to have died at the scene in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nA full-scale manhunt is under way to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is from Enfield, north London, and used to work as a security guard.\n\nArmed policer officers and specialist search teams have been \"responding at pace\", deployed to various locations in north London and the Bushey area of Hertfordshire.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, armed officers and ambulance staff were seen at a cemetery close to where a house was searched in the Enfield area of north London.\n\nThe cemetery has been closed off and an air ambulance was seen nearby.\n\nThey were: Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC commentator John Hunt, and two of their three daughters - Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nDetails are still emerging about the suspect but it is believed that Kyle Clifford left the British Army after a short period of service in 2022.\n\nPolice are treating the killings as a \"targeted incident\".\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police appealed directly to the suspect, saying: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nPolice officers were called to Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire, just before 19:00 on Tuesday, after a neighbour reported hearing screamingThe three women were found seriously injured and died at the scene despite the efforts of paramedicsArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday at around 08:00 Police confirmed that the murder was \"targeted\" and have warned the public not to approach Mr Clifford \"Extensive police resources\", including helicopters and armed officers, have been deployed to find the suspect\n\nThe police have warned the public not to approach Mr Clifford, who may still be in possession of a crossbow - anyone spotting him is being advised to dial 999 immediately.\n\nThey have also appealed to anyone who was near Ashlyn Close between lunchtime and early evening on Tuesday to get in touch.\n\nOne local councillor, Louise Nicholas, has said there is support available for residents affected by what has happened.\n\nJohn Hunt works for BBC Five Live as a racing commentator.\n\nA spokesperson for the channel said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\"\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nRacing broadcasters have also been offering their condolences.\n\nOne of them, Matt Chapman, posted on X, saying it was \"impossible to comprehend the pain\".\n\n\"Just know we are all here for you, John. We love you pal - racing loves you,\" he says.\n\nCommentator Mike Vince has said on X that his \"heart bleeds\" for Mr Hunt, adding that the incident was \"simply shattering\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said its team was \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic deaths\".\n\n\"Our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time,\" it posted on X.\n\nHome Secretary They attended alongside paramedics from the East of England Ambulance Service and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries.\n\nDespite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\n\nPolice have since been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nPeople have been warned not to approach Kyle Clifford as he may still be armed with a weapon, police said.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. {"uri": "8219029918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:01:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:01:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:01:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/moment-murder-suspect-kyle-clifford-33213571", "title": "Moment triple murder suspect leaves home with 'crossbow' after 3 women killed", "body": "Chilling footage has emerged appearing to show Kyle Clifford - the suspect of a triple murder - flee the scene with a 3ft crossbow.\n\nIn the clip, a man is seen emerging from an alleyway that leads to the property in Hertfordshire, where the three women were found dead. The man, dressed in all black, is then seen pacing towards a vehicle armed with a large object underneath his right arm, which appears to be covered in cloth.\n\nHe was also filmed carrying a bag that police fear could contain even more weapons, before climbing into a black seat of the vehicle. The same car was found abandoned earlier today in Enfield.\n\nA manhunt is now underway for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford following the murders. The victims were later identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nFollow along with our live blog here\n\nThey are thought to have been discovered with fatal injuries by Mr Hunt when he returned to the family home in Bushey from his work at BBC Five Live racing on Tuesday evening. Despite the efforts of emergency services the women all died at the scene.\n\nClifford, from Enfield in North London, is believed to be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area, but police have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokeswoman for the force warning that the 26-year-old may be in possession of a crossbow.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident\" and Clifford was \"wanted in connection with murder\". He said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nIt is understood racing commentator John Hunt been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home. The BBC said in a note to its 5 Live staff: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to his daughter Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nLouise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, the website reported.\n\nThe ongoing manhunt for Clifford has so far seen armed police search an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield. The house, close to Gordon Hill railway station, was swarmed by officers on Wednesday morning, according to neighbours. Two officers were stood outside the property at 1.30pm, after a cordon was removed.\n\nOne neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off. It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day. I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\nThe murders have continued to send shockwaves through the community in Bushey, with some residents Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon (Wednesday July 10),\" the statement said.\n\n\"At this stage, we believe the suspect was known to the victims,\" it added.\n\nPolice had earlier said they were searching for a 26-year-old man, named as Kyle Clifford, in connection with the deaths, who could be in the British capital or the neighboring county of Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice were called to a house in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening, where they found three seriously injured women who later died from their wounds.\n\nThe victims of the triple murder were identified as the wife, Carol Hunt, and two daughters, of BBC racing commentator John Hunt, the UK's public broadcaster said on Wednesday. {"uri": "2024-07-417510780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:41:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:41:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:32:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/wife-two-daughters-bbc-racing-132153187.html", "title": "Wife and two daughters of BBC racing commentator killed in crossbow attack", "body": "Wife and two daughters of BBC racing commentator killed in crossbow attack\n\nPA reporters\n\n10 July 2024 at 3:32 pm\n\nThe wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator have been killed in a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters died in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening, PA understands.\n\nA massive manhunt has been launched for their suspected killer, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died, in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in an entry on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28.\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, {"uri": "8220343013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "11:21:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T11:21:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T11:19:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.mylondon.news/news/north-london-news/complete-timeline-bushey-triple-crossbow-29520724", "title": "Complete timeline of Bushey triple crossbow killing and manhunt", "body": "Three women were killed in their Hertfordshire home on Tuesday evening (July 9) and a huge manhunt ended with police detaining prime suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, in Enfield. The killings were done by crossbow, police said, and happened in Bushey on Ashlyn Close at about 7pm on July 9. Clifford was caught in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield with serious injuries.\n\nThe victims were confirmed as Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, aged 61, 28, and 25. This is the entirety of BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt's family who is the only one to have survived them and has been reported to have been the one to have found them after the attack.\n\nThe investigation has been spread out over three days and two counties so we have put together a timeline of key events to help piece together what is known so far.\n\nREAD MORE: Bushey 'murder' investigation mapped as Clifford tracked down 16 miles away in cemetery\n\nTime Line Bushey triple murder timeline 7pm Tuesday, July 9 - Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt found dead\n\nPolice were called to Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, to reports that three women were seriously injured in their home. Police and paramedics attend but they were sadly pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe Telegraph reported that BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, father to Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, and husband to Carol, 61, may have found the bodies of his family in their home on returning from a racecourse and raised the alarm.\n\n'15 minutes later' armed police attend and 'lockdown' the street\n\nA 46-year-old Ashlyn Close resident told PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe same resident said there were 16 police cars, ambulances and helicopters. Police were knocking on doors questioning neighbours and asking for CCTV footage.\n\nThe manhunt for Kyle Clifford begins\n\nA huge manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, began soon after the killings and went on through the night. Police believe that he was known to the victims and that a crossbow was used to kill them.\n\nAbout 8am Wednesday, July 10 - Police warn public Kyle Clifford may be armed with crossbow\n\nAs the manhunt continues into the next morning Hertfordshire Police warn that their prime suspect Kyle Clifford may be armed with a crossbow. They tell the public not to approach him if he is spotted but to call 999 from a safe place.\n\nPolice also put out an appeal for information to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm.\n\n10-11am - Neighbours and the Home Secretary react to the killings\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper posted on X describing the attacks as \"truly shocking\" and said she was being \"kept fully updated\" on the situation.\n\nNeighbours who live close to the scene also commented. Riaz, a man in his 50s who lives close by, said the incident was \"tragic\" adding: \"It's a serene, quiet road, but there was over a dozen cars here. It's quite disturbing, but any tragedy like this has a bearing on how you feel.\"\n\nOne anonymous Ashlyn Close neighbour said she heard screaming from the house\n\n12pm-1pm - Police say they believe this was a targeted attack and victims named\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police said the three women were aged 25, 28 and 61, and died in a \"targeted\" attack in a press conference at about 12pm.\n\nThe victims were named an hour later as Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, the family of BBC commentator John Hunt.\n\nSchools were also advised to keep children inside at this time.\n\n1:30pm - Police search address in Enfield\n\nPolice searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued.\n\nOne neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off. It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day. I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\n2pm - 5pm - Manhunt continues with schools locking down and floral tributes laid\n\nThe manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued with several schools locking down their children for safety. During this time it was established that Kyle Clifford served in the British Army for a short period until 2022. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper's department said that it was looking into reviewing controls on crossbows.\n\n5-6pm - Kyle Clifford found in Enfield cemetery\n\nArmed police found Kyle Clifford in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield. He was found with serious injuries and detained by police but not formally arrested. He was taken to hospital where he remains this morning (July 11). No shots were fired by police.\n\nThursday, 11 July - Kyle Clifford remains in hospital\n\nKyle Clifford remains in hospital after being found injured in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield. Police are due to give an update on the situation this morning.\n\nGet the biggest stories from around London straight to your inbox. More info\n\nA manhunt has been launched for the suspected killer of the wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator after they were killed in a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters, aged 25 and 28, died in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening, the PA news agency reports. Police have appealed to members of the public for help in tracing 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued, and the public have been warned not to approach him as he may be in possession of a crossbow. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters in a press conference on Wednesday that the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nREAD MORE: Questions remain unanswered as search for Jay Slater goes into fourth week\n\nKeep up to date with all the latest breaking news and top stories from the North East with our free newsletter\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he added: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\" The force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour, who asked not to be named, described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday, telling the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown,\" she added. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died in a post on the broadcaster's news website, leading to an outpouring of tributes posted on social media by figures from the racing world. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nDramatic video from the scene shows a mass of police cars parked along the road and two armed police officers standing guard.\n\nAnother Herfordshire local today claimed 'there has been a helicopter circling all morning' close to the Bushey border.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n'Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n'This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. {"uri": "8218713873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:41:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:41:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:41:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/john-hunt-bbc-commentator-bushey-29514841", "title": "BBC commentator's wife and daughters victims of triple murder", "body": "Police have urged the chief suspect in the 'horrific' murders of three women - understood to be the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator - to hand himself in.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted in connection with the killings of three women. Police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons, the Mirror reports.\n\nThe victims are reported to be the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who it is understood had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home. Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, aged 61, 28 and 25 have since been named as the victims, MyLondon reports.\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a 'targeted incident' and Clifford, 26, was 'wanted in connection with murder'.\n\nREAD MORE: Missing Jay Slater: Inside the Tenerife drugs underworld as island branded 'the new Amsterdam'\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\"\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\"\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our potentially armed triple-murder suspect to 'make contact'", "body": "Clifford, from Enfield, north London, is wanted over the deaths of the women, aged 25, 28 and 61, who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nMr Simpson repeated warnings to the public not to approach the suspect, but to call 999 if they see him.\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed officers searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the search continued.\n\nHertfordshire Police said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nEast of England Ambulance Service said three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle and the Hazardous Area Response Team were also sent to the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable "body": "Man suspected of murdering three women may have crossbow, police fear\n\nPA Reporters\n\n10 July 2024 at 11:47 am\n\nA 26-year-old man being sought over the murders of three women may have a crossbow, police have said.\n\nKyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, is wanted over the deaths of the women who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nHertfordshire Police warned that he may still be in possession of a weapon and that members of the public should dial 999 if they see him.\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, They have issued a warning to the public urging them not to approach him and instead call 999 immediately if they see him.\n\nAt a press conference today, Hertfordshire Police urged Clifford to 'make contact with the police' as the suspect in the killings remains at large.\n\nClifford, from Enfield, north London, used to work as a security guard, it has been reported.\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac was swarming with armed police and forensic officers as the triple murder investigation continued.\n\nLouise's father John was working at Lingfield Park race course yesterday before returning home to discover the horror that had unfolded.\n\nShocked neighbours said Louise ran a dog grooming business called Groom and Glow from the detached house in a cul-de-sac.\n\nLocal resident William Nourallah paid tribute to the 'beautiful young girl'.\n\nHe said: 'She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father\n\n'She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. She was a beautiful young girl. It's a waste of a life.'\n\nAnother neighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said that Louise had been left upset at breaking up with a boyfriend and crashed her car last week as a result.\n\nHe said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house.\n\n'I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it. So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house.\n\n'Another dog groomer - who is a friend of Louise's - told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.\n\n'Who the boyfriend was, I don't know, I never saw him. I believe Hannah, Louise's sister, was also killed along with their mother Carol.\n\n'I didn't know Hannah too well but Carol was very quaint, a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'Her husband John is a BBC radio commentator. He commentates on horse racing mostly. I believe he may have been at Lingfield racecourse yesterday.\n\n'This is such an awful incident, the whole community is in shock.'\n\nA neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nIn a note sent to staff at BBC Five Live today, the corporation described the incident as 'utterly devastating'.\n\nThe note read: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be 'targeted'.\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who 'may be in possession of a crossbow'.\n\nHe said: 'Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n'We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n'The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.'\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: 'Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.'\n\nArmed police were seen forcing their way into a house in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, this morning in a raid that is believed to be related to the horrific killings.\n\nThe house, which is close to Gordon Hill railway station, had two officers stood guard outside this afternoon hours after helicopters were seen patrolling the skies overhead.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings of the three women who were found in Bushey, Hertfordshire, and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X, formerly Twitter: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nEarlier today police revealed they were looking for Kyle Clifford following the incident and warned members of the public to call 999 immediately if they saw him.\n\nIn a statement released this morning Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n'Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n'This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.'\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: 'We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n'Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n'Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.'", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", {"uri": "2024-07-417588286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:51:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:51:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-10/uk-police-are-searching-for-a-man-after-wife-daughters-of-bbc-commentator-killed", "title": "UK Police Are Searching for a Man After Wife, Daughters of BBC Commentator Killed", "body": "A forensic officer at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London. Hertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder. (Jacob King/PA via AP)\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police were hunting Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house just northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which potentially involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. The BBC has said the incident was \"utterly devastating\".\n\nIt's believed the three were killed with a crossbow. Footage has emerged of a man carrying a large object close to the murder scene.\n\nFollowing a manhunt for hours across north London, police said they arrested 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, who is believed to be the ex-boyfriend of Louise Hunt.\n\nPolice officers at a house in Ashlyn Close on July 10, 2024 in Bushey, England. (Photo by Leon Neal/Getty Images)\n\nMrs Hunt was 61 years old with Hannah aged 28 and Louise 25. The family also has a third daughter.\n\nPolice were called to Ashlyn Close, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, at 7pm on Tuesday (1am Wednesday AEST).\n\nBushey is on the suburban fringe of north west London just south of the large town of Watford.\n\nThe BBC has extensive facilities close to Bushey including the studios and set for major soap EastEnders.\n\nHunt had been working at the Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey, south west of London, and then returned home to discover the horror scene, reported The Sun.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Mr Clifford, who is from Enfield in north London, was likely still armed as he was tracked down overnight and into Wednesday.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon police raided an address in Enfield, about 27km east of Bushey. Police also visited another address and a cemetery in Enfield.\n\n\"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off,\" a neighbour said.\n\nAt 6.20pm (3.20am Thursday AEST), police said they had arrested a man in a cemetery in Enfield in connection with the triple killing.\n\nVictim Luise Hunt.\n\n\"Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon,\" said Hertfordshire Police.\n\n\"He is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries. No shots were fired by police.\"\n\nPolice said no one else was being sought in connection with the investigation.\n\nHannah Hunt also died.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said it was \"an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family,\" and asked for privacy so they could \"come to terms with what has happened\".\n\nThe BBC has said that Mr Clifford was in the British Army for a short period in 2022.\n\nPolice have arrested Kyle Clifford. A neighbour said screams were heard from a house in the quiet cul-de-sac where Mr Hunt's wife Carol and their two daughter's Hannah and Louise died.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to be armed with a crossbow.\n\nREAD MORE Bushey triple murder LIVE: BBC commentator John Hunt's wife and daughters named as victims - updates\n\nThe victims have now been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt who later died of their injuries.\n\nOn Wednesday (July 10), Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a 'targeted incident' and that Clifford, 26, was 'wanted in connection with murder'.\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\n\n\"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nAerial shots of the scene aired on the BBC show a blue and white forensic tent in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul de sac, with a police officer on guard and several police vehicles parked nearby.\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation described the incident which involved the deaths of the wife and daughters of racing commentator John Hunt as 'utterly devastating'.\n\nThe note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. A manhunt for the suspect is underway after police found three women with serious injuries in a home in Ashlyn Close just before 7pm yesterday (Tuesday, July 9).\n\nAll three women, who are believed to be related, died at the scene. Hertfordshire Police has been searching overnight for Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the murders.\n\nOfficers have told the public not to approach him as he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nLIVE: Police hunt Enfield man who may be armed after 3 women killed\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nDS Hall continued: \"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nNeighbours have expressed their shock after three women were murdered just outside of North London. {"uri": "8218618900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:43:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:43:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:42:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/10/screams-heard-as-three-women-murdered-in-quiet-suburban-cul-de-sac/", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "A police manhunt is underway for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London, after the women were killed in Bushey, Hertfordshire on Tuesday.\n\nScreams were heard from a house in a quiet cul de sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Express & {"uri": "8218846676", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:03:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:03:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:03:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/world-news/crossbow-murder-victims-pictured-wife-33212780", "title": "'Crossbow murder' victims pictured as wife and daughters of BBC star", "body": "Police in the UK have urged the chief suspect in the 'horrific' murders of three women - understood to be the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator - to hand himself in.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted in connection with the killings and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons, Mirror UK reports.\n\nThe victims are reported to be the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who it is understood had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home. Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, aged 61, 28 and 25 have since been named as the victims, MyLondon reports.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a 'targeted incident' and Clifford, 26, was 'wanted in connection with murder'.\n\nREAD MORE: 'Crossbow-armed suspect' wanted after murder of 'BBC star's wife and daughters'\n\nREAD MORE: Sister of woman strangled to death by partner 'very upset' at verdict of murder by reason of insanity\n\nHe said today: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Police believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe British Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". In a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\"\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\"\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. More info\n\nArmed officers have been seen combing local allotments and a cemetery after the wife and daughters of BBC sport commentator John Hunt were murdered in their own home in a leafy town.\n\nA manhunt is underway after Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, were discovered with fatal injuries by Mr Hunt.\n\nIt's understood John returned to the family home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, from his work at BBC Five Live racing on Tuesday evening - and despite the efforts of emergency services the three women all died at the scene.\n\nMain suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is being hunted by police following the gruesome discovery and officers have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nClifford is from Enfield and police have been seen swarming allotments with an ambulance seen at a nearby cemetery in the area this afternoon.\n\nWitnesses spotted an ambulance arriving at the Lavender Hill cemetery in North London which was being searched by armed police.\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show emergency services rushing towards a cemetery in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued. Armed police could also be seen in the video, with Hertfordshire Police saying they were unable to confirm whether they had narrowed their search for the triple murder suspect to the area.\n\nAn ambulance with blue lights was later seen leaving the cemetery -- which is a four minute walk from Kyle Clifford's home address. Armed officers could be seen guarding the gates while an air ambulances circled above the graveyard. Emergency services have not made any confirmation whether the ambulance is connected to the search.\n\nCops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokeswoman for the force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford was \"wanted in connection with murder\". {"uri": "8218750113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:04:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:04:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:03:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/police-hunt-crossbow-armed-kyle-33211525", "title": "Cops hunt 'crossbow-armed' man after murder of 'BBC star's wife and daughters'", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nPolice have launched a major manhunt and made a direct appeal to the main suspect in the 'horrific murders' of three women - believed to be the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commetator.\n\nOfficers are urging the suspect, Kyle Clifford, to give himself up, following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThe victims are reported to be the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who it is understood had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home, reports the Mirror.\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - rushed to a home in Bushley, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nA neighbour claimed screams were heard from a house in the queit cul-de-sac where the three women were murdered. The 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe suspect at the centre of the major manhunt, Kyle Clifford, is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him following the horrific discovery. Officers believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams surrounding the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours shared their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailyrecord.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Record"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dan_warburton@dailyrecord.co.uk", "name": "Dan Warburton",
