{"uri": "8218829248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:51:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/tragic-murder-bbc-star-john-29515634", "title": "'Crossbow-armed suspect' wanted after murder of 'BBC star's wife and daughters'", "body": "Police have made a direct appeal to the chief suspect in the \"horrific\" murders of three women - understood to be the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator - to give himself up.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThe victims are reported to be the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who it is understood had been working for BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home.\n\nREAD MORE: Irish air hostess faces jail in Dubai after alleged domestic attack\n\nREAD MORE: Watch as Northern Ireland's new MPs sworn in at Westminster\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nA neighbour said screams were heard from a house in the quiet cul-de-sac where three women died. The 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\"\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\"\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nFor all the latest news, visit the Belfast Live homepage here and sign up to our daily newsletter here.", "source": {"uri": "belfastlive.co.uk", "dataType": Hertfordshire Police believe the three women were related.\n\nOfficers have said they believe he may be in possession of a crossbow. Anyone who spots him should call 999 immediately and should not approach him.\n\nClifford, from Enfield, may be in Hertfordshire or north London, police believe. Pictures from the current scene show police stationed on Ashlyn Close. A cordon is in place across the street with officers guarding the taped off area and there is also a private ambulance at the scene.\n\nREAD MORE: Two children from same Liverpool primary school die\n\nREAD MORE: City heartbroken over deaths of primary school children\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were 'deeply shocked and saddened' by the news of the deaths of the three women.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\" Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said. \"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\"\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\" Local councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\"\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected. However, they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were 'deeply shocked and saddened' by the news of the deaths. A neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she didn't know them well but described them as a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit has called for anyone with information on this case to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully {"uri": "8218768848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:14:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:14:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:14:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/crossbow-manhunt-triple-murder-victims-33211896", "title": "Crossbow manhunt triple murder victims wife and daughters of BBC commentator", "body": "Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, have been named as those that lost their lives in last night's attack. The BBC confirmed they are the wide and daughters of their commentator John Hunt\n\nThree murder victims have been named as the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator as police continue the manhunt for a killer armed with a crossbow.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, have been named as those that lost their lives in last night's tragic triple killing. The BBC confirmed the names of the dead women, who are the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nMain suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally-injured women and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons. A heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nLouise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, the website reported. The deadly incident is believed to have taken place in leafy Hertfordshire last night. Armed police and ambulances raced to the cul-de-sac in Bushey at about 6.30pm.\n\nA neighbour said screams were heard from a house. The 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown. She said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAnyone with information has been urged to come forward by police and call 999 if they spot him. Officers have appealed directly to Clifford at a press conference today. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"", "source": {"uri": It's alleged Hunt returned home from work to find the three women seriously injured - they were subsequently pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nHunt, who is married with three children, is said to have been working for the BBC on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home at around 7pm, as reported by The Telegraph. The broadcaster's 61-year-old wife Carol has been named locally, with Hertfordshire Police revealing at a press conference Wednesday afternoon that the two other victims were her daughters.\n\nHunt, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last 20 years. ITV racing pundit Matt Chapman took to X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday to share his condolences for his co-star.\n\nHe wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\" A search is underway to find Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the deaths, which took place at a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nCalling on the public for information, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said in a post on X: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. {"uri": "8218734237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:54:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:54:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:53:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/crossbow-armed-suspect-wanted-after-33211749", "title": "'Crossbow-armed suspect' wanted after murder of 'BBC star's wife and daughters'", "body": "Police have made a direct appeal to the chief suspect in the \"horrific\" murders of three women - understood to be the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator - to give himself up.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThe victims are reported to be the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, who it is understood had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home.\n\nREAD MORE: Taylor Swift tickets now cheaper than original prices if you missed Dublin Eras Tour\n\nREAD MORE: Met Eireann July heatwave verdict as weather maps show Ireland sizzling in 26C scorcher\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nA neighbour said screams were heard from a house in the quiet cul-de-sac where three women died. The 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "2024-07-417619130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:16:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:16:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:55:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/world/uk-police-are-searching-for-a-man-after-wife-daughters-of-bbc-commentator-killed/article_f68ccce5-d2ea-55b0-9ae3-86cc9f0ee57e.html", "title": "UK police are searching for a man after wife, daughters of BBC commentator killed", "body": "Police and emergency services at the scene in Ashlyn Close, after an incident on Tuesday evening, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, England, Wednesday, July 10, 2024. British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow on Wednesday after three women were killed in a house near London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8219336191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/more-sports/utterly-devastating-sports-presenters-family-murdered-in-horrific-attack/news-story/b0dc3adbef51a8a72fafa06f5d14975e", "title": "'Utterly devastating': Sports presenter's family murdered in horrific attack", "body": "A UK sports presenter came home to find his wife and two of his daughters fatally injured in what police are calling a \"targeted attack\".\n\nCarol Hunt and her daughters Hannah and Louise were found at their home north of London on Tuesday night, local time, but succumbed to their injuries.\n\nThey are the family of John Hunt, a racing commentator on BBC Radio 5 Live. The BBC has said the incident is \"utterly devastating\".\n\nIt's believed the three were killed with a crossbow. Footage has emerged of a man carrying a large object close to the murder scene.\n\nFollowing a manhunt for hours across north London, police have said they arrested 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, who is believed to be the ex-boyfriend of Louise Hunt.\n\nMrs Hunt was 61 years old with Hannah aged 28 and Louise 25. The family also have a third daughter.\n\nPolice were called to Ashlyn Close, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, at 7pm on Tuesday (1am Wednesday AEST).\n\nBushey is on the suburban fringe of north west London just south of the large town of Watford.\n\nThe BBC has extensive facilities close to Bushey including the studios and set for major soap EastEnders.\n\nHunt had been working at the Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey, south west of London, and then returned home to discover the horror scene, reported The Sun.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Mr Clifford, who is from Enfield in north London, was likely still armed as he was tracked down overnight and into Wednesday.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon police raided an address in Enfield which is about 27km east of Bushey. Police also visited another address and a cemetery in Enfield.\n\n\"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off,\" a neighbour said.\n\nAt 6.20pm 3.20am, Thursday, AEST), Police said they had arrested a man in a cemetery in Enfield in connection with the triple killing.\n\n\"Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon,\" said Hertfordshire Police.\n\n\"He is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries. No shots were fired by police.\"\n\nPolice said no one else was being sought in connection with the investigation.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said it was \"an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family,\" and asked for privacy so they could \"come to terms with what has happened\".\n\nThe BBC has said that Mr Clifford was in the British Army for a short period in 2022.\n\nSocial media footage reportedly shows a man with a possible crossbow under a sheet walking near Ashlyn Close at the time.\n\nPassers-by appear to be oblivious to what might be under the sheet.\n\nMr Hunt has worked at the public broadcaster for 30 years as a sports reporter.\n\nHis main focus is horse racing but he also done commentary for football games and the equestrian events at the London 2012 Olympic Games.\n\nOriginally a police officer, he moved to BBC radio station 5 Live in 2004.\n\nHeidi Dawson, the controller of BBC Radio 5 Live, said the news was \"utterly devastating\".\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can,\" she said in an email to staff.\n\nMatt Chapman, a racing commentator with commercial network ITV said there were \"no words\" to describe what had happen to Mr Hunt's family.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. {"uri": "8218692678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:27:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:27:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:27:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.thetimes.com/uk/crime/article/bushey-murder-latest-news-kyle-clifford-manhunt-656fp90lk", "title": "Bushey murders latest: Three women killed at home of BBC commentator John Hunt", "body": "Hertfordshire police said they had searched through the night for Kyle Clifford, from the Enfield area. They believe he could be in Hertfordshire or north London and may have a crossbow. Anyone who sees him is asked to call 999 and not approach him.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson confirmed that the victims were aged 25, 28 and 61.\n\nHe said the murders are believed to have been a \"targeted incident\" involving what is \"currently believed\" to be a crossbow but \"other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nSimpson told reporters: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\"\n\nHe said \"extensive\" police resources are deployed in north London and the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used,\" Simpson added.\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nGlyn Nicholas, a 77-year-old neighbour, said one of the women had crashed her car into a wooden telephone pole outside the home last week.\n\nHe said she had told someone the crash occurred because she was upset after the breakdown of a relationship with her boyfriend. The car door was \"caved in\", he added.\n\nNicholas also described them as a \"lovely family\" who had lived there for 10 years.\n\nAlan Vincent, 86, another neighbour, said he saw three ambulances and ten police cars outside a property at 7pm.\n\nAbout 15 minutes later a man arrived in a Mini and parked in the middle of the road.\n\nVincent said: \"He told me that his girlfriend had been injured. He said he had received a phone call from the police. I said he could park in my driveway.\n\n\"Then all three ambulances left together. I didn't see any bodies being taken out.\"\n\nA female resident of Ashlyn Close, who did not want to be named, heard a woman screaming last night before armed police put the street into lockdown.\n\nThe 46-year-old said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nArmed police went from house to house questioning locals, requesting doorbell camera footage and telling people to stay indoors, a neighbour said.\n\nThe neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\nAnother neighbour described how \"lots\" of armed police descended on the street and knocked on their door. \"They told us to keep the door closed. There were about 15 to 20 police cars. There was a helicopter flying around.\" If someone had escaped on foot, the neighbour said, there were three directions they could have taken from the road.\n\nLaurence Brass, a councillor who lives nearby, told the BBC that the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\". He said: \"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire major crime unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nYvette Cooper, the home secretary, described the deaths of the three women as \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated.\n\nShe said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support Hertfordshire police with any information about this case.\"\n\nLouise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards, councillors for the area, said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected. We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"", "source": {"uri": "thetimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thetimes.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": Investigators believe the suspect could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nDet Supt Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. {"uri": "8218589921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:24:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:24:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:23:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13619671/crossbow-suspect-kyle-clifford-allegedly-tied-ex-girlfriend-sister-mother-bushey-home.html", "title": "'Crossbow suspect tied up ex, sister and mother before shooting them'", "body": "A mother and her two daughters were tied up and shot dead with a crossbow after a deadly rampage at their suburban Hertfordshire home.\n\nOne of the victims is believed to be the former partner of the suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London.\n\nPolice launched an urgent manhunt for Clifford after the three women's bodies were found at a home on Ashlyn Close in Bushey last night.\n\nThey have warned the public not to approach the suspected triple killer as he is in possession of a crossbow.\n\nNeighbours of the victims spoke of their shock while a local councillor attempted to calm fears of residents as a police helicopter hovered over the scene.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, is being actively sought by police who have warned the public not to approach him as he may be carrying a weapon\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice have said they have launched a manhunt for Clifford\n\nThe cul-de-sac remained sealed off as forensic teams carried out a search of the property.\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass said: 'I have come down to speak to residents who might be afraid. This is a very middle-class community and there are obviously fears.'\n\nNeighbours told how over a dozen police cars converged on Ashlyn Close on Tuesday evening.\n\n'There were flashing lights everywhere and all the cars blocked off the road. It was quite frightening. No one knew what was going on, but we knew something bad had happened.'\n\nAnother neighbour added: 'It is very scary when something like this happens so close.\n\n'I vaguely knew the family as I think my son went to school with the girls. It is just awful and does not bear thinking about.'\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered'\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: 'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.'\n\nHe said: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women died last night\n\nSeveral police cars can also been seen parked on the road. One resident claimed 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine descended on the scene last night\n\nAn officer stands next to a police a car outside the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the 'truly shocking' deaths.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,' he said.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n'Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.'\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: 'We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n'Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n'Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.'\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: 'We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n'As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n'We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.'\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be {"uri": "8218532261", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:49:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:49:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:49:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.nottinghampost.com/news/uk-world-news/police-say-bushey-triple-murder-9401017", "title": "Police say triple murder suspect 'may have crossbow' and issue warning", "body": "Three women have tragically been discovered dead in a home on a quiet street, prompting a police search for a suspect who may be armed with a crossbow. The emergency services, including Hertfordshire Constabulary and ambulance crews, responded to an alert at a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire just before 7pm.\n\nThey found the three victims, believed to be family members, suffering from severe injuries. Despite efforts, all three women passed away at the location.\n\nLaw enforcement officials are actively seeking 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from Enfield, having conducted searches throughout the night.\n\nClifford could be in the Hertfordshire or North London area. Police have warned the public to exercise caution if they encounter him and to dial 999 immediately, as he might still be carrying a weapon, reports the Mirror.\n\nA police spokesperson later clarified that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". The police are also appealing to anyone who was present in Ashlyn Close from midday yesterday to step forward with any information that could aid their inquiry. BBC footage from above the scene shows a forensic tent set up in the front garden of a house within the cul-de-sac, surrounded by several parked police vehicles.\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary expressed profound shock, stating: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nA neighbour named Riaz said: \"They are a middle-class family. It is tragic and horrifying. There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\n\n\"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\" Another neighbour, who wished to remain anonymous, said: \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nDet Sgt Hall issued a statement, saying: \"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nHe continued, \"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThose with information can report it via an online chat with a Force Communications Room operator or by dialling the non-emergency number 101 and mentioning Op Infauna. {"uri": "8220216695", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:07:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:07:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:06:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/london-crossbow-attack-bbc-journalist-wife-daughter-killed-13791779.html", "title": "London crossbow attack: What happened, who is the suspect that killed BBC journalist's wife, daughters?", "body": "Police said Clifford, found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought. Image Courtesy: @DetectiveCouch/X\n\nA BBC journalist returned home from work to find his wife and two daughters fatally injured in what British police are calling 'a targeted crossbow attack'.\n\nA suspect wanted in connection with the triple killings was found injured on Wednesday afternoon following a manhunt.\n\nThe search for Kyle Clifford, 26, began on Tuesday evening when police received a call regarding the attack in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his wife Carol Hunt, 61, and two daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25. The couple also have another daughter, Amy, who is believed to live in Birmingham.\n\nCarol was found in the house's hallway with a crossbow bolt in her chest, and there was signs of ligatures on the victims' faces and wrists, according to The Guardian sources. It is believed that one of the victims texted her partner to ask them to report the attack.\n\nHunt discovered the deaths early on Tuesday night after getting home from covering the Lingfield Park racecourse south of London, according to the Daily Mail and other media outlets.\n\nDespite the efforts of police and ambulance crews to save them, they were declared dead at the site.\n\nPolice stated that while a crossbow is thought to have been used in the \"targeted incident,\" other weapons might have also been used.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson asserted that the suspect was acquainted with the family and that the attack was not random, as per NPR.\n\nA nearby resident and local council member named Laurence Brass compared the area to \"a typical leafy British suburb\" while sharing his account of the previous evening.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAfter learning of the killings on Tuesday, police had been searching a park close to Clifford's northwest London residence.\n\nThe Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit's Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins had previously stated that the investigation is proceeding \"at pace\" and that the victims' \"premature\" naming \"caused great upset.\"\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she said, as per NPR, adding, \"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\n'Targeted killing'\n\nHertfordshire Police released a statement on Wednesday afternoon stating that Clifford, who they warned may have been carrying a crossbow, was discovered in Enfield, North London, and is undergoing treatment for his wounds.\n\nAlthough they insisted that they had not fired any rounds, the police did not explain how those injuries occurred.\n\n\"A man wanted in connection with a triple murder in Bushey has been traced to a location in North London. Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon (Wednesday, July 10),\" the statement said.\n\nThe manhunt intensified and armed police raided an address at Gordon Hill, Enfield, north London, early in the morning. The Rendlesham Road property is believed to have been connected to Clifford's brother Bradley, who was accused of murder in 2018 and given a life sentence.\n\nLocal schools were also shut down.\n\nAlthough British media had reported that Clifford was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters, Louise Hunt, police did not specify how or whether Clifford was related to the women.\n\nThe breakup deeply affected Louise, who recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside their family home, Daily Mail reported. Carol mentioned her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol didn't go into specifics, but you could tell she was worried,\" a friend was quoted as saying by the British newspaper.\n\nClifford left the British army in 2022 after serving for a brief time, a British Defence Ministry source told CNN. As per the report, he joined the forces in 2019 and served in the Household Cavalry.\n\nCondolences pour in\n\nThe BBC described the women's killings as \"utterly devastating\" and said that it would give Hunt \"all the support we can.\"\n\n\"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can,\" the statement to staff read.\n\nBritish Home Secretary Yvette Cooper expressed her condolences and said on X, \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support Hertfordshire Police with any information about this case.\"\n\nAccording to PA Media, a neighbour of the women said she \"would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nCalls for law change\n\nIn the UK, anyone above 18 is permitted to purchase or possess a crossbow; however, if they are caught carrying one in public without a valid reason, they risk jail time.\n\nThe previous government began an eight-week assessment of the regulations and the prospect of implementing a licensing plan in February.\n\nLaura Sugden, whose partner Shane Gilmer was killed in a similar crossbow attack in 2018, has called for a licensing system for the weapons.\n\nOn the Today programme on BBC Radio Four, she said, \"Three people lost their lives yesterday and if that's not enough to now stop and think that these are dangerous weapons, unbelievable lethal - we need to be looking to do something. Put some legislation in, bring them in line with firearms and try and prevent future deaths.\"\n\nViolence against women in the UK\n\nThe killings sent shockwaves through the country.\n\nAlthough mass killings are uncommon in Britain, the government has designated violence against women as a national issue, as per CNN.\n\nReem Alsalem, the UN special rapporteur on violence against women and girls, stated earlier this year that one in four women will experience domestic violence in their lifetime and that a woman is killed by a man in the UK every three days.\n\n\"Entrenched patriarchy at almost every level of society, combined with a rise in misogyny that permeates the physical and online world, is denying thousands of women and girls across the UK the right to live in safety, free from fear and violence,\" Alsalem said in February.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": women may have crossbow, police fear", "body": "A 26-year-old man being sought over the murders of three women may have a crossbow, police have said.\n\nKyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, is wanted over the deaths of the women who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nHertfordshire Police warned that he may still be in possession of a weapon and that members of the public should dial 999 if they see him.\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently there is no {"uri": "8218647417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:06:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:06:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:01:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13619773/Screams-heard-three-women-murdered-quiet-suburban-cul-sac.html", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "Screams were heard from a house in a quiet cul de sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nMembers of the public have been warned not to approach Kyle Clifford, who may have a crossbow (Hertfordshire Police/PA)\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\n(PA Graphics)\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nPolice at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey (James Manning/PA)\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nResidents described their street as being on 'lockdown\u00b4 following the incident (James Manning/PA)\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a Ambulance crews are also at the scene as officers carry out enquiries.\n\nHertfordshire Police has warned Kyle Clifford may be armed with a crossbow. The public has been urged not to approach him, and to dial 999 immediately.\n\nLIVE: Police hunt Enfield man who may be armed after 3 women killed\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. The BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two of their daughters had died in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nA massive manhunt has been launched for their suspected killer, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters on Wednesday that the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nMr Hunt, a 58-year-old former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last two decades. He was married to Mrs Hunt and had three children, including Hannah and Louise.\n\nWho are the victims?\n\nMrs Hunt and her two daughters Hannah and Louise were found fatally injured at their home just after 7pm on Tuesday. Officers and emergency medical crews, including two air ambulances, were sent to try to save the women, but they all died at the scene.\n\nHannah appeared in her social media profile to be a beauty and skin therapist who managed her own business, Hannah Grace Aesthetics, in Bushey.\n\nAccording to her social media, Louise had started her own dog grooming business called Groom and Glow in 2020.\n\nA friend of Louise paid tribute to her and her family online, MyLondon reported, adding: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news.\n\n\"You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nCondolences from racing world\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the Mr Hunt's employer BBC described the incident as \"utterly devastating\".\n\nThe note added: \"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were also posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in an entry on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nClick below to see the latest London headlines\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nRead more\n\nPolice issue plea to potentially armed triple-murder suspect to 'make contact'. \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\" [Independent]\n\nScreams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac. \"A resident said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\". {"uri": "2024-07-417888711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:30:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:30:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:19:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/news/nation-world/wife-daughters-of-bbc-commentator-killed-search-for-suspect/507-25c2ae5f-532c-43c0-921b-bf49d7ee0633", "title": "Man suspected of killing BBC commentator's wife and 2 daughters has been caught", "body": "The BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nLONDON, UK -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but said they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Louise and Hannah, aged 25 and 28 respectively.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford. Enfield is around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should
