You can check out at any time. More info\n\nPolice have issued a direct plea to a triple murder suspect as a huge manhunt to track him down continues.\n\nKyle Clifford has been urged to 'make contact' with officers after the 'targeted incident' on Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire on Tuesday evening. A manhunt is underway to find the 26-year-old, who is wanted over the deaths of three women - aged 25, 28 and 61 - who were found fatally injured in a house on the cul-de-sac.\n\nClifford may be armed with a crossbow, police believe. Speaking to reporters from Hertfordshire, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said 'extensive police resources' had been deployed to track him down.\n\nREAD NEXT: Fears triple murder suspect has CROSSBOW as police pictured in major UK manhunt update\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\" He repeated warnings to the public not to approach him, but to call 999 if they see him.\n\nTerrified neighbours said they heard screams as the scenes of 'absolute chaos' unfolded on Ashlyn Close last night. One 46-year-old resident, who did not wish to be named, told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\" She said multiple ambulances, helicopters and 'at least 16 police cars' arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help. It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were 'deeply shocked and saddened' by the news of the deaths. A neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the 'truly shocking' deaths. Hertfordshire police and crime commissioner Jonathan Ash-Edwards said: \"My thoughts are with the family and friends of the women who have been shockingly killed in this terrible incident in Bushey.\n\n\"It will no doubt send shockwaves through the local community and across Hertfordshire. I am being kept updated by the police and I urge the public to support the police with any information about the whereabouts of the named suspect.\"\n\nRead more of today's top stories here", {"uri": "8218633498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:52:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/triple-murder-suspect-may-armed-33210388", "title": "Triple murder suspect 'may be armed with crossbow' as cops continue manhunt", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA suspect wanted in connection with the murders of three women may be armed with a crossbow, police have warned. Emergency services rushed to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm on Tuesday, where the victims where found with serious injuries.\n\nTragically, they all died a short time later at the scene. Kyle Clifford from Enfield, north London, is wanted in connection with the incident. Police believe the 26-year-old could be anywhere in Hertfordshire or North London.\n\nCops have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately with a spokesperson for Hertfordshire Police later specifying Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\", reports the Mirror.\n\nWhile anyone who was in Ashlyn Close from lunchtime yesterday should also come forward to help the police with their investigations. The area has been described as a quiet area by shocked locals.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nRob Hall, Detective Superintendent from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nInformation can be reported via an online web chat with an operator in the Force Communications Room. Alternatively, you can phone the non-emergency number 101 and quote Op Infauna. If you have information but would like to remain 100% anonymous, you can contact the independent charity Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or by using their online form.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from Police are \"actively seeking\" Kyle Clifford, 26, who is wanted in connection with the incident which happened in Bushey on Tuesday evening (July 9).\n\nOfficers and paramedics were called to a property in Ashlyn Close just before 7pm and found three women with \"serious injuries\" on arrival, Hertfordshire Police said. \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene,\" the force added.\n\nThey have since been searching for Clifford, who is from the Enfield area, throughout the night. Members of the public have been urged not to approach Clifford if they see him but to call 999 immediately. He might still have a weapon, the force said.\n\nREAD MORE: She had a grudge against her mother-in-law so hired a man to torch her car\n\nREAD MORE: Old school turned into \u00a32m drug den as pair caught with suitcases full of cannabis\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened. evening.\n\nDespite the efforts of emergency services, all three were pronounced dead at the scene after suffering injuries in a suspected crossbow attack.\n\nREAD MORE: BBC journalist's wife and two {"uri": "8218815202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:43:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:43:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:42:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/who-bbc-star-john-hunt-33212288", "title": "Who is BBC star John Hunt whose family were murdered by crossbow killer", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nBBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt reportedly returned home from work on Tuesday evening to discover his two daughters and wife had been brutally attacked. The three women aged 25, 28 and 61 were found seriously injured - and subsequently pronounced dead at the scene, reports the Mirror.\n\nHunt, who is married with three children, is said to have been working for the BBC on Tuesday and may have been the individual to raise the alarm when he returned home at around 7pm, as reported by The Telegraph. The broadcaster's 61-year-old wife Carol has been named locally, with Hertfordshire Police revealing at a press conference Wednesday afternoon the two other victims were her daughters.\n\nHunt, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last 20 years. ITV racing pundit Matt Chapman took to X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday to share his condolences for his co-star.\n\nHe wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nNow a huge manhunt is underway to find Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the triple murder, which took place at a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nCalling on the public for information, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said in a post on X: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n\"I am being kept fully updated. after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nMr Simpson repeated warnings to the public not last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a British police were hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London.\n\nBy Pan Pylas, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, July 10, 2024 | 8:17 a.m.\n\nLONDON -- British police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson {"uri": "8219087862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:43:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:43:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:43:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.rsvplive.ie/news/celebs/who-bbc-star-john-hunt-33214592", "title": "Who is BBC star John Hunt whose family were killed in 'triple crossbow murder'", "body": "BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt reportedly return home to discover his wife and two daughters had been brutally attacked.\n\nThe three women were killed in a suspected crossbow murder. It's alleged Hunt returned home from work to find the three women seriously injured - they were subsequently pronounced dead at the scene, reports The Mirror.\n\nHunt, who is married with three children, is said to have been working for the BBC on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home at around 7pm, as reported by The Telegraph. The broadcaster's 61-year-old wife Carol has been named locally, with Hertfordshire Police revealing at a press conference Wednesday afternoon that the two other victims were her daughters.\n\nHunt, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last 20 years. ITV racing pundit Matt Chapman took to X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday to share his condolences for his co-star.\n\nHe wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\" A search is underway to find Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the deaths, which took place at a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nCalling on the public for information, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said in a post on X: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community. I am being kept fully updated. {"uri": "8219222459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:33:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:33:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:32:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/international/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police/article_7d2a9ed5-1731-5a16-a0db-f08450f106ea.html", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but said they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Louise and Hannah, aged 25 and 28 respectively.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford. Enfield is around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should {"uri": "8219162814", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:43:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:43:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:42:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/world/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police/article_8a83a0ab-67b4-55bc-a01c-0153f89e5e7f.html", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- British police say they have found the man suspected of killing three women with a crossbow near London and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London.\n\nThe BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police were scouring a park in north London on Wednesday, searching for a man they suspect killed three women with a crossbow. The BBC has confirmed that the women were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was wanted in the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\nArmed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park in Enfield, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery. The area has been closed off and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation.\n\nPolice said the three women -- aged 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be {"uri": "8219089425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:44:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:44:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:44:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/who-kyle-clifford-five-facts-33213780", "title": "Five facts about crossbow murder suspect Kyle Clifford as manhunt ramps up", "body": "Kyle Clifford is being hunted by police over the deaths of three women\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, is being hunted by police over the suspected triple murder of a beloved BBC broadcaster's family.\n\nThe victims have now been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nClifford is thought to have used a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach him if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams have said they are \"responding at pace\" to a \"horrific incident\". Police said the three women were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. As part of a note sent to BBC staff, the corporation described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and pledged that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nHere's five things we know about the suspect:\n\nClifford is 'ex-boyfriend' of one of victims\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is believed to be the ex-girlfriend of Kyle Clifford. Louise launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business.\n\nAfter the breakup, Louise had recently smashed her car into a telegraph pole outside her house. Glyn Nicholas, 77, told the Telegraph: \"Louise split up with her boyfriend a few days ago and she crashed her car into a telegraph pole because she was so upset coming home. She's a lovely, caring girl. She runs a dog grooming business in Bushey. Her sister Hannah and mother Carol are lovely as well. It's all so sad. Louise was a sweet, lovely girl. They all were. This is so sad for everyone.\"\n\nLeft army 'two years ago'\n\nThe BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022. The Ministry of Defence confirmed on Wednesday that Kyle Clifford, wanted in connection with the triple murder in Bushey had served briefly in the Armed Forces.\n\nA Whitehall source said: \"He didn't serve very long and he is no longer a serving member of the armed forces. We're not going to speculate which regiment or unit he was in, but look at his age. He didn't serve very long.\"\n\nPublic told not to approach him as he could still have crossbow\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\". The force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident. People in the UK do not need a licence to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse. A spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nHouse raided\n\nArmed police have searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as the manhunt for Clifford continues. Clifford is wanted for murder, following deaths of three women in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nThe house, close to Gordon Hill railway station, was swarmed by officers on Wednesday morning, according to neighbours. Two officers were stood outside the property at 1.30pm, after a cordon was removed. One neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off. It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day. I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\nNo 'perceived threat' to public\n\nArmed officers have been seen in the Enfield area of north London this evening as they comb local allotments and a cemetery for the fugitive. But Enfield Council in north London says it has been advised by police that \"there is no perceived threat\" to the public. In a statement posted on the local authority's X account, the council said: \"You will be aware of the news regarding the suspect Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area, wanted in relation to a triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\n\"We have been advised by the Police that there is no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal. Local schools have been advised that end of day school procedures should continue as per normal. There will be an enhanced police presence in the area and around some schools to provide reassurance to pupils and parents.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson {"uri": "8220711263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "15:13:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T15:13:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T15:10:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/triple-crossbow-murder-suspect-yet-150726087.html", "title": "Triple crossbow murder suspect yet to speak with police and in serious condition", "body": "Triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford is yet to speak with officers and is in a serious condition in hospital following the crossbow deaths of three family members of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nThe 26-year-old was found with injuries in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, on Wednesday following a manhunt which lasted for a number of hours.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC 5 Live commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters, Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were found fatally injured at a house in the quiet cul-de-sac of Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nHertfordshire Police said a crossbow has since been recovered as part of the investigation.\n\nPolice confirmed they had received no earlier reports after exploring whether there had been previous contact with Clifford or the victims.\n\nColleagues and friends of the three victims have paid tribute to the \"lovely family\" since their deaths.\n\nLea Holloway, 60, a childhood friend of Carol Hunt, described her as a \"beautiful person\".\n\nSpeaking outside St James' Church on Thursday after a vigil for Mrs Hunt and her daughters, she said: \"We grew up together and were pregnant at the same time.\n\n\"This is the stuff nightmares are made of.\n\n\"I was there the night she met John (Hunt). It was in a nightclub in Hemel Hempstead. We went out together, went to birthdays and events.\n\n\"It's very difficult. She was the nicest, kindest, sweetest person you could ever meet. A beautiful person.\"\n\nMs Holloway continued: \"They were a lovely family and (the daughters) were lovely girls.\n\n\"They were making their way through life and their lives have been taken too soon. It's the thing of nightmares.\n\n\"I feel for their eldest daughter and John (Hunt). I can't imagine what it would be like.\"\n\nAfter being joined by two other close friends, Dionne Smith, 58, and Abigail Phillips, 58, the trio told reporters: \"We were a four, and now there's only three.\n\n\"It doesn't seem real. We are together in grief.\"\n\nIn a post on Facebook, Hannah Hunt's colleagues at The Anti-Ageing Clinic in Radlett, Hertfordshire, said it was with \"deep regret and sadness\" that they learned of the \"horrific murder on Tuesday night of our skin therapist Hannah\".\n\nThe post continued: \"She was a fantastic therapist and clients loved her.\n\n\"We send our condolences and prayers to her Dad, sister and family.\n\n\"She was very much a part of our team. Please bear with us at this terrible time.\"\n\nProviding an update on the investigation, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said: \"This was an unprecedented attack and we are determined to understand the full circumstances of what happened that evening and the events leading up to it.\n\n\"This investigation, as I'm sure people can imagine, will take time.\n\n\"We are still appealing for anyone with information in relation to the incident on Tuesday evening in Bushey and activity in Enfield yesterday that could assist us to please contact police directly.\"\n\nOn Thursday, further searches took place at a house linked to Clifford's brother, Bradley Clifford, who was jailed for life with a minimum term of 23 years for the murder of moped passenger Soban Khan in 2018.\n\nAccording to the Metropolitan Police, at the time of the murder Bradley Clifford had targeted the moped before crashing into it, and continued to assault Mr Khan after the collision.\n\nOfficers were seen at the address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, north London, in relation to the deaths.\n\nPolice staff wearing gloves and face masks were seen outside the property, which was first searched on Wednesday.\n\nFlowers were left at the scene in Ashlyn Close on Thursday, with notes attached to some bouquets with messages such as \"rest in peace\".\n\nClifford was found injured in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, north London, on Wednesday and was taken to a major trauma centre for treatment.\n\nPolice said no shots had been fired by officers and no arrest had yet been made.\n\nArmed police had earlier been in the area, with an air ambulance nearby.\n\nFootage from Sky News appeared to show Clifford being stretchered out of the cemetery by paramedics and a further clip seemed to show the suspect been wheeled into the Royal London hospital.\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was found, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, from Hertfordshire Police, told reporters the killings were believed to have been \"targeted\".\n\nDuring the hunt for Clifford, who is understood to have left the Army in 2022 after a short stint, the force said they believed he may have been armed with a crossbow and warned people not to approach him.\n\nHe was believed to have been known to the victims.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is crossbow deaths of three women | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford has been found following the crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nClifford, 26, was found in the Enfield area of north London on Wednesday afternoon, Hertfordshire Police said.\n\nHe is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries.\n\nClifford was wanted in connection with the deaths of Carol Hunt, wife of BBC racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters Hannah and Louise in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nThe force said they believe he was known to the victims.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was located, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nDuring the manhunt for the suspect, the force said they believed he may have been armed with a crossbow and warned the public not to approach him.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the broadcaster said it would provide Mr Hunt with \"all the support we can\".\n\nThe note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice said they were looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nBBC racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght said: \"There are no words.\n\n\"Like everyone else I feel numb and sick on John's behalf at such incomprehensible evil.\n\n\"Everyone who knows John knows he is the absolute archetypal family man, so proud of them, so it's impossible to know what he can be going through.\n\n\"But I know I'm speaking for the whole racing community and the whole wider sports media community as well, both of which he's been part of for so long, when I say everyone is sending sympathy, love and support to him. {"uri": "2024-07-417689226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:21:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:21:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:16:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/manhunt-know-deadly-crossbow-attack-161653448.html", "title": "Manhunt: What do we know about deadly crossbow attack?", "body": "This article contains details some readers may find distressing.\n\nHow did the attack unfold?\n\nThree women were killed at about 19:00 on Tuesday evening in an attack which police believe involved a crossbow. Officers think that other weapons may also have been used.\n\nAll three victims are reported to have died at the scene in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nA full-scale manhunt is under way to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is from Enfield, north London, and used to work as a security guard.\n\nArmed policer officers and specialist search teams have been \"responding at pace\", deployed to various locations in north London and the Bushey area of Hertfordshire.\n\nWho were the victims?\n\nThey were: Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC commentator John Hunt, and two of their three daughters - Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nWhat do we know about the suspect?\n\nDetails are still emerging about the suspect but it is believed that Kyle Clifford left the British Army after a short period of service in 2022.\n\nPolice are treating the killings as a \"targeted incident\".\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police appealed directly to the suspect, saying: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nTimeline of events\n\nWhat if the suspect is spotted?\n\nThe police have warned the public not to approach Mr Clifford, who may still be in possession of a crossbow - anyone spotting him is being advised to dial 999 immediately.\n\nThey have also appealed to anyone who was near Ashlyn Close between lunchtime and early evening on Tuesday to get in touch.\n\nOne local councillor, Louise Nicholas, has said there is support available for residents affected by what has happened.\n\nWhat has the public reaction been?\n\nJohn Hunt works for BBC Five Live as a racing commentator.\n\nA spokesperson for the channel said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\"\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nRacing broadcasters have also been offering their condolences.\n\nOne of them, Matt Chapman, posted on X, saying it was \"impossible to comprehend the pain\".\n\n\"Just know we are all here for you, John. We love you pal - racing loves you,\" he says.\n\nCommentator Mike Vince has said on X that his \"heart bleeds\" for Mr Hunt, adding that the incident was \"simply shattering\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said its team was \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic deaths\".\n\n\"Our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time,\" it posted on X.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deaths were \"truly shocking\", adding that she was being kept fully updated about the police investigation.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218310561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:33:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.cornwalllive.com/news/uk-world-news/three-women-murdered-hertfordshire-police-9400336", "title": "Three women murdered as police hunt possibly armed man", "body": "A manhunt has been launched after three women were found dead just outside North London. Officers from Hertfordshire Police were called to a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, shortly before 7pm yesterday (on Tuesday, July 9) where they discovered three women with severe injuries. The trio, believed to be related, tragically died at the scene.\n\nOn Wednesday morning (July 10), the force announced that it had been searching overnight for 26 year old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, who is wanted in connection with the incident. Herts Police have warned the public not to approach Mr Clifford as he may still be armed and could be in either Hertfordshire or North London.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London. Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon,\" reports MyLondon.\n\nDS Hall went on to say: \"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nHe further added, \"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nAnyone with information can report online, talk to an operator in our Force Communications Room via our online web chat or call the non-emergency number 101, quoting Op Infauna. {"uri": "8220354260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "11:26:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T11:26:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T11:26:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13623383/kyle-clifford-crossbow-triple-murder-suspect-manhunt.html", "title": "Manhunt timeline: How search for crossbow murder suspect unfolded", "body": "The switch from quiet, suburban cul-de-sac to frantic crime scene happened almost instantaneously.\n\nNeighbours on Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire, suddenly became aware of screaming at shortly before 7pm on Tuesday. Police, then ambulances, darted to the scene.\n\nThe discovery was grim - three women, all shot dead in their own home in what was believed to be a targeted attack. The weapon - a crossbow.\n\nThe suspect is Kyle Clifford, a 26-year-old ex-military man and security guard, who was also the former boyfriend of one of the victims, Louise Hunt, 25.\n\nMs Hunt, a successful and popular dog groomer, was found slain alongside her mother, Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC radio commentator John Hunt, and the couple's older daughter Hannah, 28.\n\nKyle Clifford, a former soldier and security guard, was apprehended by police after a 24-hour man hunt on suspicion of murder\n\nVictim Louise Hunt, 25, (pictured) is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah, 28, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, and her mother Carol Hunt, 61, were also found dead in the family home\n\nBBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured) is a voice known to millions\n\nBut the sudden appearance of the emergency services, interrupting an otherwise unremarkable evening in this leafy pocket of London's commuter belt, pricked the memories of neighbours.\n\nWas there any connection to Louise's recent break-up, in which she was apparently so distressed that she crashed her car into a telephone pole at the edge of her driveway?\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, recalled the dog groomer, who ran her business from the home, was 'very upset' about splitting with Clifford.\n\n'A friend of Louise's told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash,' he said.\n\n'Carol was a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'They were all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things.\n\n'Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\nLouise Hunt, 25, (pictured) was the ex-girlfriend of suspect Kyle Clifford and was one of the three women found dead in the family home\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, and her mother Carol Hunt, 61, were also found dead in the family home\n\nFloral tributes near to the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters, Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were killed\n\nPolice officers at the scene in Ashlyn Close, where the three victims were killed in an attack allegedly involving a crossbow\n\nA message left for the victims read: 'I wish none of this was real'\n\nA message attached to floral tributes left for Carol Hunt and two daughters Hannah and Louise, who were slain in their family home\n\n'A very close-knit family and they used to love the street.'\n\nA friend added: '(Mum Carol) said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nThe manhunt for Clifford began in earnest, and the whole street suddenly became aware that something terrible had happened.\n\n'Within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos,' one neighbour said.\n\n'We had armed police running down, screaming, \"Stay in your house\" ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.'\n\nIt is understood the police missed their suspect by mere minutes.\n\nDoorbell footage showed a man matching Clifford's description walking with purpose away from the Hunts' home at 6.50pm.\n\nUnder his arm, a large, bulky item secreted beneath a white sheet.\n\nThe man then got into a car and fled the scene.\n\nDoorbell footage shows a man believed to be Kyle Clifford walking away from a house containing the dead bodies of three women\n\nPolice cordoned off Ashlyn Close, home of the Hunt family in Bushey, Hertforshire, after being called to the scene on Tuesday evening\n\nPolice believed the suspect used a crossbow to attack the three victims\n\nMANHUNT TIMELINE\n\n6.50pm TUESDAY : Suspect is seen walking away from home where BBC star's wife and two daughters found dead\n\n7pm: Police called to Ashlyn Close after neighbour reported hearing screams. Three women found seriously injured and later died.\n\n9am WEDNESDAY: Police release appeal naming Kyle Clifford as their main suspect. At the same time armed police raid a property in Rendlesham Road, Enfield\n\n12.30pm: Police confirm at a press conference crossbow attack was 'targeted'\n\n1pm - Huge manhunt across Bushey and Enfield - suspect's car found, primary schools put into lockdown\n\n4.30pm - Armed police and paramedics seen running into Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield.\n\n5pm - Kyle Clifford is detained by police and taken to a major trauma hospital after 'shooting himself'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe police's arrival, so soon after the massacre, was not triggered by neighbours' concerns, however.\n\nIndeed it is believed the police were called to the property by one of the brave victims, who somehow managed to alert emergency services while her relatives perished - and moments before she also died from her injuries.\n\nPolice initially kept a lid on the tragedy.\n\nBut by around 9am the following day, they asked for the public's help.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, detectives named former soldier Clifford as their prime suspect.\n\nPassengers arriving at London's Victoria railway station during the morning rush hour were funneled through exit barriers, allowing police officers to scan the crowd, looking for Clifford.\n\nDetectives reasoned the suspect did not have much time to get too far before the police turned up, so focussed much of their attention on Hertfordshire and North London, where Clifford was from.\n\nAt 12.30pm, police confirmed the identity of the suspects, with Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson appealing directly to the triple murder suspect to hand himself in.\n\n'Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact,' he said.'\n\nAnd he confirmed the attack was believed to have been 'targeted'.\n\nHe said there were 'extensive police resources deployed to various locations', with armed officers and specialist search teams involved.\n\nThis had included storming Clifford's family home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, around 14 miles to the east of Bushey, shortly before the police appeal that morning.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police appealed for the triple murder suspect to hand himself in\n\nPolice confirmed the names of the victims, and urged the public not to approach the suspect\n\nAnd then a development. Clifford's abandoned vehicle was discovered nearby.\n\nSchools locally were put into lockdown as police from Hertfordshire and the Met stormed the area, intensifying the search for Clifford.\n\nOne mother said: 'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into.\n\n'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\nThe net closed in on their suspect, and the hunt moved to nearby Lavender Hill cemetery.\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, as the search for Kyle Clifford intensified\n\nArmed police search the area in Enfield, north London, not far from Clifford's family home\n\nPolice guard the scene where fugitive Kyle Clifford was found, Lavender Hill Cemetry, with apparent self-inflicted wounds\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local who filmed the commotion, said: 'I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\n\n'I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.'\n\nCamera crews also picked up the moment emergency services flocked to the site.\n\nPolice and two accompanying medics could be seen running along a back lane before darting left through a clearing and into the cemetery.\n\nArmed police kept a vigil at the gap, keeping members of the public and journalists away from the site.\n\nShortly after, broadcasters captured the suspect being taken away on a stretcher, flanked by police and medics, having apparently shooting himself.\n\nHe was placed into an ambulance.\n\nPolice were thought to have spent around two hours inside the cemetery before detaining the suspect. Officers said no shots were fired.\n\nClifford was taken by road ambulance to the Royal London hospital to be treated for his injuries.\n\nThe manhunt was over. {"uri": "2024-07-417668412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:02:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:02:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/world-news/uk-police-are-searching-for-a-man-with-a-crossbow-after-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-killed-9199638", "title": "UK police are searching for a man with a crossbow after family of BBC radio commentator killed", "body": "British police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nPan Pylas, The Associated {"uri": "2024-07-417746128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:20:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:20:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:13:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2024/07/10/uk-police-are-searching-for-a-man-with-a-crossbow-after-bbc-radio-commentators-family-is-killed/74354148007/", "title": "UK police are searching for a man with a crossbow after BBC radio commentator's family is killed", "body": "London - British police were scouring a park in north London on Wednesday, searching for a man whom they suspect killed three women in one of the city's residential suburbs. The BBC has confirmed that the women were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was wanted in the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\nArmed police officers and ambulance staff were seen at a park in Enfield and a nearby cemetery. The area has been closed off and an air ambulance was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation.\n\nPolice said the three women - ages 25, 28 and 61 - were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", {"uri": "8218613950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:39:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:39:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:39:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/10/screams-heard-as-three-women-murdered-in-quiet-suburban-cul-de-sac/", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "Screams were heard from a house in a quiet cul de sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal
