{"uri": "8218610794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:37:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:37:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:37:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/screams-heard-as-three-women-murdered-in-quiet-suburban-cul-de-sac/a606737423.html", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "A resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no {"uri": "8219745039", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:20:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:20:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:19:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.sg/suspect-kyle-clifford-detained-crossbow-attack-that-killed-wife-daughters-bbc-commentator-had-75224", "title": "Suspect Kyle Clifford Detained in Crossbow Attack That Killed Wife and Daughters of BBC Commentator, Had Recently Broke-up with One of the Victim", "body": "A 26-year-old man was detained by police on Wednesday after a brief manhunt following the killing of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator. The attack, suspected to be targeted, involved a crossbow.\n\nKyle Clifford, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of three women in Bushey, a town north of London. The victims were Carol Hunt, 61, wife of BBC and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nPolice found Clifford in Enfield. He was known to the victims, and no other suspects are being sought. Clifford is receiving medical treatment for injuries. Police previously reported that officers were called to a house in Bushey where the women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson described the incident as horrific, involving a crossbow, and possibly other weapons. Reports suggest Clifford had a recent breakup with Louise Hunt, the youngest daughter. The breakup had a significant impact on Louise, who recently crashed her car outside their family home.\n\nCarol Hunt had confided in friends about her daughter's tumultuous breakup. A friend mentioned that Carol was worried about her daughter but didn't provide specifics. According to the UK's Daily Mail, the breakup was messy and deeply affected Louise.\n\nHertfordshire Police found Clifford after an extensive search in North London. The suspect is now receiving medical treatment for his injuries. UK's Interior Minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking,\" expressing her condolences to the family and the community.\n\nBBC Radio Five Live described the incident as \"utterly devastating,\" with colleagues offering tearful condolences on air. Sky Sports Racing also expressed their sadness and support for John Hunt and his family.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public was urged not to approach Clifford. The police and emergency services were seen in Enfield, where Clifford was eventually found. The investigation is ongoing, and more details are expected to emerge.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the victims were Carol Hunt and her daughters, Louise and Hannah. {"uri": "8220125605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "09:10:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T09:10:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T09:10:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.garoweonline.com/en/news/world/kyle-clifford-what-we-know-about-suspect-and-victims-of-bushey-triple-murder", "title": "Kyle Clifford: What we know about suspect and victims of Bushey triple murder", "body": "Kyle Clifford: What we know about suspect and victims of Bushey triple murder\n\nA manhunt that was underway after three women were found dead in a house in Hertfordshire has ended, with the suspect being found by police.\n\nThroughout the day yesterday, detectives had been looking for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford after the victims were discovered by police and paramedics in Bushey on Tuesday night.\n\nThey were named as Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of Sky Sports and BBC racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nHere is everything we know about Clifford and the victims, and how the events unfolded.\n\nJust after 8.30 am on Wednesday, Hertfordshire Constabulary published Kyle Clifford's name, age, and photograph.\n\nHe was on the run after the incident and police had been searching the Hertfordshire and north London areas.\n\nSky News understands he used to work as a private security guard.\n\nIt is believed he left the Army after a short period of service in 2022.\n\nA woman who grew up with him in Enfield said he \"always seemed pretty normal\" and a \"nice guy\".\n\n\"We would always be at the same parties together and hanging around in Enfield. He never seemed odd or aggressive,\" she said.\n\nPolice appealed for the public's help to find him, but warned: \"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThe suspect's brother a convicted murderer\n\nClifford's older brother Bradley Clifford, 30, is serving a life sentence for murdering a teenager in 2017.\n\nBradley Clifford mowed down 19-year-old Jahshua Francis, who was riding a moped, and his pillion passenger Sobhan Khan, 18, after his \"prized\" red Mustang was damaged.\n\nHe drunkenly chased their scooter at nearly double the speed limit on the wrong side of the road after a bottle was thrown at his sports car.\n\nMr Khan was flung in the air and Bradley Clifford continued the attack as he lay on the street, punching him hard nine times, the Old Bailey heard.\n\nBradley Clifford was sentenced at the Old Bailey six years ago and was handed a life sentence with a minimum term of 23 years for murder and seven years for the attack on Mr Francis, to run concurrently.\n\nHow he was found\n\nClifford was found in a cemetery in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield around 6pm on Wednesday evening - 24 hours after the incident in Bushey.\n\nPolice said he was injured, but added that no shots were fired by officers.\n\nSky News pictures showed Clifford being stretchered out of Lavender Hill Cemetery, which had seen a significant police presence in the afternoon, including armed officers.\n\nClifford received medical treatment in the cemetery, which is close to his home.\n\nHe was then taken by ambulance to the Royal London Hospital in Whitechapel.\n\nWhat happened in Bushey?\n\nPolice were called to a detached house in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nWhen they arrived alongside ambulance staff they found three women with \"serious injuries\".\n\nAccording to Hertfordshire Constabulary: \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\"\n\nVictims were targeted\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, 61, who was the wife of racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, it was revealed on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThey were still alive when emergency services arrived.\n\nMr Hunt works for both the BBC and Sky Sports Racing.\n\nSky Sports Racing said in a statement on Wednesday: \"Everyone at Sky Sports Racing is deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in Hertfordshire and our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time.\"\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said at a news conference that police believe it was a \"targeted incident\".\n\nPolicing commentator Graham Wettone says this means it is very likely the victims and suspect were well known to each other.\n\nDerek Turner, a resident of the same street, said the arrival of around 10 police cars and ambulance crews was \"like an explosion in the street\".\n\nHe told Sky News officers were dressed in \"black uniforms with sort of semi-automatic guns walking around\", causing him to mistake the callout for a terrorist incident.\n\nThe road was cordoned off, with a blue tent erected outside the front door of the property.\n\nAt the news conference in Hatfield on Wednesday lunchtime, Chief Supt Simpson confirmed police believe a crossbow was used in the attack, but \"other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nThe Crossbow Act 1987 allows anyone over the age of 18 to buy one - with the only major restriction being it cannot be used on animals.\n\nEarlier this year, the Home Office launched a call for evidence to see if further legislation is needed after their use in several murders in the UK.\n\nSchool pupils kept inside\n\nDuring the news conference in Hatfield, Chief Supt Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" had been deployed in both Hertfordshire and north London.\n\nThey include armed officers and specialist search teams, he added.\n\nPupils at St Michael's Primary School in Enfield were also being kept inside as a precaution.\n\nThe school's headteacher told Sky News the police had conducted a reassurance visit and told them to \"continue as normal as possible\".", "source": {"uri": "garoweonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Garowe You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA man wanted in connection with the triple murder of three women has been found after a huge manhunt. Kyle Clifford, 26, was the main suspect in the deaths of Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, who died on Tuesday night, July 9.\n\nCarol was the wife of BBC racing commentator John Hunt and their daughters were Hannah and Louise. The three women are thought to have been found with fatal injuries by Mr Hunt after he returned home from work last night in Bushey, Hertfordshire, reports MirrorOnline.\n\nDespite the efforts of emergency services, the women died at the scene. Their deaths sparked a manhunt for Clifford, who police said was armed with a number of weapons including a crossbow.\n\nREAD MORE: Emirates Airlines worker held in Dubai is allowed home after diplomatic pressure\n\nGet breaking news on BirminghamLive WhatsApp, click the link to join\n\nClifford was located to an area in north London today. He was found by officers this afternoon, July 10, in the Enfield area after an extensive search took place.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Clifford was found with injuries and has received medical treatment. Armed police were pictured at a cemetery as part of the search but no shots were fired, the police force said. A police spokesperson said it's believed Clifford was known to the victims.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened. This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\n\"The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss. Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. {"uri": "8218885204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:26:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:26:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:26:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.gloucestershirelive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/crossbow-death-victims-bbc-stars-9401830", "title": "Crossbow-death victims are BBC star's wife and daughters", "body": "A manhunt is under way for the chief suspect in the \"horrific\" killings of the wife and daughters of a BBC sports commentator. Kyle Clifford is being hunted by following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThe victims have now been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25. They are the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live horse racing commentator John Hunt. It is understood Mr Hunt been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home.\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder,\" reports The Mirror.\n\nREAD MORE\n\nTeacher sent sexual messages to undercover cop posing as 14-year-old girl\n\nA40 closed after air ambulance lands at scene of crash\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nA neighbour said screams were heard from a house in the quiet cul-de-sac where the women died. The 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos. We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house' ... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Clifford is from the Enfield area and police have been searching for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nArmed police have searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as the manhunt continues. The house, close to Gordon Hill railway station, was swarmed by officers on Wednesday morning, according to neighbours. Two officers were stood outside the property at 1.30pm, after a cordon was removed.\n\nOne neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off. It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day. I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\"\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nTV racing commentator Matt Chapman tweeted: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon : \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nLouise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, the website reported.\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"", "source": {"uri": "gloucestershirelive.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gloucestershire Live"}, "authors": [{"uri": "oliver_astley@gloucestershirelive.co.uk", The BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt -- his wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah and Louise.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford. Enfield is around 52 kilometres to the east from the site of the killing.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\nShe also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which potentially involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police were hunting Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house just northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which potentially involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the {"uri": "8219371630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "21:03:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T21:03:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:58:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/british-police-launch-manhunt-suspect-153527016.html", "title": "British crossbow killings: Police arrest suspect in triple murder of BBC host's family", "body": "July 10 (UPI) -- The manhunt is over in Britain for the alleged suspect in the triple murders Tuesday of the wife and two daughters of a prominent BBC racing broadcaster.\n\nBritish authorities launched a manhunt for the 26-year-old suspect, Kyle Clifford, in connection with the deaths of Carol Hunt and her two daughters. Hunt was killed with a crossbow, police said.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" local police official Justine Jenkins said Wednesday.\n\nClifford was found at Lavender Hill Cemetery in north London some 16 miles from the crime scene and was reportedly getting medical treatment for injuries. Aerial footage showed a man taken from the cemetery in a stretcher.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC racing broadcaster John Hunt, was found dead in the hallway with a crossbow bolt in her chest at their north London home in Hertfordshire, along with their two daughters, Hannah, aged 28 and Louise, age 25.\n\nIt was first believed Clifford was dangerous and in possession of a crossbow, later confirmed Wednesday by Hertfordshire Police.\n\nBut no shots were fired during Clifford's eventual apprehension by police and no other arrests were made.\n\nSources told British media that it was thought that Clifford spent about a year in the British Army.\n\nThe attack also was believed to have been a targeted attack, police said, but authorities have yet to disclose the relationship Clifford had with the family.\n\nPolice say they were called to the property before 7 p.m. local time Tuesday when the three victims were found. One victim reportedly text-messaged somebody, urging them to call police.\n\nPolice said the killings were being treated as murders and that \"other weapons\" may also have been used in addition to the crossbow.\n\nSchools in Enfield were put in lockdown during the hunt for Clifford.\n\nIn Britain, crossbows do not require a license or registration to own, but it is illegal to carry a crossbow in public without reasonable cause.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local town councilor, called the killing the \"worst thing to ever happen\" in the Hertfordshire neighborhood of Bushey, saying that residents there were \"shellshocked\" by the news.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb. serious injuries.\n\nIt's been reported that John, 58, a BBC 5 Live racing commentator, may have raised the alarm after returning home from work.\n\nDespite the best efforts of the medics, 61-year-old The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nMORE TOP STORIES: BMW "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/crime/suspect-in-killing-of-bbc-commentators-family-found-c-15312806", "title": "Suspect in killing of BBC commentator's family found", "body": "Police in the United Kingdom say they have found a man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries.\n\nPolice did not say how those injuries happened but said they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of John Hunt - his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Louise and Hannah, aged 25 and 28 respectively.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford.\n\nEnfield is about 52km to the east from the site of the killing.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins said.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\nShe also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset\".\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted pn Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London.\n\nPolice and ambulance crews tried to save them but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio station.\n\nHis voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early on Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can\".\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but UK media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nThe BBC reported that Clifford left the army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nPeople in the UK do not need a licence to own a crossbow but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA representative for Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said she will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": "perthnow.com.au", {"uri": "8218646381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:00:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.mylondon.news/news/north-london-news/screams-heard-during-bushey-murder-29514452", "title": "Screams heard as mum and 2 daughters 'murdered' at home", "body": "Screams were heard from a house in a quiet cul-de-sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire, near the North London border, said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow. The 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nLIVE: Police hunt Enfield man who may be armed after 3 women killed\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\n'Completely unaware of the trauma'\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help. It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\"\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Deeply shocked and saddened'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods'\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\"\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\"\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\"\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\"\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "mylondon.news", "dataType": Police have urged anyone who sees him to call 999 immediately.\n\nKyle Clifford was a trooper - the equivalent to a private - in the Queen's Dragoon Guards.\n\nHe is believed to have left the army to pursue a career in the Household Cavalry Regiment after passing out.\n\nClifford is from Enfield, North London and is 26 years old.\n\nThe suspected murderer's former boss said: \"Clifford joined the Army in 2019 and I was his Troop Commander from Basic Training.\n\n\"When he joined the Army he was immature for his age and had a bit of a chip on his shoulder.\n\n\"He struggled to grasp basic military concepts but managed to reach the standard to pass out from training.\n\n\"After passing out he joined the Household Cavalry Regiment but I'm unsure how his career developed from there.\n\n\"I hear he was working in private security so would indicate that he is no longer in the military.\"\n\nClifford allegedly murdered BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt's wife Carol, and daughters Hannah and Louise.\n\nThe three women - aged 25, 28, and 61 - were found dead at their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire on July 9, 2024.\n\nThey were found with serious injuries at around 7pm in what police have called a targeted attack.\n\nThe trio tragically died at the scene despite paramedics' best efforts.\n\nA neighbour told the Sun they heard screaming and that \"within 15 minutes it was absolute chaos\".\n\nThe neighbour added: \"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nClifford is after the wife and two daughters of Sky and BBC racing commentator John Hunt were killed in a crossbow attack.\n\nHunt's wife Carol and two of their daughters died at their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening.\n\nPolice have said they were murdered in a \"targeted incident\" as they urged the suspect, 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, to turn himself in.\n\n\"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nMr Simpson said the \"horrific incident\" is believed to have involved a crossbow \"but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nEmergency crews were sent to a property in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, just before 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nThey found the three women - aged 25, 28, and 61 - with serious injuries and they died a short time later at the scene.\n\nHertfordshire Police said it was investigating the triple murder and \"actively seeking\" Clifford, who is from Enfield, north London.\n\nThe public has been urged not to approach him and to report any sightings to the police immediately.\n\nIt is understood he used to work as a private security guard.\n\nSky Sports Racing has issued the {"uri": "2024-07-417875242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:11:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:11:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:06:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/suspect-of-killing-bbc-radio-commentator-family-found-uk-police-9445737/", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found: British police | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nBritish police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nFootage from Sky News showed the suspect being carried on a stretcher out of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, which is close to his home and around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killings. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff had massed around the cemetery through the day.\n\nThe public had been urged not to approach Clifford, who the BBC reported had been in the British Army for a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the Police investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-418481625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:18:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:18:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:12:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/644155/World/Europe/Crossbow-killings-suspect-found-after-attack-on-sport-commentators-wife-and-daughters", "title": "Crossbow killings suspect found after attack on sport commentator's wife and daughters", "body": "LONDON -- A suspect wanted in connection with the triple killings of the wife and two daughters of a BBC sport commentator was found by British police Wednesday following a manhunt.\n\nThe search for Kyle Clifford, 26, began on Tuesday evening when police were called to a house in Bushey, Hertfordshire, where they found three seriously injured women.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, wife of BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, and their daughters, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, later died from their wounds, according to statements Wednesday from police and Britain's public broadcaster.\n\nA crossbow is believed to have been used in the \"targeted incident,\" police said, adding that other weapons may also have been used.\n\nClifford, who police warned may have been armed with a crossbow, was found in Enfield, North London on Wednesday afternoon and is receiving treatment for injuries, Hertfordshire Police said in a statement.\n\n\"A man wanted in connection with a triple murder in Bushey has been traced to a location in North London. Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon (Wednesday, July 10),\" the statement said.\n\n\"At this stage, we believe the suspect was known to the victims.\"\n\nClifford left the British army in 2022 after a short period of service, a source in the British defense ministry told CNN. He joined the forces in 2019 and served in the Household Cavalry, his former military boss told CNN.\n\nThe killings sent shock waves through Britain, where mass murders are rare but violence against women has been labeled a national threat by the government.\n\nA woman is killed by a man every three days in the United Kingdom and one in four women will experience domestic violence in her lifetime, the United Nations' special rapporteur on violence against women and girls, Reem Alsalem, said earlier this year.\n\n\"Entrenched patriarchy at almost every level of society, combined with a rise in misogyny that permeates the physical and online world, is denying thousands of women and girls across the UK the right to live in safety, free from fear and violence,\" Alsalem said in February.\n\nThe BBC described the women's killings as \"utterly devastating\" in a statement to staff. The broadcaster said it would give Hunt \"all the support we can\" as part of a note sent to BBC Radio 5 Live staff.\n\n\"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating,\" it said. \"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nBritish Home Secretary Yvette Cooper expressed her condolences following the killings.\n\n\"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community,\" Cooper wrote on X Wednesday.\n\n\"I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support Hertfordshire Police with any information about this case.\"\n\nA neighbor of the women said she \"would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" according to PA Media.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking,\" she added.\n\nIn Britain, it is legal for a person to buy or own a crossbow if they are over 18, though anyone who carries one in public without a reasonable excuse can face imprisonment. No shots were fired by police.\"\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, were found seriously injured at a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, just before 19:00 BST on Tuesday, and all died at the scene.\n\nDet Insp Justine Jenkins, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\"\n\nMr Clifford left the British Army after a short period of service in 2022, the BBC understands.\n\nDet Insp Jenkins said: \"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us.\n\n\"We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will, of course, be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them.\"\n\nEarlier, local councillor Louise Nicolas wrote, in a post on Facebook, that she was \"deeply saddened to learn this morning of the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident\".\n\n\"Should anyone wish to speak with us or require any support please do not hesitate to get in touch,\" said Ms Nicolas, a Liberal Democrat who represents the North Bushey ward on Hertsmere Borough Council.\n\n\"It goes without saying that this is a live investigation, so speculation as to the {"uri": "8219224987", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:34:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:34:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:34:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/uk-crossbow-killings-bbc-presenter-1.7259561", "title": "British police track down suspect in crossbow killings of BBC presenter's wife, daughters | CBC News", "body": "British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of using a crossbow to kill the wife and two daughters of a BBC radio commentator near London, and that the suspect is receiving medical treatment for his injuries.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford had been found in the Enfield area of north London.\n\nThe BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio commentator John Hunt.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from Enfield, around 52 kilometres east of the site of the killing.\n\nArmed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery.\n\nThe area has been closed off, and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene.\n\nPolice have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation. Police said the three women -- aged 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening.\n\nPolice and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel.\n\nHis voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nThe BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said, \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a licence to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-417365234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:39:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:39:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:34:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/screams-heard-three-women-murdered-113447808.html", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac\n\nPA Reporters\n\n10 July 2024 at 1:34 pm\n\nScreams were heard from a house in a quiet cul de sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, deaths", "body": "A triple murder suspect has been detained by police following the \"utterly devastating\" crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters Hannah and Louise in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice had said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, was believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe hunt for Clifford appeared to focus on a cemetery in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nEmergency services, including armed police, could be seen in the area in footage posted on social media, with Hertfordshire Police saying they were unable to confirm whether they had narrowed their search for the triple murder suspect to the area.\n\nArmed police also searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe was wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show the suspect wearing black and carrying a large item under his right arm as he walked near the scene.\n\nHe is then seen to place the item into a black car, getting in the vehicle and pausing for a moment before driving away.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the broadcaster said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. The three women were found in the early evening on July 9 after police and ambulance vehicles were called to to the home before 7pm.\n\nREAD MORE BBC commentator John Hunt's wife and daughters victims of Bushey triple murder\n\nThe trio had suffered serious injuries but were alive when discovered, however all died a short time later.\n\nThe man at the centre of the major manhunt, Mr Clifford, was wanted by police who had searched for him throughout the night.\n\nOn Wednesday evening (July 10), emergency services were then seen rushing towards a cemetery in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London.\n\nHertfordshire Police said the suspect was later found in the Enfield area on Wednesday afternoon (July 10) and is receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries. {"uri": "8219272178", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:21:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:21:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:17:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police/article_2343b935-7b8a-5083-b3e1-5b1f1aef02db.html", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were the family of John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Louise and Hannah, aged 25 and 28 respectively.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway in Enfield, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killings, the public were urged not to approach Clifford. The BBC had reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri":
