He was then taken by ambulance to the Royal London Hospital in Whitechapel.\n\nThe victims killed in the \"targeted\" attack were Carol Hunt - the wife of racing commentator John Hunt - and their two daughters Hannah and Louise.\n\nThe killings involved the use of a crossbow and possibly other weapons, Hertfordshire Police said.\n\nThe women - aged 25, 28 and 61 - were found with serious injuries and they died a short time later at the scene.\n\nAt this stage, police believe the suspect was known to the victims.\n\nMr Hunt is a Sky Sports Racing presenter and BBC 5 Live commentator.\n\nIn a statement, Sky Sports Racing said: \"Everyone at Sky Sports Racing is deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in Hertfordshire and our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time.\"\n\nA note sent to BBC 5 Live staff described the news as \"utterly devastating\". We treated a man at the scene and took him to a major trauma centre.\"\n\nPolice said earlier today that \"extensive police resources\" had been deployed in both Hertfordshire and north London as part of the manhunt. {"uri": "8220292041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:53:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:53:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:53:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.newstalk.com/news/mother-and-daughters-tied-up-by-ex-boyfriend-in-uk-crossbow-attack-1743973", "title": "Mother and daughters 'tied up' by ex-boyfriend in UK crossbow attack | Newstalk", "body": "A mother and two daughters murdered in an apparent crossbow attack at their home in England are believed to have been tied up before they were killed.\n\nCarol Hunt (61) and her daughters Louise (25) and Hannah (28) were discovered at their home in Hertfordshire on Tuesday night.\n\nThey are the wife and daughters of BBC racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nThe suspect is 26-year-old Kyle Clifford - the ex-boyfriend of Louise Hunt.\n\nPolice were called to the house just before 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nAccording to Hertfordshire Constabulary: \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\"\n\nThroughout Wednesday, police carried out a major manhunt for Kyle Clifford, who was found in a nearby cemetery at around 6pm.\n\nPolice said he was injured but added that no shots were fired by officers.\n\nLondon-based journalist Vincent McAvinney told Newstalk Breakfast Kyle Clifford was known to the family.\n\n\"What we understand happened was that these three [people] were found at their home in Hertfordshire, which is north of London, on Tuesday evening,\" he said.\n\n\"They had been shot by a crossbow, allegedly by Louise Hunt's ex-boyfriend Kyle Clifford.\n\n\"There are signs that they had been tied up; ligature marks have been found on them.\n\n\"The emergency services swung into action... but sadly all three appear to have died at their home\".\n\nMr McAvinney said a \"huge manhunt\" was launched to find Kyle Clifford after the attack.\n\n\"He had spent some time in the army, we understand, and he was said to be armed and dangerous,\" he said.\n\n\"Yesterday afternoon he was discovered in a graveyard in Enfield - east of Hertfordshire - when police went in to search for him.\n\n\"He was stretchered away injured - not injured by the police - supposedly having injured himself at some point\".\n\nMr McAvinney said Mr Hunt is \"a very familiar voice\" on the BBC for the last 20 years.\n\n\"You heard in the voices last night of fellow BBC 5 Live presenters, who had to go on-air to cover the England match, the shock of it all,\" he said.\n\n\"They spoke about it right at the top of their broadcast\".\n\nMr McAvinney said changes to legislation in Britain will likely be forthcoming.\n\n\"It is not illegal in the UK to buy, sell, hire or possess a crossbow if you are over 18 years of age,\" he said.\n\n\"There's questions as to why you don't even need a licence to own one as is required with a gun.\n\n\"I think that law will likely now need to be re-examined\".\n\nMr McAvinney added that Kyle Clifford is currently being treated in hospital and has yet to be charged.\n\nMr Clifford's older brother Bradley Clifford (30) is "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13620483/Huge-manhunt-armed-triple-murder-suspect-devastating-deaths.html", "title": "Huge manhunt for armed triple murder suspect after 'devastating\u00b4...", "body": "A huge manhunt for a potentially armed triple murder suspect is under way following the \"utterly devastating\" crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters Hannah and Louise in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show the suspect wearing black and carrying a large item under his right arm as he walked near the scene.\n\nHe is then seen to place the item into a black car, getting in the vehicle and pausing for a moment before driving away.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nPolice at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire (James Manning/PA)\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\n(PA Graphics)\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the broadcaster said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. {"uri": "8218793055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:30:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:30:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:29:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/screams-heard-as-three-women-murdered-in-quiet-suburban-cul-de-sac-1648196.html", "title": "Screams heard as three women murdered in quiet suburban cul-de-sac near London | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Screams were heard from a house in a quiet cul-de-sac where three women died before \"absolute chaos\" broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, near London in England, said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \"absolutely traumatic\".\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford (26) from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nBritish home secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \"This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\"\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe said: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\" he said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws in the UK around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill Britain's late Queen Elizabeth.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8218791354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:28:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:28:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:28:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/10/world/europe/crossbow-attack-uk-manhunt.html", "title": "U.K. Police Searching for Man Suspected of Killing 3 Women With Crossbow", "body": "The authorities in England were hunting on Wednesday for a man who was suspected of killing three women the previous night with a crossbow and possibly other weapons in a small, leafy town east of London, according to Hertfordshire Police.\n\nThe police said they arrived at the scene just before 7 p.m. local time on Tuesday and found three women with serious injuries. The victims, aged 25, 28 and 61, died shortly afterward at the scene.\n\nThe BBC reported that the victims were the wife and two daughters of one of its horse-racing commentators. \"As we've just reported, the three women killed in a crossbow attack in Bushey, near Watford, are Carol Hunt, the wife of the BBC commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters,\" the broadcaster wrote.\n\nThe police were searching for Kyle Clifford, 26, they said, warning people that \"he may be in possession of a crossbow, do not approach.\" It was not immediately clear on Wednesday what the relation was between Mr. Clifford and the three women.\n\nThe police said Mr. Clifford could be in Bushey, the town where the crime happened, or in nearby North London. They had deployed armed officers and specialized search teams across both areas.\n\n\"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police said during a news conference, adding that the police believed the murders were a \"targeted incident.\"\n\nMr. Simpson said that the man had probably used a crossbow in the killings, but that other weapons might also have been used.\n\nMr. Simpson also addressed Mr. Clifford directly during the news conference: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nFor the residents of the quiet corner of England, the killings came as a big shock. A local councilman, Laurence Brass, told the BBC that it was a traumatizing event. \"The most dramatic thing that has ever happened here is a bit of illegal fly-tipping,\" he said. \"And suddenly we {"uri": "2024-07-417990793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "23:23:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T23:23:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T23:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police/article_a6f5dfdb-2168-5c70-af10-4cdb430a5a42.html", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "British police say they have found the man suspected of killing three women with a crossbow near London and that he's receiving medical treatment for his injuries\n\nLONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing three women, the wife and daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator, near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nFootage from Sky News showed the suspect being carried on a stretcher out of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, which is close to his home and around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killings. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff had massed around the cemetery through the day.\n\nThe public had been urged not to approach Clifford, who the BBC reported had been in the British Army for a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. Officials believe the victims were the wife and two daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nOfficials believe the weapon used in the attack was a crossbow, but other weapons may have been involved.\n\nLaw enforcement responded to the scene at around 7 p.m. and located three seriously injured victims.\n\nPolice are currently concentrating search efforts on north London and the Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nIf anyone sees Clifford, officials are asking them to call 999. They are also encouraged not to approach Clifford since \"he may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\n\"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police,\" Hertfordshire Police Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said at a press conference on Wednesday.\n\nOfficials are also launching an investigation into the incident.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened,\" Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said in a statement.\n\nOliver Dowden, Parliament Member for the area prior to boundary changes, posted about the incident on X.\n\n\"I am deeply concerned by the tragic reports of the murder of 3 women in Bushey yesterday evening,\" Dowden wrote.\n\nHe offered thoughts and prayers to families and friends of the victims and said he will support the community during this \"difficult\" time.\n\n\"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community,\" local councilors for the area said.\n\nHunt is a radio presenter specializing in horse racing events, such as the Grand National.\n\nThe BBC called the killings as \"utterly devastating\" in a note to staff, ITV reported.\n\nThe murder rate in Britain is more than six times lower than in the U.S., NBC News reported.\n\nCrossbow killings are even more uncommon, with fewer than 10 in the U.K. between 2011 and 2021.", "source": "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/10/huge-manhunt-for-armed-triple-murder-suspect-after-devastating-deaths/", "title": "Huge manhunt for armed triple murder suspect after 'devastating' deaths", "body": "Carol Hunt and her two daughters were killed in the incident in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday.\n\nA huge manhunt for a potentially armed triple murder suspect is under way following the \"utterly devastating\" crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the broadcaster said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. BBC Five Live Racing Commentator's John  Hunt's Wife and Two Daughters Shot Dead by Ex-Boyfriend With Crossbow", "body": "On Wednesday morning, the usually tranquil cul-de-sac was teeming with armed police and forensic officers as the triple murder investigation continued.\n\nThe victims of a deadly crossbow attack at their home have been identified as the wife and two daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt. Mother Carol, 61, and daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their $100,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday night.\n\nAccording to police sources, the three women were first tied up and then shot in what appears to have been a \"targeted attack\" that might have also involved several \"other weapons.\" Hertfordshire Police are now searching for their suspected killer, 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, who allegedly fled the house on Ashyn Close, Bushey, before 7 pm on Tuesday evening.\n\nTargeted Attack, Victims Identified\n\nA massive manhunt is in underway to track Clifford, the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise. Helicopters were spotted circling the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, on Wednesday afternoon before police raided an empty property in the vicinity.\n\nAuthorities then focused on a nearby primary school, which was placed on lockdown after the suspect's car was found.\n\nPolice have warned that Clifford may still be armed and dangerous. They have advised the public not to approach him and to call 999 immediately if he is spotted.\n\nAt a press conference today, Hertfordshire Police urged Clifford to \"make contact with the police\" as the suspect in the killings remains at large.\n\nClifford, from Enfield, north London, worked as a security guard, it has been reported. On Wednesday morning, the usually tranquil cul-de-sac was teeming with armed police and forensic officers as the triple murder investigation continued.\n\nLouise's father, John, was working at Lingfield Park racecourse yesterday before returning home to the horrific scene.\n\nShocked neighbors said that Louise ran a dog grooming business called Groom and Glow from the detached house in the cul-de-sac.\n\nLocal resident William Nourallah paid tribute to the \"beautiful young girl.\" \"She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father,\" Nourallah said.\n\n\"She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. She was a beautiful young girl. It's a waste of a life,\" Nourallah added.\n\nCommunity Shocked\n\nA neighbor, who lives on the \"serene and quiet road\" and wished to remain anonymous, described the victims as a \"friendly family.\" \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn a statement released this morning, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said, \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family, and we ask that their privacy be respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n\"He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.sg", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times, Singapore Edition"}, "authors": [{"uri": "r_ghosh@ibtimes.sg", "name": "R. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nMORE TOP STORIES: BMW {"uri": "8219644530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:30:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:30:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:27:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/uk-police-arrest-crossbow-attack-suspect-after-3-women-killed-6079787", "title": "UK Police Arrest Crossbow Attack Suspect After 3 Women Killed", "body": "Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe police said that it was a suspected \"targeted\" attack. (Representational)\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n- 'Shocking' -\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nOne neighbour described hearing \"shrill\" screams from the home on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house',\" she added.\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal man armed with crossbow after 3 women killed", "body": "Police said 3 women were found seriously injured in a house, northwest of London, and warned that the suspect may be armed with a crossbow\n\nScreams were heard from a house in a quiet British cul-de-sac where three women, died before \u201cabsolute chaos\u201d broke out as armed police looking for their killer put the road in lockdown, a neighbour has said.\n\nA resident living in Ashlyn Close in Bushey, Hertfordshire said the tragedy that unfolded at around 7pm on Tuesday was \u201cabsolutely traumatic\u201d.\n\nPolice have launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, north London in connection with the deaths, and have warned that he may be armed with a crossbow.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who lives near the scene, did not wish to share her name but said she works in the media.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \u201cIt was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night, and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill, and I was like, \u2018that\u2019s definitely a woman screaming\u2019, and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\u201cWe had armed police running down, screaming \u2018stay in your house\u2019 \u2026 they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\u201d\n\nThey said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \u201cat least 16 police cars\u201d arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added: \u201cIt\u2019s really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\u201d\n\nInvestigators believe Clifford could be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \u201ctruly shocking\u201d deaths.\n\nOfficers and emergency medical crews including two air ambulances were sent to try to save the women, who were related, but they all died at the scene.\n\nLocal councillors for the North Bushey area said they were \u201cdeeply shocked and saddened\u201d by the news of the deaths.\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well, but they were a friendly family.\n\n\u201cWe would see them every day passing by, and they would say good morning,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really sad what\u2019s happened, very shocking.\u201d\n\nAnother neighbour, Riaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give his surname, said: \u201cThis has been an awful situation and I can\u2019t even imagine what the family must be going through.\u201d\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who also lives nearby, told the BBC the area is \u201ca typical leafy British suburb\u201d.\n\nHe said: \u201cAt about eight o\u2019clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed on the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey, and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\u201cThis is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so [it\u2019s a] terrible shock, and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\u201cThat really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I\u2019ve gathered they\u2019re all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we\u2019ll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\u201d\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit called for anyone with information to come forward.\n\n\u201cWhilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford, who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or north London,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cGiven the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\u201cOur inquiries will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened, but I would also like to take this opportunity to appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\u201d\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \u201cWe were called around 7pm on Tuesday, July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\u201cThree ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\u201cSadly, despite the team\u2019s best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\u201d\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: \u201cWe are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\u201cAs North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\u201cWe would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\u201d\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws around crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nAdditional reporting {"uri": "8219851330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:58:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:58:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:56:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/suspect-in-crossbow-killing-of-bbc-commentators-family-found-police-5683737", "title": "Suspect in Crossbow Killing of BBC Commentator's Wife and Daughters Found: Police", "body": "LONDON -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing three women, the wife and daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator, near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nFootage from Sky News showed the suspect being carried on a stretcher out of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, which is close to his home and around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killings. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff had massed around the cemetery through the day.\n\nThe public had been urged not to approach Clifford, who the BBC reported had been in the British Army for a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nMs. Jenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Mr. Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Mr. Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Mr. Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Mr. Clifford was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident killed", "body": "UK hunt for man with crossbow after three women killedStaff WritersAPWed, 10 July 2024 8:21PM\n\nBritish police are hunting for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow after three women were killed in a house near London.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Herfordshire Police said Clifford was believed to have targeted the women, who were related.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident, involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow and other weapons may also have been used,\" Simpson said on Wednesday.\n\nPolice said the three women - aged 25, 28 and 61 - were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening.\n\nPolice and ambulance crews tried to save them but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women.\n\nClifford might still be armed and the public was warned not to approach him.\n\n\"Kyle, if you are "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13620883/Armed-police-paramedics-swoop-cemetery-manhunt-triple-murder-suspect-Kyle-Clifford-continues-BBC-stars-wife-daughters-murdered.html", "title": "Armed cops swoop in on cemetery as Kyle Clifford manhunt continues", "body": "The hunt for a fugitive accused of murdering three people with a crossbow took a dramatic turn when armed police swooped in on a north London cemetery.\n\nPolice and paramedics were seen racing to Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, on Wednesday afternoon as the huge manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued.\n\nClifford became Britain's most wanted man after police said they were hunting the ex-soldier in connection with the 'murders' of Carol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nThe women, who are wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, were found fatally injured inside their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nPolice sources said the women had been tied up before they were shot dead with a crossbow in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons'.\n\nChilling doorbell footage emerged of what was believed to be the suspect fleeing the scene on Ashlyn Close in Bushey carrying what appeared to be a crossbow concealed underneath a white sheet shortly before 7pm yesterday.\n\nTeams of armed police were seen searching Lavender Hill Cemetery this afternoon\n\nForensics were seen outside Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued\n\nArmed police searching Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for fugitive Kyle Clifford took a new turn\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for Clifford continues\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nAs police scoured the area, their attention turned to Clifford's hometown of Enfield, with officers carrying out raids and locking down primary schools in a bid to catch him.\n\nArmed police and paramedics were filmed this afternoon running into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt continued for Clifford, a former soldier and security guard.\n\nLater, armed police closed down the cemetery, a five-minute walk from the house linked to the suspect. Up to four black-clad officers - two carrying automatic rifles - stood guard at the cemetery gates, preventing members of the public from entering.\n\nMeanwhile, an ambulance rushed into the cemetery grounds with blue lights flashing and sirens on. It re-emerged about 20 minute later, still in emergency mode.\n\nDoorbell footage shows a man believed to be Kyle Clifford allegedly fleeing the murder scene with a crossbow\n\nThe suspect is allegedly seen coming out of an alleyway and walking towards a car (seen on the left of this grab)\n\nThe man opens the car door and gets inside before driving off\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nPolice have launched a huge manhunt for Clifford\n\nTwo helicopters were also spotted hovering- one believed to be an air ambulance which landed in the cemetery grounds.\n\nEarlier, officers raided a house where Clifford is known to live, with dramatic footage from today showing officers storming the property.\n\nPolice have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park. Members of the public have been told to immediately call 999 if they see Clifford but not approach him, describing him as dangerous and potentially still armed.\n\nKyle Clifford dropped out of the army weeks before he is alleged to have murdered three people\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nNearby schools have gone into precautionary lockdowns, with teachers at one primary telling parents to collect their children at the end of the day and take them directly home.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nClifford's neighbours told today how police had put the road into lockdown as a house was searched by armed officers.\n\nThey spoke as two police helicopters hovered above the neighbourhood and two uniformed PCs stood guard at the door of the terraced home.\n\nOne local mother told how she arrived back from dropping her children off at school to find armed police at the house opposite hers.\n\nRead MoreEXCLUSIVE 'Crossbow suspect tied up his ex, her sister and mother before shooting them dead' at Bushey home\n\n'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into,' she told MailOnline. 'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\n'They let me through to get home and they remained there for about an hour before they left. Then there was just the ordinary police there. 'I don't know the family at all. I know the father passed away some time ago but that's about it.'\n\nOne woman who lives across the road from the house said he had been working from home when she heard a commotion.\n\n'I was upstairs, when I heard cars honking and then looked out the window and realised that there were police there,' she said.\n\n'I came down and looked across. And they were saying ''armed police'' and then they went right in. There were dogs barking and everyone realised there was something big going on.'\n\nThe mother added: 'We've now been told that my daughter's school around the corner has gone into an amber lockdown. A few other schools have shut their doors as well. So we're just a little bit worried. I think everyone is really, really concerned.'\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X: 'No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n'Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.'\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered'\n\nDramatic footage shows police storming a home in Enfield as part of the hunt for triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford, 26\n\nPolice - seen during the raid - have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park\n\nArmed police have been seen carrying out a thorough search of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield\n\nAn officer walks through foliage in Lavender Hill Cemetery this afternoon\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place was swarming with armed police and forensic officers.\n\nOne neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there were like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women died last night\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nA lone police officers patrols the road at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.'\n\nSeveral police cars can also been seen parked on the road. It was in a nightclub in Hemel Hempstead. We went out together, went to birthdays and events.\n\nMs Holloway continued: \"They were a lovely family and (the daughters) were lovely girls.\n\n\"They were making their way through life and their lives have been taken too soon. It's the thing of nightmares.\n\n\"I feel for their eldest daughter and John (Hunt). More info\n\nBBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt tragically discovered his wife and two daughters had been brutally attacked upon returning home.\n\nThe family members were victims of a suspected crossbow attacker. It is believed that Hunt came back from his work duties to find his wife and daughters with serious injuries and all three were later declared deceased at the scene.\n\nHunt, who has been married with three children, was reportedly working for the BBC on Tuesday and is thought to have sounded the alarm when he arrived home around 7pm, as The Telegraph reports. Carol Hunt, the broadcaster's 61 year old wife, has been identified by locals, while Hertfordshire Police confirmed in a Wednesday afternoon press briefing that the other casualties were her daughters.\n\nWith a background in law enforcement, Hunt has been a familiar voice on BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for two decades. ITV racing analyst Matt Chapman expressed his deep sorrow on X, previously known as Twitter, on Wednesday.\n\nHis message read: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\", reports the Mirror.\n\nAuthorities are currently searching for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, who is sought in relation to the tragic events that unfolded at a residence in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit has issued a plea for public assistance, stating: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\nHe continued to highlight the urgency of locating a person of interest: \"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\"\n\nEmphasising the potential danger, he added: \"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nDS Hall also called for witnesses: \"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\"\n\nAddressing community concerns, he reassured: \"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper expressed her condolences via social media: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. The victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nPolice said Clifford, found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought. Clifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said. Police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\". According to British media reports, Clifford had been romantically involved with Louise Hunt, the youngest daughter of the Hunts, but they split up a week ago. The breakup deeply affected Louise, who recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside their family home, UK's Daily Mail reported.\n\nCarol Hunt, a mother of three, had confided in friends at her local gym about her daughter's tumultuous breakup with her boyfriend. \"She mentioned her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol didn't go into specifics, but you could tell she was worried,\" a friend was quoted as saying by the British newspaper.\n\nUK's Interior Minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry. \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. London suburb of Bushey.\n\nThe women, aged 25, 28 and 61, were found seriously injured in their home on Tuesday evening and despite efforts by police and emergency services technicians, all three died at the scene.\n\nThe deceased were the wife and daughters of BBC Radio horse racing commentator John Hunt, who discovered the women upon returning from work at Lingfield Park Racecourse south of {"uri": "8219210381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:21:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:21:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:21:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.dailywire.com/news/bbc-commentators-wife-daughters-killed-in-crossbow-attack-suspect-caught", "title": "BBC Commentator's Wife, Daughters Killed In Crossbow Attack; Suspect Caught", "body": "The wife and two daughters of a BBC horseracing commentator have been killed in a crossbow attack, with police capturing the suspect after a day-long manhunt.\n\nBritish police were called to the home of commentator John Hunt in Bushey, Hertfordshire, around 7 p.m. local time on Tuesday. Once there, police discovered three women with serious injuries, Deadline reported.\n\n\"Sadly, despite our best efforts, the women died a short time later, at the scene,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson told reporters after the incident. \"Our overarching objective today is to protect the public and locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\"\n\nClifford is a former soldier and the ex-boyfriend of one of the slain women and is still at large.\n\nArmed police and search teams looked for Clifford throughout Wednesday, finally capturing him in the evening without incident.\n\n\"Following an extensive search, Kyle Clifford, aged 26, was found in the Enfield area by officers this afternoon,\" Herts Police Department said in a statement, according to Deadline. \"He is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries. No shots were fired by police.\"\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, told reporters following Clifford's capture that \"the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\nThe Independent reported that \"swarms\" of officers were seen raiding a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, a woman connected to Clifford was questioned in a home near Lavender Hill,\n\nThe three female victims were identified as Hunt's wife, Carol, 61; his daughter Hannah, 28; and another daughter Louise, 25.\n\nPolice have said the attack was carried out with a crossbow and possibly other weapons, according to BBC.\n\nJacqueline Ball told the BBC earlier Wednesday that schools in the area were in \"lockdown,\" and children were being kept indoors while police searched for Clifford. Other parents told the outlet they were given specific times, which were staggered, for when they could pick up their children from school.\n\nThe attack comes as Britain's Home Office is looking to tighten laws on citizens owning crossbows, even though fewer than 10 crossbow attacks occurred between 2011 and 2021. The BBC has confirmed that the women were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was wanted in the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\nArmed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park in Enfield, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery. The area has been closed off and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation.\n\nPolice said the three women -- aged 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without be.\n\nIt is thought that Clifford, from the Enfield area, \"may be in possession of a crossbow\" and anyone who sees him is urged not to approach but to instead call 999 \"straight away\".\n\nIn a in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\"\n\nArmed police swarmed an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as part of a search connected to the murders, this morning.\n\nSome Enfield Primary Schools have been keeping children inside as
