{"uri": "8220311586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "11:06:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T11:06:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T11:05:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13623197/triple-crossbow-killer-suspect-kyle-Clifford-condition-police-update.html", "title": "Vigil for BBC star's wife and two daughters who killed with crossbow", "body": "READ MORE: Who is John Hunt? The BBC Five Live racing commentator\n\nTributes have been paid to the wife and daughters of BBC racing commentator John Hunt after they horrifically murdered in a 'targeted' crossbow attack at their home.\n\nDistraught neighbours and friends have said mother Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were the 'loveliest family' after they were killed at their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening.\n\nThis morning heartbroken loved ones attended a vigil for the murdered women at their local church, with many who went seen arriving in tears at the deeply emotional event.\n\nIt comes as colleagues of Mr Hunt, who shares another daughter with Carol who was not present at the time of the attack and survived, have rallied around him during the 'utterly devastating' nightmare their family has been plunged into.\n\nToday police are continuing to search a property in Enfield, believed to be linked to suspect Kyle Clifford, who was the subject of a huge 22-hour manhunt following the discovery of their bodies on Tuesday night.\n\nHe was tracked down to a cemetery in north London, with the ex-solder then being rushed to hospital after being injured - it is believed he turned the crossbow on himself with police saying they did not fire any shots during the operation to capture him.\n\nPolice are expected to issue an update on his condition later today, and while officers continue to investigate the killings, they say they are not looking for anyone else in connection.\n\nIt comes as it was revealed:\n\nNeighbours heard piercing screams in the minutes before the bodies of the three women were found;Louise Hunt crashed her car days before the murders after going through a 'messy' break up; Colleagues of John Hunt expressed their horror at the 'evil' incident which has befallen 'one of the nicest members of the human race';Doorbell footage showed Kyle Clifford fleeing the scene of the murders while carrying a crossbow;Home Secretary Yvette Cooper is considering changes to legislation after the latest violent attack involving crossbows;Louise Hunt shared a tweet praising 'women who leave' for their 'strength' days before the murders\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nSuspect Kyle Clifford with his ex-girlfriend Louise Hunt, who was one of the three victims\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nThe suspect can be seen receiving medical treatment on a stretcher in the cemetery in North London\n\nArmed police carrying guns run into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield on Wednesday afternoon\n\nAn ambulance at the scene at Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield on Wednesday afternoon\n\nPolice sources say there is evidence the women were being tied up before being shot dead with a 3ft-long crossbow in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons' on Tuesday night.\n\nNeighbours had alerted police to the horrifying attack after hearing the terrified screams of the women in their quiet cul-de-sac in Hertfordshire on Tuesday evening.\n\nBy the time police arrived at the property the assailant had fled, with officers believed to have contacted Mr Hunt as he returned from working at Lingfield Park course.\n\nAlthough police and ambulance had rushed to the house, they were unable to save the three victims who died at the scene.\n\nIt wasn't long before detectives were on the trail of a suspect after a figure was seen darting out of an alleyway directly behind the murder scene. Clad in black, the man was captured on camera calmly striding away with what appeared to be a crossbow tucked under his arm hidden beneath a white sheet.\n\nREAD MORE BBC star John Hunt credits wife Carol for inspiring his career after spotting advert in paper\n\nChillingly, he passed within feet of a female neighbour, who stood alone on her driveway stroking a cat and seemed startled by the sight of the barely concealed weapon at 6.50pm.\n\nWithin hours, a national manhunt was under way for former soldier Kyle Clifford, who was named by police in a highly unusual step. The 26-year-old had previously served in the Queen's Dragoon Guards for a short time before dropping out having failed to impress superiors, it was said last night.\n\nAs they attempted to track him down, police warned the public not to approach the suspect, who was last seen driving off from the cul-de sac in a grey vehicle the previous evening.\n\nAs police scoured the area, their attention turned to Clifford's hometown of Enfield, with officers carrying out raids and locking down primary schools in a bid to catch him.\n\nBystanders captured the moment police raided a property in Rendlesham Road, believed to be where Clifford lived, with officers continuing to search the address today.\n\nArmed police and paramedics were filmed on Wednesday afternoon running into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt continued for Clifford, a former soldier and security guard.\n\nLater, armed police closed down the cemetery, a five-minute walk from the house linked to the suspect. Up to four black-clad officers - two carrying automatic rifles - stood guard at the cemetery gates, preventing members of the public from entering.\n\nMeanwhile, an ambulance rushed into the cemetery grounds with blue lights flashing and sirens on just after 4.30pm after Clifford seemingly shot himself with the crossbow.\n\nAround 20 minutes later he was stretchered from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he received medical treatment overnight.\n\nA member of the public dries her eyes at a vigil for Carol, Hannah and Louise Hunt at St James's Church in Bushey this morning\n\nPeople hug each other and shed tears as they remember the victims of the horrific murders at a vigil this morning\n\nParishioners bow their heads as they listen to a sermon at a vigil for Carol, Hannah and Louise Hunt at St James's Church in Bushey this morning\n\nFather Stevenson delivers a sermon to members of the public at a vigil being held this morning for three women who were killed\n\nFlowers left outside the house where the bodies of Carole, Hannah and Louise Hunt were found on Tuesday\n\nIn one message bereaved neighbours paid tribute to the 'three beautiful souls that left us too early'\n\nFloral tributes left outside the police cordon close to the scene where the three women were murdered\n\nJockeys wear black armbands at Kempton Park Racecourse yesterday out of respect for John Hunt\n\nPolice confirmed no shots had been fired by officers and nobody else was being sought.\n\nREAD MOREEXCLUSIVE How 'crossbow killer' slayed three in cul-de-sac rampage before 'shooting himself'\n\nA London Ambulance spokesperson said yesterday: 'Ambulance crews and London's air ambulance attended an incident in Lavender Hill Cemetery, Enfield, this afternoon. We treated a man at the scene and took him to a major trauma centre.'\n\nTributes have since poured in for the family, with the BBC saying Mr Hunt is 'utterly devastated'.\n\nAround 50 people attended a vigil in their memory at a local church this morning, many of whom arrived in tears and were too upset to speak.\n\nInside Father David Stevenson paid tribute to the women, echoing the written tributes left to the family amid the bundles of flowers outside the police cordon.\n\nKyle Clifford dropped out of the army weeks before he is alleged to have murder three people\n\nArmed police searching Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for fugitive Kyle Clifford took a new turn\n\nForensics were seen outside Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nColleagues of Hannah took to Facebook to pay tribute to the 'fantastic therapist' who was 'loved' by her clients.\n\nThe Anti-Ageing Clinic at Radlett wrote on Facebook: 'It is with deep regret and sadness of the horrific murder on Tuesday night of our skin therapist Hannah.\n\nREAD MORE Michael Owen pays tribute to John Hunt's family after the murder of his wife and daughters\n\n'She was a fantastic therapist and clients loved her.\n\n'We send our condolences and prayers to her Dad, sister and family.'\n\nNeighbours claimed Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left her so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house. I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it.\n\n'A friend of Louise's told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.'\n\nA police officer walks down the road at the site of a triple murder in Bushey on Wednesday\n\nAn officer stands next to a police a car outside the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place\n\nHe added: 'Carol was a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'They were all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\nREAD MOREBREAKING NEWS 'Moment murder suspect flees scene with crossbow' after 'killing ex-girlfriend and her family'\n\n'A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. They'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years.'\n\nMrs Hunt, a mother of three, had recently told friends at her local gym that her youngest daughter was involved in a 'messy break-up' with her boyfriend.\n\nOne suggested her daughter's relationship had turned nasty.\n\nA friend said: 'She said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nDays before she was murdered Louise had shared a post on social media praising 'women who leave'.\n\nThe young dog groomer reposted her final tweet on social media platform X on July 3, which read: 'I admire women who leave, idgaf if you left after the 1st time or the 12th time I admire s***!\n\n'Idgaf if ppl calling you dumb for 11 years but in the 12th year you decided you was done. It takes A LOT of strength to break a tie. It takes ALOT of self love to choose yo self.'\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago\n\nLouise Hunt shared her final post on social media platform X on July 3, praising 'women who leave' for their 'strength'\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, and mother Carol Hunt, 61, were also killed in the tragic attack on Tuesday\n\nThe three women lived with BBC star John Hunt (pictured), who was at work at the time of the attack\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nHis colleague at Radio 5 Live Mark Chapman opened his coverage of England's Euro 2024 semi-final by paying a tearful tribute to his friend.\n\nREAD MORE Horrific details emerge from crossbow carnage house where BBC man's wife and daughters were executed\n\nSpeaking with a quivered voice on the radio last night, sports presenter Chapman said: 'This has been a heartbreaking day. John Hunt is our colleague, and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live Sport team, but to all of those who have worked here with him over the past 20 years.\n\n'And also, to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries. So, on behalf of everybody connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.'\n\nYesterday jockeys at Kempton Park Racecourse wore black armbands as they took part in races as a mark of respect of Mr Hunt. This afternoon there will be a minute's silence at Newmarket Racecourse in Suffolk in memory of his family.\n\nJulie Harrington, chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority, said: 'The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n'John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable {"uri": "8219019889", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:55:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:55:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:55:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/uk-bbc-journalist-john-hunt-wife-two-daughters-killed-using-crossbow-manhunt-begins-for-kyle-clifford-triple-murder-case-2024-07-10-941231", "title": "BBC journalist's wife, two daughters killed using crossbow, manhunt begins in 'horrific' triple murder case", "body": "The BBC said that the women were Carol Hunt, the wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters. A huge search involving armed officers has now been launched for the suspect, Kyle Clifford.\n\nBritish police launched a huge manhunt Wednesday for a man believed to be armed with a crossbow and potentially other weapons after three women were killed in a house northwest of London. The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio horse racing commentator John Hunt. Hertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons.\n\nThe public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him. Armed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said. Police said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters. John Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. The Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\" Police did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident. People in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse. A spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n(With inputs murder suspect after 'devastating' deaths", "body": "Carol Hunt and her two daughters were killed in the incident in Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday.\n\nA huge manhunt for a potentially armed triple murder suspect is under way following the \"utterly devastating\" crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to {"uri": "8219299127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:44:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:44:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:43:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/world-news/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police-say-9199638", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a well-known BBC radio commentator near London in a brutal crossbow attack.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford was found in the Enfield area of north London, near his home, and that he is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. Police did not say how those injuries happened but stressed that they had not fired any shots.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the women killed were members of the family of its commentator John Hunt -- his 61-year-old wife Carol Hunt and their daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25.\n\nFootage from Sky News showed the suspect being carried on a stretcher out of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, which is close to his home and around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killings. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff had massed around the cemetery through the day.\n\nThe public had been urged not to approach Clifford, who the BBC reported had been in the British Army for a brief period of service in 2022.\n\n\"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" said Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" she added.\n\nJenkins said the investigation is moving \"at pace\" and that formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. She also said that the \"premature\" naming of the victims \"caused great upset.\"\n\nPolice had been scouring a park in north London, near the home of Clifford, after being alerted Tuesday about the killings in a house in Bushey, a residential area in northwestern London. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nA colleague of Hunt's and BBC 5 Live's lead presenter Mark Chapman struggled to hold back the tears as he expressed everyone's shock and pain.\n\n\"We have a football match to bring you tonight ... and we will start our buildup to it shortly but this has been a heartbreaking day,\" he said as he opened Wednesday's coverage on 5 Live of England's semifinal match against The Netherlands in soccer's European Championship.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who've worked here with him over the past 20 years, and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries,\" Chapman said. \"So on behalf of everyone connected to 5 Live Sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that Hunt found the bodies early Tuesday evening, after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nPolice did not say how or whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media had reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson suggested the attack was not random and that the suspect knew the family.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, described the area as \"a typical leafy British suburb\" as he recounted his experience from the previous night.\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, was kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nPan Pylas, The Associated {"uri": "2024-07-417811155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:38:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:38:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:41:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2024/07/10/john-hunt-kyle-clifford-bbc-crossbow-manhunt/74350957007/", "title": "Manhunt underway in UK after 3 family members of BBC journalist were killed; crossbow involved in attack", "body": "British police said Wednesday a manhunt is underway after three women related to a BBC commentator were killed in an attack involving a crossbow.\n\nHertfordshire police were called Tuesday evening to a property in Bushey, more than an hour northwest of London, a spokesperson said at a Wednesday press conference. Upon arrival, they found three women seriously injured. Officials administered emergency aid, but the women, aged 61, 28 and 25, died at the scene, police said.\n\nThe BBC identified the victims as Carol Hunt, wife of BBC Racing radio commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nPolice are seeking information on the whereabouts of Kyle Clifford, 26, who is wanted in connection to the killings. Police called the triple murder a \"targeted incident\" involving a crossbow, though other weapons may have also been used. Clifford may still be armed, police said.\n\nAnyone with knowledge of his whereabouts should contact local police by calling 101, reporting information online or dialing 999 in the case of an {"uri": "8220278149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:44:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/how-kyle-clifford-manhunt-unfolded-33216943", "title": "Crossbow murder manhunt timeline - school lockdown terror to 'hiding in church'", "body": "Kyle Clifford was taken to hospital following a 24-hour police manhunt\n\nA manhunt for suspected triple murderer Kyle Clifford finally came to an end last night after 24 hours when they captured him in a cemetery in north London.\n\nThe 26-year-old former security guard, from Enfield, was wanted by police in connection with the deaths of mother Carol Hunt, 61, and her daughters Louise Hunt, 25, and Hannah Hunt, 28. The trio were fatally wounded in their home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, in what is believed to be a 'targeted attack' with a crossbow.\n\nPolice and emergency services were called to the property at around 7pm on Tuesday however despite their best efforts to save the women, all three tragically died at the scene. They have since been named as the wife and two daughters of BBC racing commentator John Hunt, who is said to be inconsolable over the harrowing tragedy.\n\nHorrific details from the attack emerged yesterday, with one of the three victims believed to have called 999 in a brave act before the perpetrator fled the scene, The Guardian reports. The paper also claims that one of the women sent a text to their partner urging them to call the police.\n\nThe mum, who shares a third daughter with John who lives in Birmingham, was reportedly found in the hallway of their home with a crossbow bolt in her chest. Previous reports suggested the alleged killer tied up his victims but a source told the Guardian that the women were not gagged and bound when found.\n\nHowever there was reportedly evidence of ligature marks around their wrists and face, suggesting these had been removed. The source also said all three had injuries to their knees.\n\nDistraught neighbours have described what they heard that evening, with one resident hearing a piercing cry for help, which they initially mistook for a distressed child. The 46-year-old, who wished not to be named, said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\" They said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nThey added: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help. It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone. I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nThe following morning, police announced that three women had died at a property in Bushey, with the suspected killer still at large. Hertfordshire Police then held a press conference at lunchtime with more details, confirming the ages of the victims.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson confirmed they had been \"targeted\" and attacked with a crossbow and other weapons. Directly appealing to the suspect, Chief Sup Simpson said: \"Kyle if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact.\"\n\nThey appealed to the public for information and to ring 999 if anyone saw him, however warned not to approach him. They believed the suspect to be in Hertfordshire or closer to his home in Enfield.\n\nChief Supt Simpson also told reporters: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nIt didn't take long for the suspect to be picked up on a nearby door cam, where he was spotted wearing a black tracksuit and carrying what appeared to be a crossbow covered in a white sheet under his arm. The bearded figure also carried a black sports bag, which police feared may have contained a cache of weapons.\n\nChillingly, Clifford, who is understood to have served in the British Army for about a year, strode past a female neighbour who was stroking a cat on her drive at around 6.50pm. He was then seen getting into his car and placing the suspected weapons in the backseat.\n\nSchools in north London were put under lockdown as they continued to search for Clifford. Headteacher Jade-Simone Bacon, of St Michael's C.E. Primary School in Enfield, said: \"We've locked both buildings and just kept the children inside. So we've not had them on the field or the playground. It's not a lockdown as in under the desks or hidden or anything, it's just a lighter lockdown.\n\n\"We have just kept them within the building as though it were like a wet playday so we don't cause the children any distress and we keep everything as calm as possible.\" Speaking to Sky News, she said that police visited to reassure staff and students and that teachers were told to \"continue as normal as possible\".\n\nAfter finding Clifford's abandoned car in north London, dozens of armed officers from Scotland Yard and Hertfordshire Police flooded the area. One mother, who wished not to be named, told MailOnline: \"They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into. They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\"\n\nMeanwhile, a local mum-of-two told the Mirror: \"Armed police have been here since around 2.30pm today - it's terrifying.\" Their efforts then moved to a nearby cemetery near to Rendlesham Road - a five-minute walk from Clifford's address - and on Wednesday evening, the manhunt finally came to a close after he was found hiding among headstones. A swarm of armed police closed in at the site, with paramedics then seen rushing into the grounds with an air ambulance circling overhead.\n\nThe BBC reported that the air \"is thick with the sound of helicopters\" operated by police and press. Local Rae Cresswell, 26, who filmed the commotion, said: \"I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them. I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.\"\n\nAfter around 20 minutes, Clifford was seen stretchered away from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he is receiving medical treatment after being discovered with injuries. Clifford had reportedly been hiding from police in a nearby church, according to one local, Adam, who claimed: \"He was hiding there all day and then came here. He was well known here, and was actually expelled from school for carrying a knife.\"\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\nA London Ambulance Spokesperson said: \"Ambulance crews and London's air ambulance attended an incident in Lavender Hill Cemetery, Enfield, this afternoon (Tuesday 10). We treated a man at the scene and took him to a major trauma centre.\"\n\nClifford is believed to have been the ex-boyfriend of the youngest victim Louise. It has been reported that they split up just a week earlier, with their parting said to have left her so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nLouise, who had her own dog grooming business, reposted a tweet praising 'women who leave' for their 'strength' just days before she was fatally attacked alongside her loved ones in the family home. The post read: \"I admire women who leave, idgaf if you left after the 1st time or the 12th time I admire s***!\n\n\"Idgaf if ppl calling you dumb for 11 years but in the 12th year you decided you was done. It takes A LOT of strength to break a tie. It takes ALOT of self love to choose yo self.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "saffron_otter@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Saffron Otter", {"uri": "8218628417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/uk-triple-murder-crossbow-manhunt-bushey-hertfordshire/", "title": "Police search underway after 3 women killed in crossbow attack in U.K.", "body": "London -- Police in England were searching Wednesday for a 26-year-old man they believe could be armed with a crossbow in connection with a triple murder.\n\nThe Hertfordshire Police force said in a statement that officers were called to a property in Bushey, northwest of London, just before 7 p.m. (2 p.m. Eastern) on Tuesday, where they found three women with serious injuries.\n\nThree ambulances, along with other emergency response vehicles including as Hazardous Area Response Team and two air ambulances were sent to the property, but all three of the women, who were believed to be related, died at the scene, the police said.\n\nOfficers were still searching on Wednesday for a man named Kyle Clifford, and they issued a public appeal for anyone with knowledge of his whereabouts to contact emergency services. The police advised people not to approach Clifford as \"he may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThe attack was carried out with a crossbow, Hertfordshire Police Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said later, adding that other weapons may also have been used.\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford had been known to the women, who were 25, 28 and 61 years old, but they said it was believed to have been a targeted incident.\n\nSpeaking on live television, Simpson appealed directly to Clifford on Wednesday, saying: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact,\" and urging him to call the U.K. emergency services number 999.\n\nBritain's Home Secretary Yvette Cooper, the top government official in charge of law enforcement, said in a post on social media that she was being kept \"fully updated\" on the case, and she urged anyone with information to contact the police.\n\n\"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community,\" she said.\n\n\"We're very shocked,\" local city councilor Laurence Brass told CBS News partner network BBC News that. \"We're not used to this in this area, it's a very typical, leafy Bushey suburb... and suddenly we're told there are three murders. We had a helicopter landing at the top of my road last night, police all over the place. So, I'm concerned for residents, who I think are a little bit traumatized by what's going on here.\"\n\nCrossbows are legal in the U.K. and no license or registration is required to own one, though it is illegal to carry a crossbow in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "body": "Huge manhunt for armed triple murder suspect after 'devastating' deaths\n\nPA reporters\n\n10 July 2024 at 5:01 pm\n\nA huge manhunt for a potentially armed triple murder suspect is under way following the \"utterly devastating\" crossbow deaths of the wife and two daughters of a BBC racing commentator.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the broadcaster said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: commentator John Hunt's wife and two daughters 'tied up and shot dead with crossbow'\n\nBBC stalwart Mr Hunt has worked at the corporation for 30 years as a racing commentator and previous to this worked as a police officer.\n\nHunt, a regular racetrack caller and frequent presenter on At the Races, is most widely heard as the commentary voice for the sport on BBC 5Live.\n\nHis work on the national sport's network has widened to occasional football commentary and also coverage of the equestrian events at the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nThe BBC said in its memo to staff it would provide Mr Hunt with 'all the support we can' following the murders of Carol Hunt and her two daughters in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nThe note to BBC 5 Live staff read: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham The public have been urged not to approach him and call 999.\n\nOne of the women's husbands is the BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, who was working at Lingfield Park race course yesterday.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, is being actively sought by police concerning the incident\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire following the deaths of three women\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey where three women, believed to be related, were discovered with serious injuries\n\nPolice have said they have launched a manhunt for Clifford\n\nThis morning the small close was cordoned off while scenes of crime officers carried out a forensic examination. Neighbours were concerned the killer was still at large.\n\nAerial shots of the scene aired on the BBC show a blue and white forensic tent in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac, with a police officer on guard and several police vehicles parked nearby.\n\nDramatic video from the scene earlier today a mass of police cars parked along the road and two armed police officers standing guard.\n\nA neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nAnother Herfordshire local today claimed 'there has been a helicopter circling all morning' close to the Bushey border.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings of the three women who were found in Bushey, Hertfordshire, and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X, formerly Twitter: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there was like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women, who police believe to be related, died last night\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.'\n\n'It's a serene, quiet road, but there was over a dozen cars here. It's quite disturbing, but any tragedy like this has a bearing on how you feel.\n\n'I don't think it's anything that we really should be overtly concerned about. Relationships go up and down, sometimes they end up like this.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nA lone police officers patrols the road at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\nSeveral police cars can also been seen parked on the road. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.'\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: 'We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n'As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n'We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.'\n\nAn East The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which potentially involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.", "source": -- were killed in a home in Hertfordshire, England on Tuesday, July 9, authorities said\n\nPolice in England have launched a manhunt after three women were killed in a home, with authorities saying the suspect may be in possession of a crossbow.\n\nIn a press release shared on Wednesday, July 10, Hertfordshire Police said they are looking for a 26-year-old man called Kyle Clifford in connection with the incident after being called to a property in Bushey just before 7:00 p.m. local time on Tuesday, July 9.\n\n\"Officers attended alongside colleagues from the East of England Ambulance Service and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries,\" the release read in part. \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\"\n\nIn a post shared on X (formerly Twitter) on July 10, police said Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\" and warned the public not to approach him.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\"\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately,\" Hall added. \"If you believe {"uri": "8219169566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:48:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:48:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:47:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/07/10/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police-say/", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW LONDON (AP) - British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a BBC radio commentator near London and that the suspect is receiving medical treatment for his injuries. In a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London. The BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt. While the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing. Armed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park in Enfield, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery. The area has been closed off and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation. Police said the three women - aged 25, 28 and 61 - were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene. The BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt. John Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. The Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London. As part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\u009d Police did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022. Local council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\u009d \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC. Addressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\u009d Britain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\"\u009d about the \"truly shocking\"\u009d incident. People in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse. A spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\"\u009d the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.", "source": {"uri": "8218839075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:58:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:58:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:57:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13620103/Armed-police-raid-Enfield-home-hunt-crossbow-killer-Cops-triple-murder-suspects-car-search-nearby-park-schools-lockdown-BBC-racing-commentator-John-Hunts-wife-two-daughters-dead.html", "title": "Armed police hunting for crossbow attack suspect raid home in Enfield", "body": "Armed police have raided a home in Enfield as they hunt for a man accused of a deadly crossbow attack that killed BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt's wife and two daughters.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, and her daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nPolice sources said the three women were tied up before being shot in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons'.\n\nDramatic footage from today shows officers storming a house in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, as part of a huge manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26 - the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise.\n\nPolice have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park. Members of the public have been told to immediately call 999 if they see Clifford but not approach him, describing him as dangerous and potentially still armed.\n\nNearby schools have gone into partial lockdowns, with teachers at one primary telling parents to collect their children at the end of the day and take them directly home.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nDramatic footage shows police storming a home in Enfield as part of the hunt for triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford, 26\n\nPolice - seen during the raid - have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey\n\nPolice have launched a huge manhunt for Clifford\n\nClifford's neighbours told today how police had put the road into lockdown as a house was searched by armed officers.\n\nThey spoke as two police helicopters hovered above the neighbourhood and two uniformed PCs stood guard at the door of the terraced home.\n\nOne local mother told how she arrived back from dropping her children off at school to find armed police at the house opposite hers.\n\n'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into,' she told MailOnline. 'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\nRead MoreEXCLUSIVE 'Crossbow suspect tied up his ex, her sister and mother before shooting them dead' at Bushey home\n\n'They let me through to get home and they remained there for about an hour before they left. Then there was just the ordinary police there. 'I don't know the family at all. I know the father passed away some time ago but that's about it.'\n\nOne woman who lives across the road from the house said he had been working from home when she heard a commotion.\n\n'I was upstairs, when I heard cars honking and then looked out the window and realised that there were police there,' she said.\n\n'I came down and looked across. And they were saying ''armed police'' and then they went right in. There were dogs barking and everyone realised there was something big going on.'\n\nThe mother added: 'We've now been told that my daughter's school around the corner has gone into an amber lockdown. A few other schools have shut their doors as well. So we're just a little bit worried. I think everyone is really, really concerned.'\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X: 'No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n'Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.'\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nClifford used to work as a security guard, it has been reported.\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered'\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place was swarming with armed police and forensic officers.\n\nOne neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there were like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women died last night\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.'\n\n'It's a serene, quiet road, but there was over a dozen cars here. It's quite disturbing, but any tragedy like this has a bearing on how you feel.\n\n'I don't think it's anything that we really should be overtly concerned about. Relationships go up and down, sometimes they end up like this.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nA lone police officers patrols the road at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\nSeveral police cars can also been seen parked on the road. One resident claimed 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine descended on the scene last night\n\nAn officer stands next to a police a car outside the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nA police officer walks down the road at the site of a triple murder in Bushey on Wednesday\n\n'Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n'This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.'\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: 'We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n'As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n'We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.'\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: 'We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n'Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n'Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were {"uri": "8219164773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:44:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:44:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:43:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/crossbow-triple-murder-suspect-kyle-33215040", "title": "Crossbow triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford found in cemetery after manhunt", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nPolice have confirmed that the suspect of a horrific crossbow massacre that saw three women murdered has been found in a cemetery yards from his home.\n\nOfficers said Kyle Clifford, 26, was found this afternoon and is currently receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries.\n\nArmed officers and a specialist search dog tracked Kyle down after searching a cemetery near Rendlesham Road in Enfield, north London.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\"\n\nClifford was the subject of a huge manhunt across areas of Hertfordshire and north London after three women were found dead in their home in Hertfordshire following a horrific crossbow attack.\n\nThe victims were later named as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nMr Hunt is understood to have been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday, and reportedly returned home to discover his wife and two daughters had been fatally injured. Police were called to the property in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm that day.\n\nOfficers arrived on scene with ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - to find that the trio had suffered serious injuries. The three women were alive when discovered, however, despite the best efforts of paramedics, all tragically died at the scene a short time later.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and
