{"uri": "8219108282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:00:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:00:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:59:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13620791/Triple-murder-suspect-Kyle-Clifford-CAUGHT-cemetery-tying-BBC-stars-wife-daughters-shooting-dead-crossbow-huge-manhunt.html", "title": "'Crossbow killer' Kyle Clifford is CAUGHT in cemetery after manhunt", "body": "A fugitive accused of murdering three people with a crossbow has been caught in a cemetery after a huge manhunt.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, was seen being bundled into the back of an ambulance in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, by armed police and paramedics on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nClifford became Britain's most wanted man after police said they were hunting the ex-soldier in connection with the 'murders' of Carol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28.\n\nThe women, who are wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, were found fatally injured inside their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nPolice sources said the women had been tied up before they were shot dead with a crossbow in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons'.\n\nChilling doorbell footage emerged of what is believed to be the suspect fleeing the scene on Ashlyn Close in Bushey carrying what appeared to be a crossbow concealed underneath a white sheet shortly before 7pm yesterday.\n\nDoorbell footage shows a man believed to be Kyle Clifford walking away from a house containing the dead bodies of his ex-girlfriend, her mother and her sister in Bushey yesterday evening. He is allegedly seen what appears to be the crossbow he allegedly used in the attack\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nKyle Clifford dropped out of the army weeks before he is alleged to have murder three people\n\nArmed police searching Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for fugitive Kyle Clifford took a new turn\n\nForensics were seen outside Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continued\n\nAs police scoured the area, their attention turned to Clifford's hometown of Enfield, with officers carrying out raids and locking down primary schools in a bid to catch him.\n\nArmed police and paramedics were filmed this afternoon running into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt continued for Clifford, a former soldier and security guard.\n\nLater, armed police closed down the cemetery, a five-minute walk from the house linked to the suspect. Up to four black-clad officers - two carrying automatic rifles - stood guard at the cemetery gates, preventing members of the public from entering.\n\nMeanwhile, an ambulance rushed into the cemetery grounds with blue lights flashing and sirens on. It re-emerged about 20 minute later, still in emergency mode.\n\nThe suspect is allegedly seen coming out of an alleyway and walking towards a car (seen on the left of this grab)\n\nThe man opens the car door and gets inside before driving off\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for Clifford continues\n\nTeams of armed police were seen searching Lavender Hill Cemetery this afternoon\n\nPolice have launched a huge manhunt for Clifford\n\nTwo helicopters were also spotted hovering- one believed to be an air ambulance which landed in the cemetery grounds.\n\nEarlier, officers raided a house where Clifford is known to live, with dramatic footage from today showing officers storming the property.\n\nPolice have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park. Members of the public have been told to immediately call 999 if they see Clifford but not approach him, describing him as dangerous and potentially still armed.\n\nNearby schools have gone into precautionary lockdowns, with teachers at one primary telling parents to collect their children at the end of the day and take them directly home.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nClifford's neighbours told today how police had put the road into lockdown as a house was searched by armed officers.\n\nThey spoke as two police helicopters hovered above the neighbourhood and two uniformed PCs stood guard at the door of the terraced home.\n\nOne local mother told how she arrived back from dropping her children off at school to find armed police at the house opposite hers.\n\nRead MoreEXCLUSIVE 'Crossbow suspect tied up his ex, her sister and mother before shooting them dead' at Bushey home\n\n'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into,' she told MailOnline. 'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\n'They let me through to get home and they remained there for about an hour before they left. Then there was just the ordinary police there. 'I don't know the family at all. I know the father passed away some time ago but that's about it.'\n\nOne woman who lives across the road from the house said he had been working from home when she heard a commotion.\n\n'I was upstairs, when I heard cars honking and then looked out the window and realised that there were police there,' she said.\n\n'I came down and looked across. And they were saying ''armed police'' and then they went right in. There were dogs barking and everyone realised there was something big going on.'\n\nThe mother added: 'We've now been told that my daughter's school around the corner has gone into an amber lockdown. A few other schools have shut their doors as well. So we're just a little bit worried. I think everyone is really, really concerned.'\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X: 'No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n'Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.'\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered'\n\nDramatic footage shows police storming a home in Enfield as part of the hunt for triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford, 26\n\nPolice - seen during the raid - have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park\n\nArmed police have been seen carrying out a thorough search of Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield\n\nAn officer walks through foliage in Lavender Hill Cemetery this afternoon\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place was swarming with armed police and forensic officers.\n\nOne neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there were like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women died last night\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nA lone police officers patrols the road at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. suspect after 'devastating' deaths", "body": "As part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation said it would provide John Hunt with \"all the support we can\" after the killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters Hannah and Louise in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThe hunt for Clifford appeared to focus on a cemetery in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nEmergency services, including armed police, could be seen in the area in footage posted on social media, with Hertfordshire Police saying they were unable to confirm whether they had narrowed their search for the triple murder suspect to the area.\n\nArmed police also searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show the suspect wearing black and carrying a large item under his right arm as he walked near the scene.\n\nHe is then seen to place the item into a black car, getting in the vehicle and pausing for a moment before driving away.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the broadcaster said: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether it had contact with the victims or Clifford before the killings.\n\nOne neighbour described hearing screams from the suburban home where the three women died on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who works in the media and lives near the scene but asked not to be named, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she is being kept fully updated about the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. {"uri": "8219176636", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:56:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:56:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:53:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2782283/", "title": "Search underway after BBC commentator's wife and two daughters killed in crossbow attack in UK - ExBulletin", "body": "LONDON -- Police in England were searching for a 26-year-old man they believe may have been carrying a crossbow in connection with a triple murder Wednesday. CBS News partner network BBC News reported that the victims were the wife and two adult daughters of John Hunt, a commentator for the network's horse racing radio channel BBC Racing.\n\nHertfordshire Police said in a statement that officers were called to a property in Bush, north-west London, just before 7pm (2pm ET) on Tuesday where they found three women with serious injuries.\n\nAccording to police, three ambulances and two air ambulances were dispatched to the scene along with other emergency response vehicles, including a hazardous area response team, but all three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nPolice were still searching for a man named Kyle Clifford who lives in the area on Wednesday and have issued a public appeal for anyone who knows his whereabouts to contact emergency services. Police have advised people not to approach Clifford, saying: \"He may still be carrying a weapon.\"\n\nA forensic scientist at the scene of Ashlyn Close, Bush, Hertfordshire, where three women, believed by police to be related, died at the scene with serious injuries, shortly after police and ambulance crews were called just before 7pm on July 9, 2024. James Manning/PA Images/Getty\n\nHertfordshire Police Chief Constable John Simpson said on Wednesday the attack was carried out with a crossbow, but other weapons may have also been used.\n\nPolice have not said whether Clifford was known to the Hunt family. The victims were Carol Hunt, 61, and the couple's two daughters, aged 25 and 28. Police said it was believed to be a targeted incident but the connection was unclear. According to British media, former police officer John Hunt, who worked for the BBC for several years, returned home after the attack with his wife and daughter seriously injured.\n\nSimpson appeared on television on Wednesday and made a direct appeal to Clifford, saying: \"Kyle, if you see or hear this, please get in touch,\" and urged him to call Britain's emergency service 999.\n\nYvette Cooper, the UK's home secretary and top government official responsible for law enforcement, said in a social media post that she was keeping \"fully informed\" of the incident and urged anyone with information to contact police.\n\n\"It is absolutely shocking that three women lost their lives in Bush last night. My thoughts go out to the families and friends of those who died, and to the community,\" she said.\n\n\"We're pretty shocked,\" local councillor Lawrence Brass told CBS News partner network BBC News. \"We're not used to this in this area. This is a very typical, bushy suburb... and all of a sudden we have three murders. We had helicopters landing on our roads last night, police everywhere. So I'm worried about the residents. I think they're a little bit traumatised by what's going on here.\"\n\nCrossbows are legal in the UK and no license or registration is required to own one. They died at the scene a short time later.\n\nThe BBC said that the women were Carol Hunt, the wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters. {"uri": "8218637064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:54:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:54:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:54:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/breaking-kyle-clifford-press-conference-33210376", "title": "Police message to 'crossbow-armed suspect' after three women murdered", "body": "Police have made a direct appeal to the chief suspect in the \"horrific\" murders of three woman to give himself up.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally injured women - who are believed to be related and are aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack in Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" last night and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\". He did not take any questions from the press.\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Bushey, Hertfordshire before 7pm. They found the trio with serious injuries but alive, whoever all died a short time later.\n\nOfficers are now looking for 26-year-old Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident, having searched for him throughout the night after the horrific discovery. Cops believe he could be anywhere in the Hertfordshire or North London area but have urged anyone who sees him to stay wary and to phone 999 immediately, with a spokesperson for the police force later specifying that Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\". Anyone with information has been urged to come forward by police.\n\nAerial shots from a BBC live feed have shown a blue-and-white forensic tent in one of the front gardens of the cul-de-sac, with police and forensic teams swarming the area. The search is ongoing but no arrests have yet been made.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" are being piled into the manhunt, and that members of the public had already been getting in touch with the police to report possible sightings.\n\nThe Home Office is aware of the incident and being kept \"fully updated\". in a post on X, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.\"\n\nNeighbours expressed their shock after police, an ambulance crew and ground ambulances rushed to the \u00a3800,000 four-bed house. One neighbour, who gave his name as Riaz, said: \"They are a middle class family. It is tragic and horrifying.\n\n\"There was a lot of activity from the police and ambulance last night - there were over a dozen cars. There was an air ambulance. The road was closed way past midnight. There is no access into the road.\" Riaz, who is in his late 50s and works in Telecoms, said: \"It is a decent neighbourhood. It is mostly retired people and professionals living here.\"\n\nAnother neighbour of the family, who did not want to be named, said she did not know them well, but they were friendly. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLocal councillor Louise Nicolas posted on Facebook that she is \"deeply saddened\" by the \"tragic news\", offering her \"heartfelt condolences to all those affected\". She invited anyone who may be affected by the news to get in touch for support - adding that people should not take to Facebook to speculate on the ongoing investigation.\n\nLaurence Brass, a local county councillor, told BBC News: \"This is not something that happens in Bushey. We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our Upon arrival, officers found the three women suffering serious injuries.\n\n\"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women ... died a short time later,\" Simpson said during a press conference.\n\nSimpson described the assault as a \"targeted incident\" and said official believe a crossbow was involved \"but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\n\"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford,\" Simpson said Wednesday.\n\nHe added: \"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nAuthorities have not said what connection, if any, Clifford had to the Hunt family.\n\nThe Daily Mail reported, however, that Clifford, 26, is the ex-boyfriend of Hunt's daughter Louise. He briefly served in the British army and left in 2022, according to the BBC.\n\nCondolences and support across the horse racing world poured in for Hunt as the search for Clifford played out Wednesday.\n\n\"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today,\" racing broadcaster Matt Chapman wrote in a post on X. \"Just know we are all here for you John. {"uri": "8219169484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:48:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:48:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:47:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/man-suspected-of-killing-the-family-of-bbc-radio-commentator-has-been-found-british-police-say/", "title": "Man suspected of killing the family of BBC radio commentator has been found, British police say - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- British police said they found Wednesday the man suspected of killing the wife and two daughters of a BBC radio commentator near London and that the suspect is receiving medical treatment for his injuries.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said 26-year-old Kyle Clifford has been found in the Enfield area of north London. The BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\nArmed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park in Enfield, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery. The area has been closed off and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation.\n\nPolice said the three women -- aged 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8218644525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:59:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:59:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/what-we-know-about-kyle-clifford-the-suspect-wanted-by-police-over-bushey-triple-murder-13176041", "title": "What we know about Kyle Clifford - the suspect wanted by police over Bushey triple murder", "body": "Kyle Clifford is 26, from Enfield, north London, where neighbours say he \"always seemed pretty normal\".\n\nA manhunt is under way after three women were found dead in a house in Hertfordshire.\n\nDetectives are \"actively seeking\" 26-year-old Kyle Clifford after the victims were discovered by police and paramedics in Bushey on Tuesday night.\n\nFollow Bushey manhunt latest\n\nHere is everything we know about Clifford and the incident so far.\n\nWomen 'believed to be related'\n\nPolice were called to a detached house in Ashlyn Close, in northern Bushey, near Watford, just before 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nWhen they arrived alongside ambulance staff they found three women with \"serious injuries\".\n\nAccording to Hertfordshire Constabulary: \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\"\n\nThe victims were aged 25, 28, and 61, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said during a news conference at 12.30pm on Wednesday, but their exact relationship has still not been revealed.\n\nChief Supt Simpson said police believe it was a \"targeted incident\".\n\nDerek Turner, a resident of the same street, said the arrival of around 10 police cars and ambulance crews was \"like an explosion in the street\".\n\nHe told Sky News officers were dressed in \"black uniforms with sort of semi-automatic guns walking around\", causing him to mistake the callout for a terrorist incident.\n\nThe road is currently cordoned off, with a blue tent erected outside the front door of the property.\n\nSuspect 'may have crossbow'\n\nJust after 8.30am on Wednesday, police published Kyle Clifford's name, age, and photograph.\n\nHe is 26, from Enfield, north London. Detectives believe he could still be in either Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nThey appealed for the public's help to find him, warning: \"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nAt the news conference in Hatfield on Wednesday lunchtime, Chief Supt Simpson confirmed police believe a crossbow was used in the attack, but \"other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nThe Crossbow Act 1987 allows anyone over the age of 18 to buy one - with the only major restriction being they cannot be used on animals.\n\nEarlier this year, the Home Office launched a call for evidence to see if further legislation is needed after their use in several murders in the UK.\n\nA woman who grew up with Clifford in Enfield said he \"always seemed pretty normal\" and a \"nice guy\".\n\n\"We would always be at the same parties together and hanging around in Enfield. He never seemed odd or aggressive,\" she said.\n\nResidents of the area told Sky correspondent Ashna Hurynag that he is popular with local families and retirees.\n\n'Extensive police resources' deployed\n\nDuring the news conference in Hatfield, Chief Supt Simpson said \"extensive police resources\" have been deployed in both Hertfordshire and north London.\n\nThey include armed officers and specialist search teams, he added.\n\nHe acknowledged the public's concern and said additional officers will be on patrol to answer any questions.\n\nDetectives are appealing for anyone to come forward who was in or around Ashlyn Close between midday and 7pm on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "news.sky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sky News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which potentially involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world-famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it would provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters.\n\nLocal councilor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my In a previous statement, Hertfordshire Police said officers were called to a house in Bushey just before 7pm on Tuesday, where they found the women with serious injuries. All three died at the scene.\n\nThe BBC has named the victims as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25. They are the wife and daughters of John Hunt, a horse racing commentator for BBC 5 Live radio.\n\nHertfordshire Police said as of Wednesday evening it appeared the suspect knew the victims.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper, who took office last week following Labour's election victory, is considering tougher crossbow laws and will be assessing the results of a Home Office review this year, British media reported.\n\nThe previous government considered tightening laws around crossbows after assassin Jaswant Singh Chail broke into Windsor Castle on Christmas morning 2021 and attempted to kill Queen Elizabeth II with a crossbow.\n\nThere is no registration system or licensing requirement for crossbow ownership in the UK, but it is illegal for anyone under the age of 18 to possess a crossbow.\n\nIn February, the Conservative government's Home Office launched an eight-week review to consider introducing licensing and tighter restrictions on the sale of crossbows, similar to firearms regulations.\n\nThe office completed its review in April, but the recent election appears to have stalled any action.\n\nCooper wrote in a post to X on Wednesday that he was shocked by the killings and that he was keeping the investigation updated.\n\nJohn Hunt's fellow sports journalists and others in the horse racing industry have taken to social media to offer their condolences to the Hunt family.\n\nPain beyond comprehension, ITV racing commentator Matt Chapman writes to X. Magazine and Reach PLC magazines.\n\nPolice in England have launched a manhunt after three women were killed in a home, with authorities saying the suspect may be in possession of a crossbow.\n\nIn a press release shared on Wednesday, July 10, Hertfordshire Police said they are looking for a 26-year-old man called Kyle Clifford in connection with the incident after being called to a property in Bushey just before 7:00 p.m. local time on Tuesday, July 9.\n\n\"Officers attended alongside colleagues from the East of England Ambulance Service and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries,\" the release read in part. \"Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\"\n\nIn a post shared on X (formerly Twitter) on July 10, police said Clifford \"may be in possession of a crossbow\" and warned the public not to approach him.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said in a statement, \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\"\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately,\" Hall added. \"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. The BBC said the women killed were the family of its main radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder.\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 live said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Herfordshire Police said the incident involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Simpson said.\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women.\n\nClifford may still be armed and the public was warned not to {"uri": "8219067683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:28:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:28:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:27:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/bbc-commentators-wife-2-daughters-killed-in-crossbow-attack-in-london-manhunt-underway-6076345", "title": "BBC Commentator's Wife, 2 Daughters Killed In Crossbow Attack In London, Manhunt Underway", "body": "Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, is wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK. (Representational)\n\nLondon:\n\nUK police were searching Wednesday for a suspect who may have a crossbow after the wife and two daughters of a BBC radio racing commentator were killed in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, is wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nLocal police said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said armed officers and specialist search teams were involved in the manhunt, with the suspect believed to be in north London or around Bushey.\n\nSimpson also urged Clifford to contact police and warned the public not to approach the suspect.\n\nHe called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n'Shocking'\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nOne neighbour described hearing \"shrill\" screams from the home on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'\", she added.\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he was trying to kill Queen Elizabeth II.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", {"uri": "8219120702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:09:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:09:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:08:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13620805/Kyle-Clifford-dropped-army-failing-impress-superiors-just-scrapping-pass-attacking-BBC-stars.html", "title": "Triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford dropped out of the army", "body": "Follow MailOnline's Bushey manhunt live blog for the latest updates\n\nA man suspected of killing a BBC star's wife and two daughters is an army dropout who failed to impress his superiors, according to reports.\n\nTriple murder suspect Kyle Clifford is being hunted by police after Carol Hunt, and her daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nThe three women, who are the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, are thought to have been tied up and shot dead with a crossbow in a 'target attack' which police believe may have included 'other weapons'.\n\nNow it has been reported that Clifford, who is the ex-boyfriend of Louise, briefly served as a trooper - the equivalent to a private - in the Queen's Dragoon Guards.\n\nA picture has emerged showing the 26-year-old in his army gear holding a gun with a face covered in camouflage paint.\n\nKyle Clifford is being hunted by police after Carol Hunt, and her daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night\n\nA picture has emerged showing the 26-year-old in his army gear holding a gun with a face covered in camouflage paint\n\nDoorbell footage shows a man believed to be Clifford walking away from the house and towards a car (seen on the left of this grab)\n\nOne of his bosses, who saw Clifford join the Army in 2019 and went through Basic Training with him, said he dropped out after he joined the Household Cavalry Regiment.\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Kyle Clifford is CAUGHT after 'tying up BBC star's family and shooting them dead with crossbow'\n\nHe told The Sun: 'When he joined the Army he was immature for his age and had a bit of a chip on his shoulder.\n\n'He struggled to grasp basic military concepts but managed to reach the standard to pass out from training.\n\n\"After passing out he joined the Household Cavalry Regiment but I'm unsure how his career developed from there. I hear he was working in private security so would indicate that he is no longer in the military.'\n\nThe horror of the attack unfolded yesterday, with doorbell footage coming to light that allegedly shows Clifford striding away from the family home while carrying a large object underneath a white sheet shortly before 7pm.\n\nArmed police and paramedics were filmed this afternoon running into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt continued for Clifford, a former soldier and security guard.\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses today\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women, who police believe to be related, died last night\n\nLater, armed police closed down the cemetery, a five-minute walk from the house linked to the suspect. Up to four black-clad officers - two carrying automatic rifles - stood guard at the cemetery gates, preventing members of the public from entering.\n\nMeanwhile, an ambulance rushed into the cemetery grounds with blue lights flashing and sirens on. It re-emerged about 20 minute later, still in emergency mode.\n\nRead More BBC star John Hunt credits wife Carol for inspiring his career after spotting advert in paper\n\nTwo helicopters were also spotted hovering- one believed to be an air ambulance which landed in the cemetery grounds.\n\nEarlier, officers raided a house where Clifford is known to live, with dramatic footage from today showing officers storming the property.\n\nPolice have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park. Members of the public have been told to immediately call 999 if they see Clifford but not approach him, describing him as dangerous and potentially still armed.\n\nNearby schools have gone into precautionary lockdowns, with teachers at one primary telling parents to collect their children at the end of the day and take them directly home.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nPolice have launched a huge manhunt for Clifford\n\nDoorbell footage shows a man believed to be Clifford walking away from a house containing the dead bodies of his ex-girlfriend, her mother and her sister in Bushey yesterday evening. He is allegedly seen what appears to be the crossbow he allegedly used in the attack\n\nThe suspect is allegedly seen coming out of an alleyway and walking towards a car (seen on the left of this grab)\n\nThe man opens the car door and gets inside before driving off\n\nClifford's neighbours told today how police had put the road into lockdown as a house was searched by armed officers.\n\nRead More Revealed: Crossbow attack suspect's brother is convicted killer in row over 'prized' car\n\nThey spoke as two police helicopters hovered above the neighbourhood and two uniformed PCs stood guard at the door of the terraced home.\n\nOne local mother told how she arrived back from dropping her children off at school to find armed police at the house opposite hers.\n\n'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into,' she told MailOnline. 'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\n'They let me through to get home and they remained there for about an hour before they left. Then there was just the ordinary police there. 'I don't know the family at all. I know the father passed away some time ago but that's about it.'\n\nOne woman who lives across the road from the house said he had been working from home when she heard a commotion.\n\n'I was upstairs, when I heard cars honking and then looked out the window and realised that there were police there,' she said.\n\nPolice and paramedics run into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield during the hunt for Clifford\n\n'I came down and looked across. And they were saying ''armed police'' and then they went right in. There were dogs barking and everyone realised there was something big going on.'\n\nThe mother added: 'We've now been told that my daughter's school around the corner has gone into an amber lockdown. A few other schools have shut their doors as well. So we're just a little bit worried. I think everyone is really, really concerned.'\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X: 'No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n'Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.'\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place was swarming with armed police and forensic officers.\n\nOne neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered' today\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there were like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for Clifford continues\n\nTeams of armed police were seen searching Lavender Hill Cemetery this afternoon\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": They died at the scene.\n\nBritish police said on Wednesday they had located a man wanted in connection with the murder of three women, the wife and two daughters of a BBC horse racing commentator, in an incident believed to have involved a crossbow.\n\nOfficers had discovered the three victims, aged 25, 28, and 61, with serious injuries at the house in Bushey, a leafy town 20 miles northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. They had died at the scene a short time later.\n\nThe BBC said that the women were Carol Hunt, the wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nA huge search involving armed officers was launched for suspect, Kyle Clifford, with police warning the public not to approach the 26-year-old.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the local Major Crime Unit said in a statement.\n\nPolice said Clifford had been located in north London and was receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries. No shots were fired by police, the statement added.\n\nThe victims are yet to be formally identified but police said they believed Clifford was known to the three women.\n\nJon Simpson's statement\n\nEarlier on Wednesday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson called the incident \"horrific,\" telling reporters a crossbow and possibly other weapons were believed to have been involved.\n\nFriends and colleagues of Hunt expressed their shock at the news.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community,\" Cooper wrote on X Wednesday.\n\n\"I am being kept fully updated. {"uri": "2024-07-417879308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:16:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:16:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:12:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240710-uk-police-arrest-crossbow-attack-suspect-after-three-women-killed", "title": "UK police arrest crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "Bushey (United Kingdom) (AFP) - anUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n'Shocking'\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nOne neighbour described hearing \"shrill\" screams from the home on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house',\" she added.\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, is wanted following the deaths of the women in Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice were called to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushy just before 7pm. Officers and paramedics attended and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries. Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\n\nPolice have since been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nRead more:Contractor stole 20 laptops from hardworking Essex hospital staff at the height of Covid pandemic\n\nRead more:The Essex areas where 43,000 new homes could be built after initial plans thrown out\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nYou can report information online, speak to an operator in our Force Communications Room via our online web chat or call the non-emergency number 101, quoting \"Op Infauna\". {"uri": "8219953388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:14:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:14:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:14:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.shethepeople.tv/news/kyle-clifford-kills-three-women-with-crossbow-5997417", "title": "UK Police Arrests Man Suspected Of Killing BBC Journalist's Family", "body": "In a tragic incident, a British man killed three women after an alleged messy breakup. 26-year-old Kyle Clifford targetted three women and killed them using a crossbow. The deceased were the family members of BBC Racing radio commentator JohnHunt. 61-year-old Carol Hunt was his wife and Hannah, 28 and Louise, 25, were the couple's daughters. Reports suggest that Clifford was romantically involved Louise but they split up a week ago. The murder happened on July 9 in the house of Hunt family in Bushey, Hertfordshire, the UK.\n\nThe murder was termed shocking by police and the colleagues of John Hunt. The three women were murdered on their property and later were declared dead on the spot. Since then, the Hertfordshire police have been on an extensive manhunt and managed to trace down Clifford in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield on June 10. Clifford is believed to be a retired army officer after serving for a year.\n\nDetective inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time\"\n\nEarlier also the police suspected that Clifford was behind the crime. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said that the \"horrific\" attack was targeted and other than crossbow, more weapons might have been used.\n\nAfter Clifford was located, his body was injured even though police didn't fire any shots at him. So Clifford was sent to the hospital for treatment. After the treatment, he is supposed to go to a major trauma centre.\n\nThe police got several calls that were concerned about the three women. To keep the leads about the case private, the police urged anyone with any evidence to directly reach the police rather than posting on social media. Not only this, the police had set up an information portal where anyone with any lead can submit their evidence.\n\nOn investing, it was revealed that Louise was utterly disturbed by the breakup. She once rammed her car into a telegraph pole. Carol, Louise's mother has confided in a friend about her daughter's tumultuous breakup. Speaking BBC, Carol's friend said, \" She mentioned that her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol didn't go into specifics, but you could tell she was worried.\"\n\nLoise was a dog groomer and Hannah was a beautician. According to neighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, who has been living near Hunt's property for 50 years Hunt family was good and respected their privacy.\n\nHe told the media portal, \"They were a private family, all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed. A very close-knit family and they used to love the street.\"\n\nLouise's friend said that she was \"always a positive person.\" He could not think of anything bad about her.\n\nMoreover, John Hunt's colleagues have also lamented Hunt's tragedy. BBC Radio 5 Live has said that it will provide every support to the family. It also sent a note to John Hunt saying that the murder was devastating.\n\nUK's Interior Minister Yvette Cooper also said that the murder was \"truly shocking\" She took to X and wrote, \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. three women killed", "body": "LONDON: United Kingdom police said on Wednesday (Jul 10) that a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries\", police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be {"uri": "8220581476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:46:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:46:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T13:45:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/crossbow-suspects-terrifying-brush-neighbour-33219318", "title": "Crossbow suspect's terrifying brush with neighbour and how he concealed 'weapon'", "body": "A major manhunt to find Kyle Clifford was sparked after three women were found fatally injured at their home in Hertfordshire.\n\nThe 26-year-old, from Enfield, north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of BBC racing commentator John Hunt's wife, Carol, 61, and their two daughters, Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, who are believed to have been 'targeted' and attacked with a crossbow.\n\nPolice and emergency services, including two air ambulances, were called to the scene of horror on Tuesday around 7pm, where despite best efforts to save the women, the trio tragically died at the family home located in Ashlyn Close, Bushey.\n\nArmed police went from house to house to question locals and request doorbell camera footage as they worked to locate the suspect - who was later found injured in a cemetery just a short walk from his home.\n\nBefore he was eventually located 24 hours later, chilling footage emerged that appeared to show the former security guard flee the quiet cul-de-sac, armed with a 3ft crossbow. In the clip, a bearded man is seen emerging from an alleyway that leads to the property where the family lived.\n\nThe man, dressed in a black tracksuit, is captured pacing towards a vehicle armed with a large object underneath his right arm, thought to be a crossbow, covered in a white cloth. He was also filmed carrying a black sports bag that police fear could contain even more weapons, before climbing into a black seat of the vehicle to place them there.\n\nBut as the footage showed him pacing through the estate, he brushed past a neighbour who was standing just feet away. She bent down to stroke a black cat, while another resident stepped out of the same property. The black vehicle the suspect was seen driving off in was then found abandoned in Enfield.\n\nHorrific details from the attack emerged yesterday, with one of the three victims believed to have called 999 in a brave act before the perpetrator fled the scene, The Guardian reports. The paper also claims that one of the women sent a text to their partner urging them to call the police.\n\nThe mum, who shares a third daughter with John who lives in Birmingham, was reportedly found in the hallway of their home with a crossbow bolt in her chest. Previous reports suggested the alleged killer tied up his victims but a source told the Guardian that the women were not gagged and bound when found.\n\nHowever there was reportedly evidence of ligature marks around their wrists and face, suggesting these had been removed. The source also said all three had injuries to their knees.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday lunchtime, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, of Hertfordshire Police, said the attack was a \"targeted incident\" and Clifford was \"wanted in connection with murder\". He said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nAfter police located Clifford's car, their search efforts then shifted to a nearby cemetery close to Rendlesham Road - a five-minute walk from Clifford's address. By Wednesday evening, the manhunt finally came to a close after he was found hiding among headstones.\n\nA swarm of armed police closed in at the site, with paramedics then seen rushing into the grounds with an air ambulance circling overhead. The BBC reported that the air \"is thick with the sound of helicopters\" operated by police and press.\n\nLocal Rae Cresswell, 26, who filmed the commotion, said: \"I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them. I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.\"\n\nAfter around 20 minutes, Clifford was seen stretchered away from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he is receiving medical treatment after being discovered with injuries. Clifford had reportedly been hiding from police in a nearby church, according to one local, Adam, who claimed: \"He was hiding there all day and then came here. He was well known here, and was actually expelled from school for carrying a knife.\"\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\nA London Ambulance Spokesperson said: \"Ambulance crews and London's air ambulance attended an incident in Lavender Hill Cemetery, Enfield, this afternoon (Tuesday 10). Carol Hunt, Hannah Hunt and Louise Hunt, aged 61, 28 and 25 respectively, died following the attack in Ashlyn Close yesterday evening (Tuesday, July 9).\n\nThey are reportedly the wife and two daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt. The Telegraph reports that he'd been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home at around 7pm, reports My London.\n\nA tribute to Louise Hunt on social media reads: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news.\"\n\n\"You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx\"\n\nLouise launched dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business.\n\nHertfordshire Police has launched a manhunt for Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield who is wanted in connection with the incident. Officers say he is potentially still armed with a crossbow.\n\nIn a press conference this afternoon Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\"\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.
