before climbing into a black Seat.\n\nThe same car is understood to have been found abandoned earlier today - leading cops to Enfield where armed officers were searching for the suspect.\n\nA source said: \"You can see clearly from the outline of what is under the sheet that it is in the shape of a crossbow - but it's massive.\n\n\"When we first heard the weapon was involved no-one thought it might be that big - it makes you wonder where he got it from.\n\n\"The way he is walking is with clear intent - he is moving to get to his car as fast as he can while still walking.\n\n\"He was clearly carrying plenty of equipment but if you were on the street you would never assume it was a deadly weapon.\"\n\nWhat we know so far...\n\nA full-size crossbow could shoot bolts accurately up to 250ft - raising the terrifying prospect victims may not even see their shooter before being hit.\n\nIn the clip - the man believed to be Kyle Clifford - climbs into the black car and waits for 18 seconds before driving away West-bound on Bushey Grove Road towards.\n\nThe road is directly connected to the murder scene on Ashlyn Close by a pedestrian footpath.\n\nThe black Seat from the footage is believed to form part of the ongoing investigation.\n\nHertfordshire Police said: \"A vehicle has been located and is being investigated.\"\n\nA spokeswoman added: \"We cannot comment any further at this time.\"\n\nThe three women are the wife and two daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, the broadcaster confirmed this afternoon.\n\nThey have been identified as John's 61-year-old wife Carol and their daughter Hannah and Louise.\n\nJohn had been working at Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey yesterday before returning home in the evening to discover the horror that had unfolded, it is understood.\n\nMailOnline reports Clifford was the ex-boyfriend of one of Hunt's daughters.\n\nDramatic footage obtained exclusively by The Sun this afternoon showed cops storming a home in the hunt for the suspect.\n\nTwo helicopters were spotted circling the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, North London, as armed police stormed a home.\n\nOne officer can be heard screaming: \"Armed Police, come to the door and raise your hands\" as cops barrage through the front of the property.\n\nIt is unclear who or what cops discovered in the home but at least two officers are still at the scene of the raid.\n\nA source said: \"It's a really heavy response -- and shocking for everyone to see.\n\n\"They charged in and spent quite a while in the home. It didn't seem like anyone was there\".\n\nIn a press conference at 12.30pm Hertfordshire Police said they were still hunting for the suspect.\n\nThe force confirmed Clifford, who is from Enfield in North London, may still be armed and urged anyone who sees him to call 999 immediately.\n\nThey also said it is believed he may be in possession of a crossbow and may have used other weapons in the \"targeted\" attack.\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nAppealing directly to Clifford today, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact with police via 999.\"\n\nHerts Police have told anyone who was in Ashlyn Close from lunchtime yesterday to come forward to call 101 quoting Op Infauna.\n\nDSI Rob Hall said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nEnfield Council said: \"You will be aware of the news of the suspect Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area, wanted in relation to a triple murder in Bushey.\n\n\"We have been advised by the Police that there is no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal.\n\n\"Local schools have been advised that end of day school procedures should continue as per normal.\n\n\"There will be an enhanced police presence in the area and around some schools to provide reassurance to pupils and parents.\"\n\nIt comes after horrified neighbours told of hearing screams last night.\n\nFrancis Turner told The Sun: \"My husband and I were watching the football when we heard sirens and shouting. There were around 30 policemen outside.\n\n\"There were armed police. They came and knocked on our door and told us to stay inside and keep our doors shut.\n\n\"My heart goes out to them. I feel very sad for the family, my heart goes out to them.\"\n\nOne neighbour, who didn't want to be named, said they heard screaming before \"at least 16 police cars\" swooped on the scene.\n\nThey added: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nAnother local Dereck Turner, who took a photo of armed cops outside, said: \"It's a very quiet and peaceful area, it's close to everything, when a house comes up it's gone.\"\n\nShocked neighbours said Louise ran a dog grooming business called Groom and Glow from the detached house in a cul-de-sac.\n\nLocal resident William Nourallah paid tribute to the \"beautiful young girl\".\n\nHe said: \"She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl.\n\n\"I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father\n\n\"She was happy every time I saw her. The victims were found in their Bushey home with fatal injuries. Armed officers are searching for suspect Kyle Clifford. Authorities have urged the public to avoid him.\n\nBritish police launched a massive manhunt on Wednesday after the wife and daughters of BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt were killed in Bushey, a town outside London, in a suspected crossbow attack.\n\nOfficers discovered the three victims, aged 25, 28, and 61, with serious injuries at their residence on Tuesday evening. They died at the scene shortly afterward. The BBC identified the women as Carol Hunt, John's wife, and their two daughters.\n\nA huge search involving armed officers has now been launched for the suspect, 26-year-old Kyle Clifford. Police have appealed to Clifford to surrender and warned the public not to approach him. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson described the incident as 'horrific,' noting that a crossbow and possibly other weapons were involved.\n\n'Our primary objective today is to protect public safety and locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident,' Simpson said. They had died at the scene a short time later.\n\nThe BBC said that the women were Carol Hunt, the wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nA huge search involving armed officers was launched for suspect, Kyle Clifford, with police warning the public not to approach the 26-year-old.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time,\" Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the local Major Crime Unit said in a statement.\n\nPolice said Clifford had been located in north London and was receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries. No shots were fired by police, the statement added.\n\nThe victims are yet to be formally identified but police said they believed Clifford was known to the three women.\n\nEarlier on Wednesday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson called the incident \"horrific\", telling reporters a crossbow and possibly other weapons were believed to have been involved.\n\nFriends and colleagues of Hunt expressed their shock at the news.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. {"uri": "8219236720", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:46:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:46:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:44:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/suspect-located-triple-crossbow-killings-172553133.html", "title": "Suspect found with injuries after triple crossbow killings in Bushey", "body": "A British Army veteran wanted in connection with the murder of three women in a suspected crossbow attack has been captured after being found with injuries, police have said.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, who is understood to have served in the British army for about a year, was named as a suspect by Hertfordshire police after the deaths of Carol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters, Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, at a property in Bushey.\n\nCh Supt Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire police told reporters earlier on Wednesday the suspected murders were believed to be targeted.\n\nLater on Wednesday, a statement from Hertfordshire police said Clifford had been found in north London and received medical treatment for injuries. Police emphasised no shots were fired.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service confirmed a man was treated at Lavender Hill Cemetery before being transported to a \"major trauma centre\", which could be one of four hospitals in the capital.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, there was a significant number of police officers at the cemetery, 16 miles from the crime scene and near a property that was searched earlier in the day as part of the manhunt.\n\nParamedics and ambulances were also at the location. Footage captured from a helicopter showed a man being stretchered out of the cemetery.\n\nPolice believe the suspect was known to the victims and no one else is being sought in connection with the investigation.\n\nSources said that Carol Hunt was found in the hallway of the house with a crossbow bolt in her chest, while evidence of ligatures were found near the victims. One of the victims is understood to have texted her partner, urging them to call the police.\n\nClifford is believed to have served in the British army for a year, sources have said. The Ministry of Defence has been contacted for comment.\n\nThe women are understood to be the family of the BBC's racing radio commentator, John Hunt. As part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation described the incident as \"utterly devastating\".\n\nThe Hunts have another daughter, Amy, who is thought to live in Birmingham.\n\nPolice said a crossbow or other weapons may have been used in the attacks, and they are investigating what relationship any of the victims may have had to Clifford.\n\nThe home secretary, Yvette Cooper, is urgently considering the findings of a Home Office review launched in 2021 to see if tougher crossbow laws need to be introduced.\n\nA source said the victims were not gagged and bound when found, but there were ligature marks around their wrists and face, suggesting they had been and that these were removed. The source added that all of the victims had injuries to their knees.\n\nThe Guardian understands that one of the victims called 999 and alerted the police to the incident before the perpetrator fled.\n\nDetectives have appealed for information or video footage and asked the public to report anything suspicious they saw in Ashlyn Close from midday on Tuesday, about seven hours before they found the women.\n\nOne source said the women may have been held hostage for hours before police were called.\n\nOn Wednesday morning armed police raided a property not far from the cemetery in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, which is understood to have been linked to Clifford's brother, Bradley, who was jailed for life in 2018 for murder.\n\nSchools in Enfield were placed in lockdown.\n\nDI Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire major crime unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\"\n\nShe added: \"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us.\"\n\nCooper, said she is being kept fully updated on the inquiry into the \"truly shocking\" deaths.\n\nA Home Office spokesperson said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The home secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8219049927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:15:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:15:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:15:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-hunt-carol-louise-hannah-bushey-crossbow-160749200.html", "title": "Who are the family of John Hunt killed in Bushey crossbow attack?", "body": "The wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator have been named as the victims of a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nThe wife and two daughters of a BBC sports commentator have been named as the victims of a crossbow attack at their home.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters, Hannah and Louise, were killed in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, on Tuesday evening. The BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two of their daughters had died in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nA massive manhunt has been launched for their suspected killer, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London. Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters on Wednesday that the murders are believed to be \"targeted\" and the force warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nMr Hunt, a 58-year-old former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last two decades. He was married to Mrs Hunt and had three children, including Hannah and Louise.\n\nMrs Hunt and her two daughters Hannah and Louise were found fatally injured at their home just after 7pm on Tuesday. Officers and emergency medical crews, including two air ambulances, were sent to try to save the women, but they all died at the scene.\n\nHannah appeared in her social media profile to be a beauty and skin therapist who managed her own business, Hannah Grace Aesthetics, in Bushey.\n\nAccording to her social media, Louise had started her own dog grooming business called Groom and Glow in 2020.\n\nA friend of Louise paid tribute to her and her family online, MyLondon reported, adding: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news.\n\n\"You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the Mr Hunt's employer BBC described the incident as \"utterly devastating\".\n\nThe note added: \"Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were also posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in an entry on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nClick below to see the latest London headlines\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\nThe force said it is looking at whether the force had contact with the victims or Clifford before the {"uri": "8219194634", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:08:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://kuwaittimes.com/article/16502/top-stories/suspected-crossbow-attacker-murders-bbc-journalists-family/", "title": "Suspected crossbow attacker murders BBC journalist's family", "body": "BUSHEY, United Kingdom: UK police were searching Wednesday for a suspect who may have a crossbow after the wife and two daughters of a BBC radio racing commentator were killed in a suspected \"targeted\" attack. Kyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, is wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said. Local police said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson said armed officers and specialist search teams were involved in the manhunt, with the suspect believed to be in north London or around Bushey. Simpson also urged Clifford to contact police and warned the public not to approach the suspect. He called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search. There is no license required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse. Interior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\". She said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n'Shocking'\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\". Sky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\". One neighbor described hearing \"shrill\" screams from the home on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown. \"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'\", she added. Another neighbor told reporters the victims were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area. Last October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow. following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show the suspect wearing black and carrying a large item under his right arm as he walked near the scene.\n\nHe is then seen to place the item into a black car, getting in the vehicle and pausing for a moment before driving away.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn suspect after three women killed | News24", "body": "No formal arrests have been made, and police are not seeking additional suspects.\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nREAD | Manhunt underway after 3 women killed in London crossbow attack\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokesperson for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n'Shocking'\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nread more UK police hunt crossbow attack suspect after three women killed Night watchman found dead in Paris hotel after robbery bid 8 arrested after gruesome murder of Indian politician Passenger bus collides with tanker on expressway in India: 18 dead, several injured\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\nShocking\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he was trying to kill with police helicopters swooping over parts in Enfield.\n\nArmed police then swarmed Hilly Fields and Clifford was found injured.\n\nDespite speculation online, police say no shots were fired.\n\nAccording to Hertfordshire Constabulary in a new update, Clifford has been unable to speak with officers yet due to his serious condition - The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. killings of Carol Hunt and her two daughters in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nPolice have said 26-year-old suspect Kyle Clifford, who is understood to have left the British Army in 2022 following a short period of service, is believed to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a home in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, on Wednesday morning as the hunt for Clifford continued.\n\nHe is wanted over the deaths of Mrs Hunt and two of her daughters who were aged 25 and 28 when they were killed in Ashlyn Close on Tuesday.\n\nEnfield Council said it had been advised by the police that there is \"no perceived threat to the public so the guidance is to carry on as normal\".\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who \"may be in possession of a crossbow\".\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, Mr Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, told the PA news agency pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nParents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nIn a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff after the deaths, the It didn't seem like anyone was there\".\n\nResidents claimed they've been told a \"coordinated search\" is underway in the area and local primary schools have been urged to keep children inside.\n\nNearby St Michael's Primary School has been put under lockdown after the triple murder.\n\nA \"car of possible interest\" has also been located at the Hilly Fields scene.\n\nIt is understood cops have found Clifford's vehicle, a black Seat hatchback.\n\nThe manhunt suspect is believed to have driven from the scene was found abandoned earlier.\n\nWhat we know so far...\n\nHertfordshire Constabulary have warned the public \"not to approach\" suspect Clifford, 26, as their specialist search continues.\n\nIt comes after three women were discovered seriously injured at a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire, yesterday evening.\n\nThe victims, aged 25, 28 and 61-years-old, sadly could not be saved despite the best efforts of paramedics.\n\nThe women are said to be the family of a BBC star, as reported by the Telegraph.\n\nIt is understood the three women were related to John Hunt, a BBC Five Live racing commentator.\n\nOne of the victims has been named locally as Carol Hunt, 61, and her daughter Hannah.\n\nMeanwhile, the MailOnline reported Clifford was the ex-boyfriend of one of Hunt's daughters.\n\nIn their latest update, Superintendent Jon Simpson confirmed the force believe the horror was \"a targeted incident\" involving \"what is believed to be a crossbow but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\n\"If any members of the public see Kyle Clifford they are urged not to approach him at any point and dial 999 immediately,\" urged the Supt.\n\nHe also issued a personal message to Clifford, and urged the suspect to contact police.\n\n\"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact with police via 999,\" he said.\n\nClifford, from Enfield in North London, may still be in possession of a crossbow, police warned earlier.\n\nThe force urged anyone who sees him to call 999 immediately.\n\nOne horrified local told how armed cops swarmed the quiet residential street last night.\n\nFrancis Turner, who was watching the Spain v France game at the time, told how she heard shouting outside.\n\nShe told The Sun: \"My husband and I were watching the football when we heard sirens and shouting. There were around 30 policemen outside.\n\n\"There were armed police. They came and knocked on our door and told us to stay inside and keep our doors shut.\n\n\"My heart goes out to them. I feel very sad for the family, my heart goes out to them.\"\n\nAnother local Dereck Turner, who took a photo of armed police outside, said: \"It's a very quiet and peaceful area, it's close to everything, when a house comes up it's gone.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Simon Powler, 49, a tennis coach who lives nearby to the scene in Bushey, added: \"I got told to go inside because a man might be on the loose with a crossbow.\"\n\nOther stunned residents told how more than a dozen emergency vehicles were scrambled to the quiet residential street last night.\n\nOne person said: \"It's on my road Ashlyn Close It's cordoned off. There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n\"We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.\"\n\nAnother resident said there was a \"huge police presence\" in the area.\n\nSomeone else who lives in Ashlyn Close said they heard screaming as the \"absolutely traumatic\" horror unfolded.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who did not wish to share their name, said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\n\"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help,\" she added.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nEast of England Ambulance Service confirmed three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team and two air ambulances were sent to the scene.\n\nLouise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards, who are local councillors for the area, paid tribute to the women.\n\nThey said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry murder victim pay tribute to 'fantastic...", "body": "Colleagues of the daughter of a BBC racing commentator have paid tribute to the \"fantastic therapist\", after she was murdered with a crossbow alongside her mother and sister.\n\nSuspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is in hospital after being found injured during Wednesday's manhunt for the alleged killer.\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, the daughter of BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, was killed alongside her mother Carol Hunt, 61, and sister Louise, 25 during an incident in the quiet cul-de-sac of Ashlyn Close, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nOn Thursday, further searches took place at a house linked to Clifford's brother, Bradley Clifford, who was jailed for life with a minimum term of 23 years for the murder of moped passenger Soban Khan in 2018.\n\nFloral tributes near the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire (Jonathan Brady/PA)\n\nAccording to the Metropolitan Police, at the time of the murder, Bradley Clifford had targeted the moped before crashing into it, and continued to assault Mr Khan after the collision.\n\nOfficers were seen at the address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, north London, in relation to the deaths.\n\nPolice staff wearing gloves and face masks were seen outside the property, which was first searched on Wednesday.\n\nIn a post on Facebook, Hannah Hunt's colleagues at The Anti-Ageing Clinic in Radlett, Hertfordshire, said it was with \"deep regret and sadness\" that they learned of the \"horrific murder on Tuesday night of our skin therapist Hannah\".\n\nThe post continued: \"She was a fantastic therapist and clients loved her.\n\n\"We send our condolences and prayers to her Dad, sister and family.\n\n\"She was very much a part of our team. Please bear with us at this terrible time.\"\n\nA message attached to a floral tribute left near the scene in Ashlyn Close (Jonathan Brady/PA)\n\nFlowers were left at the scene in Ashlyn Close on Thursday, with notes attached to some bouquets with messages such as \"rest in peace\".\n\nClifford was found injured in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, north London, on Wednesday and was taken to a major trauma centre for treatment.\n\nPolice said no shots had been fired by officers and no arrest had yet been made.\n\nFootage from Sky News appeared to show Clifford being stretchered out of the cemetery by paramedics.\n\nArmed police had earlier been in the area, with an air ambulance nearby.\n\nNeighbours recalled hearing screaming on Tuesday, as the \"traumatic\" incident unfolded.\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was found, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, from Hertfordshire Police, told reporters the killings were believed to have been \"targeted\".\n\nPolice vehicles at the scene in Ashlyn Close, Bushey (Jonathan Brady/PA)\n\nDuring the hunt for Clifford, who is understood to have left the Army in 2022 after a short stint, the force said they believed he may have been armed with a crossbow and warned people not to approach him.\n\nHe was believed to have been known to the victims.\n\nRadio 5 Live presenter Mark Chapman paid an emotional tribute at the start of the Euro 2024 pre-match show.\n\nSpeaking through tears, he said: \"This has been a heart-breaking day.\n\n\"John Hunt is our colleague and our friend, not just to the current 5 Live sport team but to all of those who have worked here with him over the past 20 years and also to all of you who have enjoyed his superb commentaries.\n\n\"On behalf of everybody connected to 5 Live sport, our love and thoughts and support are with John and his family.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is urgently considering whether tougher crossbow laws are needed in the wake of the killings.\n\nShe will look at the findings of a Home Office review carried out earlier this year.\n\nA Home Office spokeswoman said: \"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"", "source": "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/uk-police-detain-crossbow-attack-suspect-after-three-women-killed/article_40dad172-2c02-5bd9-82a1-fd40c6d853cf.html", "title": "UK police detain crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "The three women were killed on Tuesday night in Bushey, near Watford, north of London\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n- 'Shocking' -\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he sister.\n\nSuspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is in hospital after being found injured during Wednesday's manhunt for the alleged killer.\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, the daughter of BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, was killed alongside her mother Carol Hunt, 61, and sister Louise, 25 during an incident in the quiet cul-de-sac of Ashlyn Close, in Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nOn Thursday, further searches took place at a house linked to Clifford's brother, Bradley Clifford, who was jailed for life with a minimum term of 23 years for the murder of moped passenger Soban Khan in 2018.\n\nAccording to the Metropolitan Police, at the time of the murder, Bradley Clifford had targeted the moped before crashing into it, and continued to assault Mr Khan after the collision.\n\nOfficers were seen at the address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, north London, in relation to the deaths.\n\nPolice staff wearing gloves and face masks were seen outside the property, which was first searched on Wednesday.\n\nIn a post on Facebook, Hannah Hunt's colleagues at The Anti-Ageing Clinic in Radlett, Hertfordshire, said it was with \"deep regret and sadness\" that they learned of the \"horrific murder on Tuesday night of our skin therapist Hannah\".\n\nThe post continued: \"She was a fantastic therapist and clients loved her.\n\n\"We send our condolences and prayers to her Dad, sister and family.\n\n\"She was very much a part of our team. Please bear with us at this terrible time.\"\n\nFlowers were left at the scene in Ashlyn Close on Thursday, with notes attached to some bouquets with messages such as \"rest in peace\".\n\nClifford was found injured in Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, north London, on Wednesday and was taken to a major trauma centre for treatment.\n\nPolice said no shots had been fired by officers and no arrest had yet been made.\n\nFootage from Sky News appeared to show Clifford being stretchered out of the cemetery by paramedics.\n\nArmed police had earlier been in the area, with an air ambulance nearby.\n\nNeighbours recalled hearing screaming on Tuesday, as the \"traumatic\" incident unfolded.\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was found, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, from {"uri": "8218834386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:54:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.parikiaki.com/2024/07/enfield-man-wanted-in-connection-with-triple-murder-in-bushey/", "title": "Enfield Man wanted in connection with triple murder in Bushey", "body": "Detectives investigating a triple murder which occurred in Bushey yesterday evening (Tuesday 9 July) are actively seeking a man who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nDetectives investigating a triple murder which occurred in Bushey yesterday evening (Tuesday 9 July) are actively seeking a man who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nPolice were called to a property in Ashlyn Close just before 7pm. Officers attended alongside colleagues from the East of England Ambulance Service and on arrival, found three women with serious injuries. Sadly, despite their best efforts, the women, who are believed to be related, died a short time later at the scene.\n\nPolice have since been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nYou can report information online, speak to an operator in our Force
