Thank you for following our coverage.\n\nHere is a summary of today's events:\n\nA manhunt was launched this morning for Kyle Clifford, 26, after three women were killed in a crossbow attack at their home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, and her daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were pronounced dead at the scene\n\nThe victims were the wife and two daughters of the BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt\n\nThe Ministry of Defence confirmed Clifford had served in the Armed Forces\n\nA Home Office spokesman said the Home Secretary is urgently considering the findings of a review to see if tougher crossbow laws need to be introduced in the wake of the attack\n\nPolice searched an address in Enfield as the hunt for Clifford continued, with the Met working alongside Hertfordshire Constabulary\n\nArmed police and paramedics were seen rushing into Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield\n\nPolice confirmed they had found Clifford and that he was receiving medical treatment but said no shots had been fired\n\nThe force said they believe Clifford was known to the victims and that the murders were 'targeted'\n\nFriends and neighbours paid tribute to the victims as flowers were laid near Ashlyn Close in Bushey, with the local community 'completely in shock'\n\n08:23 PM BST\n\nMap: Where events unfolded in North London\n\n07:58 PM BST\n\n'Pretty quiet' local community 'completely in shock'\n\nA friend of Louise Hunt, who lives in Bushey, has said the usually \"pretty quiet\" local community is \"completely in shock\" at the triple murder.\n\nHe told BBC News: \"I've lived in Bushey pretty much my whole life, only a couple of roads away, and it is generally a pretty quiet community.\n\n\"We certainly don't hear about any kind of violence of this magnitude.\n\n\"A lot of working professionals, families, and everyone gets on with their day - so it's a pretty quiet community, and completely in shock tonight.\"\n\nThe friend also described Louise as \"always a positive person\" and that he could not think of \"anything bad to say about her\".\n\nHe added: \"I couldn't believe what had happened at first. I'd heard the news from my sister early in the morning before I'd figured out who the victims were and, once I found out, it's been a massive shock, (I've) been in denial.\n\n\"I haven't processed it yet and I feel also angry towards the murder and I can't even begin to imagine what the father's going through - so, mixture of emotions - angry, sad and in shock.\"\n\n07:49 PM BST\n\nPictured: Forensics officers at work in Lavender Hill cemetery\n\n07:35 PM BST\n\nAmbulance service took man to major trauma centre\n\nA London Ambulance spokesman said ambulance crews and the air ambulance attended an incident in Lavender Hill cemetery this afternoon.\n\nThey said a man was treated at the scene and later taken to a major trauma centre.\n\n07:28 PM BST\n\nPictured: Tributes and messages for victims laid in Bushey\n\n07:17 PM BST\n\nPolice believe suspect known to victims\n\nPolice said they believe triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford was known to the victims.\n\nHertfordshire Police confirmed Clifford is receiving medical treatment and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was located, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\n07:08 PM BST\n\nFriend of victims pays tribute to 'beautiful souls'\n\nA friend of the women who were killed in Bushey has remembered them as \"beautiful souls\".\n\nSu Kehinde, 60, who lives nearby, spoke after laying some flowers at a makeshift tribute at the end of the police cordon.\n\nMs Kehinde said: \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They were the meekest human beings. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.\"\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah Hunt \"always had a smile\", adding: \"She was hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle.\"\n\n06:55 PM BST\n\nWatch: Man believed to be Kyle Clifford stretchered away\n\n06:42 PM BST\n\nPolice statement after suspected crossbow killer found\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe force also said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\n06:17 PM BST\n\nLocal resident describes moment police swept into Enfield cemetery\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local resident who filmed police sweeping into Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield earlier, said: \"I saw about 10 officers coming in, it was around 3pm I'd say. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\"\n\nHe added: \"I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.\"\n\n05:57 PM BST\n\nBushey residents invited to offer prayers and candles for victims\n\nIn a post on Facebook, the Parish of Bushey invited people to offer prayers and light candles at two churches in Bushey after expressing \"deep sadness\" as the \"people of Bushey mourn the tragic loss of three members of our community\".\n\nThey wrote: \"This has made the national news and attention will be focused on where we live. Both the Parish Church of St James on the High Street of Bushey and St Pauls on Bushey Hall Road are open for people to offer prayers and light a candle for those who have died, the family of the victims and those helping with this terrible crime. We also remember the perpetrator who committed this act, that he may come forward to the police.\"\n\n05:43 PM BST\n\nWatch: Armed police raid at an address in Enfield\n\n05:41 PM BST\n\nNeighbour describes 'very close-knit' Hunt family\n\nGlyn Nicholas, 77, retired, who has lived on the same road as the victims for 50 years said: \"I know one of the daughters because she's our dog groomer. All our daughters had their dogs groomed with Louise. She knew my wife, but the other daughter I didn't know at all.\"\n\nHe added: \"They were a private family, all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\n\"They used to have a dog themselves and they used to be out and about walking their dog. I'd just say hello, never stopped and talked.\n\n\"A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. With his job they probably could have found a more salubrious house but they'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years. They had a groomer's hut built for the dogs in the garden. I believe they had another daughter who lives away.\n\nHe said that the girls \"were quite young when they came here - they were just young girls when they came here so they've probably been nearer 20 years here\".\n\n05:29 PM BST\n\nSuspected crossbow killer Kyle Clifford's brother is serving life for murder\n\nThe man being hunted by police on suspicion of a triple crossbow murder has a brother who is serving life in prison for beating a man to death, The Telegraph can disclose.\n\nSix years ago, Clifford's older brother, Bradley, was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey.\n\nBradley Clifford, a plumber, was 23 when he chased and deliberately mowed down Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, on their moped after they struck his prized Ford Mustang car with a bottle.\n\nThe Telegraph's Crime Editor, Martin Evans, has the full story here.\n\n05:20 PM BST\n\nPictured: Armed police search Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield\n\n05:15 PM BST\n\nForensics van arrives at cemetery\n\nA Metropolitan Police forensics van has just pulled up at the entrance to Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield, the focus of the search for suspected crossbow killer Kyle Clifford.\n\nMeanwhile, the air ambulance has just taken off.\n\nAlthough shielded from view by a thick evergreen hedge, the cemetery is just yards from the residential housing on Cedar Road, which runs adjacent.\n\nThe cemetery is on the northern edge of London, between central Enfield and the M25 motorway.\n\n05:09 PM BST\n\nWatch: Police and paramedics rush into Enfield cemetery\n\nIn footage from LBC posted on X, dozens of paramedics and police can be seen racing into the cemetery in Hilly Fields, Enfield where the search has been centred.\n\n04:31 PM BST\n\nPictured: Armed police hunt for Kyle Clifford at Enfield allotment\n\n04:27 PM BST\n\nMet assisting Hertfordshire police in hunt for Kyle Clifford\n\nThe Metropolitan Police have confirmed they are assisting their colleagues in Hertfordshire with the search for Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the triple crossbow murder in Bushey.\n\nA Hertfordshire Constabulary spokesman said: \"Whilst we are asking the public to remain vigilant, people should go about their business as normal at this time. At this stage there is no explicit wider threat to members of the public and no children have been involved.\"\n\n04:14 PM BST\n\nPictured: Residents around Ashlyn Close lay flowers by police cordon\n\n04:09 PM BST\n\nBHA chief says sport will rally around John Hunt in time of 'unimaginable grief'\n\nJulie Harrington, the chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority has shared a message of condolence for John Hunt, who she describes as a \"great friend of many in our sport\".\n\nIn a statement, she said: \"The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends at this shocking and tragic time. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n\"John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have seen many times before when one of our number is faced with great trauma.\"\n\n03:55 PM BST\n\nHome Secretary urgently considering if tougher crossbow laws needed\n\nThe Home Secretary is urgently considering the findings of a Home Office review to see if tougher crossbow laws need to be introduced in the wake of the deaths of the wife and two daughters of racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nA department spokesman said: \"This is an appalling incident and the Home Secretary is being kept updated by the police.\n\n\"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\n03:52 PM BST\n\nPictured: Victims of triple crossbow murder\n\n03:42 PM BST\n\nHeadteacher of Enfield primary school says children under 'lighter lockdown'\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for a triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, said pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nBut parents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nShe said \"We've locked both buildings and just kept the children inside. So we've not had them on the field or the playground. It's not a lockdown as in under the desks or hidden or anything, it's just a lighter lockdown.\n\n\"We have just kept them within the building as though it were like a wet playday so we don't cause the children any distress and we keep everything as calm as possible.\"\n\nMrs Bacon said the police carried out a \"reassurance visit\" to the primary school on Wednesday.\n\n03:18 PM BST\n\nMoD confirms suspect served in Armed Forces\n\nThe Ministry of Defence confirmed on Wednesday that the man wanted in connection with the triple murder in Bushey had served briefly in the Armed Forces.\n\nA Whitehall source said: \"He didn't serve very long and he is no longer a serving member of the armed forces. We're not going to speculate which regiment or unit he was in, but look at his age. He didn't serve very long.\"\n\n03:14 PM BST\n\nWatch: Police launch manhunt for Kyle Clifford after three women found murdered\n\n03:08 PM BST\n\nNeighbour describes murder victim's upset at recent breakup\n\nA near neighbour of the murdered women said Louise Hunt had been left so upset by a recent break up with her boyfriend she had crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nGlyn Nicholas, 77, suggested that Louise had been in a relationship with the man now wanted in connection with the murders of the three women and that the relationship had ended badly.\n\nHe said: \"Louise split up with her boyfriend a few days ago and she crashed her car into a telegraph pole because she was so upset coming home. She's a lovely, caring girl. She runs a dog grooming business in Bushey.\n\n\"Her sister Hannah and mother Carol are lovely as well. It's all so sad. Louise was a sweet, lovely girl. They all were. This is so sad for everyone,\" he said.\n\n02:58 PM BST\n\nPictured: John and Carol Hunt\n\n02:56 PM BST\n\nBBC note to staff describes incident as 'utterly devastating'\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation described the incident which involved the deaths of the wife and daughters of racing commentator John Hunt as \"utterly devastating\".\n\nThe note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\n02:48 PM BST\n\nPrevious government had considered tougher crossbow laws\n\nKillings involving a crossbow are typically rare but ministers had considered tightening laws in a bid to stop the weapons being used in violent attacks.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nThe previous government looked at bringing in firearms licensing-style rules in the wake of an attempt to kill the late Queen with a crossbow.\n\nWould-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nPlans for crossbow owners to face police checks were mooted as part of efforts to \"step up action to prevent violence on our streets\", the Home Office said earlier this year.\n\nThe department launched an eight-week consultation in February to see if there should be a licensing system to control the use, ownership and supply of crossbows, with anyone looking to buy one facing police checks - similar to regulations already in place for firearms.\n\n02:37 PM BST\n\nFigures from racing world share condolences\n\nMessages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in a post on X: \"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\n02:00 PM BST\n\nPolice search address in Enfield\n\nArmed police have searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continues.\n\nThe house, close to Gordon Hill railway station, was swarmed by officers on Wednesday morning, according to neighbours.\n\nTwo officers stood guard outside the property at 1.30pm, after a cordon was removed.\n\nOne neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off.\n\n\"It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day.\n\n\"I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\nAnother Rendlesham Road resident said: \"It was quite the shock seeing all the guns and dogs, the road went from quiet to manic out of nowhere.\n\n\"They were shouting 'armed police' and pointing their guns so it was clearly quite a serious matter.\n\n01:49 PM BST\n\nNorth London primary school reportedly under lockdown\n\nSt Michael's Primary School in Enfield is reportedly under lockdown as police search for a suspected crossbow killer.\n\nPupils at the school are being kept inside as the hunt for Kyle Clifford continues, according to its headteacher.\n\nPolice are said to have carried out \"a reassurance visit\", according to Sky News.\n\n01:35 PM BST\n\nHelicopters seen circiling Enfield area near Clifford home\n\nTwo helicopters have been seen circling the Hilly Fields Park near Enfield opposite Clifford's home.\n\nA \"co-ordinated search\" is reportedly taking place and a car of possible interest has been found.\n\n01:20 PM BST\n\nDowden 'deeply concerned' about triple murder\n\nOliver Dowden, the Member of Parliament for Hertsmere, has said he is\"deeply concerned\" about the triple murder in Bushey.\n\nPosting on X, formerly Twitter, he said:\n\n01:12 PM BST\n\nHertfordshire crime commissioner pays tribute to family and friends of victims\n\nJonathan Ash-Edwards, Hertfordshire police and crime commissioner, said: \"My thoughts are with the family and friends of the women who have been shockingly killed in this terrible incident in Bushey.\n\n\"It will no doubt send shockwaves through the local community and across Hertfordshire.\n\n\"I am being kept updated by the police and I urge the public to support the police with any information about the whereabouts of the named suspect.\"\n\n01:09 PM BST\n\nPictured: Carol Hunt victim of Bushey triple murder\n\nThe wife of BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, who was the victim of a crossbow attack, has been pictured.\n\nShe and her two daughters were found dead in their family home in Bushey on Tuesday.\n\nMr Hunt is thought to have raised the alarm at around 7pm upon returning to the property on Ashlyn Close.\n\n12:51 PM BST\n\nWatch: Police give update on hunt for man 'with crossbow' after triple murder\n\nPolice gave an update on the search for a suspected triple murderer who is thought to be in possession of a crossbow.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, of Hertfordshire Police, spoke at a press conference shortly after 12.30pm on Wednesday.\n\nHe revealed the ages of the victims and made a personal plea to Kyle Clifford to hand himself in.\n\n12:46 PM BST\n\nTriple crossbow killing victims are wife and daughters of BBC racing commentator\n\nThe wife and two daughters of the BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt are thought to be the victims of the triple crossbow murder in Bushey.\n\nEmergency Services were called to the Hunt family home on Tuesday evening following reports that three women had been found with serious injuries.\n\nIt is believed Mr Hunt, who is married with three daughters, had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned to the home in Hertfordshire at around 7pm.\n\nThe three women died at the scene shortly after paramedics arrived.\n\nHertfordshire Police has issued an urgent appeal for Clifford, 26, from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nMr Hunt, 58, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live for the last 20-years.\n\n12:42 PM BST\n\nPolice address Kyle Clifford directly\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, addressed Clifford personally in the press conference.\n\nHe said: \"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\n12:41 PM BST\n\nCrossbow and other weapons may have been used\n\nKyle Clifford is believed to be carrying a crossbow but other weapons may also have been used, police said.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, said: \"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\n12:36 PM BST\n\nTeams of police helping with search\n\nManhunt involves armed police officers and specialist search teams who are responding \"at pace\" to the \"horrific incident\", Jon Simpson, Chief Superintendent said.\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\n12:35 PM BST\n\nAges of victims revealed\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, said the victims of the Bushey murders were aged 25, 28 and 61-years-old.\n\n12:34 PM BST\n\nPress conference due to begin\n\nA press conference is set to start following the triple murder in Bushey.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent of Hertfordshire Police is set to speak.\n\n12:17 PM BST\n\nTriple murder leaves residents 'shellshocked'\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass, who lives close by the scene in Bushey, said: \"I didn't know them personally but I knocked on their door, I was canvassing a few days ago for the General Election.\n\n\"I'm sure that their friends will be comforting the remains of the family that are left. These are all my representatives, I know them all.\n\n\"At 7pm last night a helicopter landed on the lawn in the development I live in which is 100 yards away from here, but it was an air ambulance, I'm told, and then rumours started circulating about a crossbow.\n\n\"The worst thing that's ever happened in this part of Bushey is a bit of illegal flytipping and then suddenly we get three murders and we're all a bit shellshocked.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb, we don't get this sort of thing in this area and I want residents to know that the council will be ensuring that the liaison team is down here and doing everything they can to comfort them and make sure that they are reassured that everything is being done.\n\n\"But we're worried that this guy is still floating around somewhere.\"\n\n12:14 PM BST\n\nResident heard screaming before police arrived\n\nA resident of Ashlyn Close in Bushey where police are investigating the murders of three women said they heard screaming on Tuesday evening as the \"absolutely traumatic\" incident unfolded.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nThe woman said she was upset and stressed to know a man sought in connection with the triple murder is still at large, adding: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\n12:00 PM BST\n\nPolice to hold presser\n\nPolice are expected to hold a press conference at 12.30pm.\n\nWe'll be bringing you live updates and a stream of the conference.\n\n11:39 AM BST\n\nHome Secretary being kept 'fully updated' Bushey killings\n\nThe Home Secretary is being kept \"fully updated\" on the killings of the three women who were found in Bushey, Hertfordshire, and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nYvette Cooper said in a post on X, formerly Twitter: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n\"I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support [Hertfordshire Police] with any information about this case.\"\n\n11:29 AM BST\n\nCouncillor can't remember murder in 'quiet neck of the woods' Bushey\n\nAerial footage of the scene show a blue and white forensic tent in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul de sac, with a police officer on guard and several police vehicles parked nearby.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe told the BBC: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so [it's a] terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\n11:20 AM BST\n\nAshlyn Close 'swarming with armed police', says resident\n\nSarah Fernandez, 52, arrived back home just after 7.30pm to find Ashlyn Close swarming with armed police.\n\nShe said: \" I was the last car allowed into the street before the police closed off access. There were about 15 armed police vehicles parked up. It's really frightening. We've never had anything like this before here.\"\n\n11:14 AM BST\n\nAerial footage of Ashlyn Close where three women died\n\nAerial footage of Ashlyn Close in Bushey where three women died on Tuesday.\n\n10:42 AM BST\n\nPictured: Scene of the crime in Bushey\n\nPolice officers have been pictured at the scene of the crime with a cordon in place on Ashlyn Close.\n\n10:36 AM BST\n\nResidents 'deeply shocked' after three women found dead\n\nResidents are \"deeply shocked\" after three women were found dead at a home in Bushey.\n\nRiaz Hussein, a telecoms specialist in his late 50s, told The Telegraph: \"It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n\"This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.\"\n\nMr Hussein added: \"I don't recognise the man wanted in connection with this from the picture police have released. I've not noticed him around here before.\"\n\nCounty Councillor Laurence Brass echoed the dismay felt by local residents.\n\n\"It's a shock for everyone on the street,\" he said. \"The worst thing that usually happens around here is fly tipping and now we've got three people dead. Utterly shocking.\"\n\n10:29 AM BST\n\nMap: Police search Bushey and Enfield\n\nPolice are searching for Kyle Clifford in Enfield, north London, where he lives and Bushey, Hertfordshire, where the three women were found seriously injured and later died.\n\n10:20 AM BST\n\nWomen died despite best efforts of ambulance crew\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\n10:16 AM BST\n\nNeighbours claim victims were family\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\n10:06 AM BST\n\nCouncillors pay tribute to the three dead women\n\nLocal councillors have paid tribute to the three women, adding they are \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the incident.\n\nThey called the deaths \"tragic\" and extended their condolences to those affected.\n\nLouise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards, who are local councillors for the area, said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\n09:55 AM BST\n\nPictured: Ashlyn Close where three women died on Tuesday\n\nPolice were called to a property in Ashlyn Close at around 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nOfficers attended the scene alongside the East of England Ambulance Service.\n\n09:51 AM BST\n\nLondon police appeal for witnesses\n\nOfficers from Enfield Metropolitan Police are appealing for witnesses following a suspected triple murder.\n\n09:47 AM BST\n\nHuge police presence in Bushey\n\nLocal residents reported a \"huge police presence\" in Bushey overnight and into the morning, with a force helicopter seen in the grounds of the former American University.\n\nOne X user posted: \"It's on my road, Ashlyn Close - It's cordoned off. There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n\"We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.\"\n\nAnother social media user, called Stu, added before details of the attacks emerged: \"Huge police presence in Bushey tonight, and a chopper at the old American University, hope it's nothing too serious.\"\n\n09:43 AM BST\n\nHelicopter pictured near to scene of crime\n\nA helicopter has been photographed nearby Ashlyn Close following a suspected triple murder on Tuesday.\n\n09:24 AM BST\n\nHertfordshire Police: Have you seen Kyle Clifford?\n\n09:18 AM BST\n\nPolice statement in full\n\nRob Hall Detective Superintendent from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\n09:18 AM BST\n\nPublic told not to approach Clifford\n\nOfficers have been searching overnight for Clifford, of Enfield, north London. The three victims have now been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25. They are the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHe was found in the Enfield area of north London and is receiving treatment for his injuries, Hertfordshire Police said. Police previously said they believe it was a \"targeted incident\" and urged members of the public not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\nKyle Clifford is understood to be the ex-boyfriend of victim Louise Hunt. The BBC reported that Kyle Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022. The Ministry of Defence confirmed on Wednesday that he had served briefly in the Armed Forces. A Whitehall source said: \"He didn't serve very long and he is no longer a serving member of the armed forces. We're not going to speculate which regiment or unit he was in, but look at his age. He didn't serve very long.\"\n\nIt has also emerged that his brother, Bradley Clifford, is currently serving a life sentence over the murder of a moped driver. Bradley, from Enfield, pursued and collided with Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, in his Ford Mustang after they hit his car with a bottle, the Old Bailey heard in 2018.\n\nBoth victims were thrown into flung into the air by the crash. Bradley Clifford then beat moped rider Mr Khan as he lay on the ground. Mr Khan later died, and a post-mortem gave his cause of death as multiple injuries. During the trial, the jury was told how Bradley Clifford became \"enraged\" when his Mustang EcoBoost's wing mirror was broken, beginning a \"rapid, brutal and unrelenting\" chase through the streets of Enfield in north London.\n\nJahshua Francis, 19, was found injured near the scene. He was rushed to hospital in ambulance and recovered from his injuries.\n\nBradley Clifford was found guilty of murder and attempted GBH with intent. killed three women", "body": "A wanted man who sparked a manhunt after killing three women has been found.\n\nArmed police swarmed the Hilly Fields area of Enfield today (July 10) after heavy police presence across the area as officers urgently searched for Kyle Clifford following a crossbow attack.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, who was married to the BBC 5 Live racing presenter John Hunt, and two of their daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found seriously injured at a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, yesterday (July 9).\n\nHerts Police and the East of England Ambulance Service were called just before 7pm, but a spokesperson confirmed that \"despite their best efforts\" all three victims died at the scene.\n\nArmed police in Enfield (Image: SWNS)\n\nThe manhunt to find 26-year-old Clifford was then launched with officers searching across the Hertfordshire and north London areas, where they believed he may be.\n\nHertfordshire Constabulary confirmed that Clifford is now receiving medical treatment after he was found with injuries.\n\nDespite speculation online, no shots were fired by police.\n\nAt this stage, police believe the suspect was known to the victims.\n\nArmed police in Enfield (Image: SWNS)\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. The three women were the wife and daughters of John Hunt, who works for the BBC 5 Live radio station as a horse racing commentator.\n\nIn a statement, Hertfordshire Police said officers were called to the Hunt family's home in Bushey just before 7 p.m. on Tuesday and found the women seriously injured. All three died at the scene.\n\nPolice said they have been searching since Wednesday night for a suspect, Kyle Clifford, 26, who is believed to be in Hertfordshire or North London. Officers said the women were shot in an apparently \"targeted incident.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident, involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used,\" said the Hertfordshire police chief, Superintendent Jon Simpson, at a news conference Wednesday.\n\nTwo helicopters were circling parts of the town of Enfield in North London, where Clifford is from, and armed police raided an Enfield property, according the Independent newspaper.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper, who took office last week after the Labour Party's election victory, is considering tougher crossbow laws and will assess the findings of a Home Office review carried out earlier this year, British news outlets reported.\n\nThe previous government had considered tightening the laws involving crossbows after would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail attempted to break into Windsor Castle and kill Queen Elizabeth II with such a weapon on Christmas morning in 2021.\n\nThe United Kingdom currently does not have a registration system or licensing requirement for crossbow ownership, though it is illegal for anyone under 18 to possess one.\n\nIn February, the Conservative government's Home Office launched an eight-week review to consider implementing a licensing system and tighter restrictions on buying and selling crossbows, similar to regulations already instated for firearms.\n\nThe office completed the review in April, but action was apparently stalled by the recent elections.\n\nIn a tweet on Wednesday, Cooper called the killings \"shocking\" and said she is being kept \"fully updated\" on the investigation.\n\nJohn Hunt's fellow sports journalists and other figures from the racing world took to social media to express their condolences for the Hunt family.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain,\" wrote ITV racing commentator Matt Chapman on X. \"Just know we are all here for you John. The BBC has confirmed that the women killed were the family of its well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nWhile the manhunt was underway, the public were urged not to approach Clifford, who is from the Enfield area in north London, around 52 kilometers (17 miles) to the east from the site of the killing.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nArmed police officers, forensic personnel and ambulance staff were seen at Hilly Fields Park in Enfield, which is popular with joggers and dog-walkers, and the adjacent Lavender Hill cemetery. The area has been closed off and an ambulance helicopter was also at the scene. Police have not confirmed whether the intense activity is connected to the manhunt as it is an ongoing investigation.\n\nPolice said the three women -- aged 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nThe BBC confirmed the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two daughters, Louise Hunt and her older sister Hannah Hunt.\n\nJohn Hunt is the main racing commentator for BBC 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel. His voice is known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal council member Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area where the killings took place is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE The police advised people not to approach Clifford as \"he may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThe attack was carried out with a crossbow, Hertfordshire Police Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said Wednesday, adding that other weapons may also have been used.\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford had been known to the women, who were 25, 28 and 61 years old, but they said it was believed to have been a targeted incident.\n\nSpeaking on live television, Simpson appealed directly to Clifford on Wednesday, saying: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact,\" and urging him to call the U.K. emergency services number 999.\n\nBritain's Home Secretary Yvette Cooper, the top government official in charge of law enforcement, said in a post on social media that she was being kept \"fully updated\" on the case, and she urged anyone with information to contact the police.\n\n\"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community,\" she said.\n\n\"We're very shocked,\" local city councilor Laurence Brass told CBS News partner network BBC News that. \"We're not used to this in this area, it's a very typical, leafy Bushey suburb... and suddenly we're told there are three murders. We had a helicopter landing at the top of my road last night, police all over the place. So, I'm concerned for residents, who I think are a little bit traumatized by what's going on here.\"\n\nCrossbows are legal in the U.K. and no license or registration is required to own one, though it {"uri": "8218258912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:00:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:00:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:59:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/breaking-manhunt-after-three-related-33207657", "title": "Manhunt after 3 women found dead in home in plush suburb as cops say 'find him'", "body": "A manhunt has been launched following a suspected triple murder. Three women were found seriously injured inside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire on Tuesday night and later died.\n\nSince being called to the horror scene in Ashyn Close just before 7pm last night, Herts Police have been searching for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford who is wanted in connection with the incident. Clifford is from the Enfield area.\n\nPolice have since been searching throughout the night for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nMembers of the public have been urged to dial 999 \"straight away\" if they see Clifford but warned against approaching him as he may still be armed.\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. {"uri": "8219157336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:37:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:37:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:37:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/13111108/caught-murder-three-women-bushey-crossbow/", "title": "'Crossbow killer' caught after 'murder' of BBC star's wife & two daughters", "body": "A MAN has been caught after a BBC star's wife and two daughters were allegedly murdered in their home.\n\nKyle Clifford was seen being bundled into the back of an ambulance this afternoon after armed police swooped on a cemetery in Hilly Fields in Enfield, North London.\n\nFootage emerged showing an ambulance with sirens blaring leaving the graveyard this afternoon amid the major manhunt - before cops confirmed the suspect had been caught.\n\nPolice said Clifford is receiving treatment for injuries, having been found injured - though no shots were fired by officers.\n\nIt comes after a BBC star's wife and two daughters were allegedly murdered in Bushey, Hertfordshire.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61 - the wife of BBC racing commentator John Hunt - and their daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found dead inside their home last night.\n\nA haunting photo shows Clifford with ex-girlfriend Louise.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\n\"The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us.\n\n\"We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, who took footage this afternoon of armed cops inside the graveyard, told The Sun: \"It's probably shaken up the locals quite a lot.\"\n\nHe went on to describe suspect Clifford as a \"local lad\", adding: \"His family are well known around here and have had quite a lot of incidents with the police.\"\n\nFootage emerged today showing a man coming out of an alleyway next to the property dressed all in black and carrying what appears to be a crossbow and a bag cops fear could be a cache of further weapons.\n\nThe man in the footage then climbs into a black Seat - the same car understood to have been found abandoned earlier today.\n\nThat discovery led cops to Enfield where armed officers were searching for the suspect.\n\nWhat we know so far...\n\nA full-size crossbow could shoot bolts accurately up to 250ft - raising the terrifying prospect victims may not even see their shooter before being hit.\n\nIn the clip - the man, believed to be Kyle Clifford - climbs into the black car and waits for 18 seconds before driving away West-bound on Bushey Grove Road.\n\nThe road is directly connected to the murder scene on Ashlyn Close by a pedestrian footpath.\n\nBBC Five Live racing commentator Hunt had been working at Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey yesterday before returning home in the evening to discover the horror that had unfolded, it is understood.\n\nMailOnline reports Clifford was the ex-boyfriend of one of Hunt's daughters.\n\nThe Sun revealed earlier the 26-year-old had served briefly in the Armed Forces before the \"targeted\" attack last night.\n\nClifford was a trooper - {"uri": "8219504292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "23:28:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T23:28:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T23:26:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/uk-police-detain-crossbow-attack-suspect-after-three-women-killed/", "title": "UK police detain crossbow attack suspect after three women killed | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "UK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n- 'Shocking' -\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he was trying to kill Queen Elizabeth II.\n\naks/phz/giv/nro\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8219108301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:59:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:59:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:59:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13620679/john-hunt-bbc-bushey-crossbow-murder-daughter-car-messy-breakup.html", "title": "Victim of triple crossbow murder suspect crashed car before 'murder'", "body": "BBC star John Hunt's daughter crashed her car before being fatally attacked by a crossbow alongside her mother and sister because she was going through a 'messy' breakup with her ex-boyfriend, locals have said.\n\nMother Carol, 61, and daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nPolice sources said the three women were tied up before being shot in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons'.\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise.\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said Louise had been left upset at breaking up with her boyfriend and crashed her car last week as a result.\n\nHe said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house.\n\n'I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it. So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house.\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt Kyle Clifford continues\n\nDetectives investigating a triple murder which occurred in Bushey, Hertfordshire, yesterday evening are actively seeking a man who is wanted in connection with the incident\n\nArmed police search Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield, as the hunt Kyle Clifford continues\n\n'Another dog groomer - who is a friend of Louise's - told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.'\n\nThe neighbour added: 'I don't know if it was her boyfriend, but put it this way, some of my dog walkers said that she'd had a traumatic boyfriend bust up the week before last.'\n\nCarol told friends at her local gym that her youngest daughter was involved in a 'messy break up' with her boyfriend.\n\nThe mother worked out at the Bushey Grove Leisure Centre on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nShe spoke with friends at the gym about her daughter Louise's relationship with Kyle turning nasty.\n\nA friend said: 'She said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy.\n\n'Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nThe gym is a five-minute walk from her detached home in Bushey.\n\nHelicopters were seen circling the Hilly Fields area of Enfield on Wednesday afternoon before police raided an empty property in the area.\n\nThey then turned their sights on a nearby primary school which has gone into lockdown after locating the suspect's car.\n\nPolice warned Clifford may be armed and dangerous, and urged the public not to approach the man if they see him, but to instead call 999 immediately.\n\nAt a press conference today, Hertfordshire Police urged Clifford to 'make contact with the police' as the suspect in the killings remains at large.\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nCarol Hunt (pictured) and her two daughters were tied up before being shot with a crossbow, MailOnline understands\n\nPolice stand at a cordon in front and blue tent which has been erected outside a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire following the deaths of three women\n\nTwo armed police officers stand guard at the scene on a street in Bushey where three women, believed to be related, were discovered with serious injuries\n\nPolice have said they have launched a manhunt for Clifford\n\nClifford, from Enfield, north London, used to work as a security guard, it has been reported.\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac was swarming with armed police and forensic officers as the triple murder investigation continued.\n\nAlthough the police have not officially released the identity of the victims, the BBC revealed this afternoon that the three women were the wife and two daughters of its racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHe had been working at Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey yesterday before returning home in the evening to discover the horror that had unfolded.\n\nShocked neighbours said Louise ran a dog grooming business called Groom and Glow from the detached house in a cul-de-sac.\n\nLocal resident William Nourallah paid tribute to the 'beautiful young girl'.\n\nHe said: 'She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father\n\n'She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. She was a beautiful young girl. It's a waste of a life.'\n\nAnother neighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said that Louise had been left upset at breaking up with a boyfriend and crashed her car last week as a result.\n\nA blue and white forensic tent has been erected in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul-de-sac in Bushey\n\nForensics outside a home in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, where three women were found 'murdered'\n\nHe said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house.\n\n'I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it. So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house.\n\n'Another dog groomer - who is a friend of Louise's - told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.\n\n'Who the boyfriend was, I don't know, I never saw him. I believe Hannah, Louise's sister, was also killed along with their mother Carol.\n\n'I didn't know Hannah too well but Carol was very quaint, a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'Her husband John is a BBC radio commentator. He commentates on horse racing mostly. I believe he may have been at Lingfield racecourse yesterday.\n\n'This is such an awful incident, the whole community is in shock.'\n\nA neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nIn a note sent to staff at BBC Five Live today, the corporation described the incident as 'utterly devastating'.\n\nThe note read: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women, who police believe to be related, died last night\n\nA police car is seen parked up outside a police cordon in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nIn a press conference on Wednesday, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told reporters the murders are believed to be 'targeted'.\n\nThe force also warned the public not to approach the suspect who 'may be in possession of a crossbow'.\n\nHe said: 'Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n'We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n'The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.'\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: 'Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.'\n\nArmed police were seen forcing their way into a house in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, this morning in a raid that is believed to be related to the horrific killings.\n\nAn aerial view of the scene of the suspected triple murder in Bushey, Hertfordshire\n\nTwo officers stand outside a police cordon at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nA lone police officers patrols the road at the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close\n\nThe house, which is close to Gordon Hill railway station, had two officers stood guard outside this afternoon hours after helicopters were seen patrolling the skies overhead.\n\nWhile this was taking place a nearby primary school in Enfield was sent into lockdown as police searched for the triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, said pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nBut parents will be able to pick up their children at 'the normal time' at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: 'We've locked both buildings and just kept the children inside. So we've not had them on the field or the playground. It's not a lockdown as in under the desks or hidden or anything, it's just a lighter lockdown.\n\n'We have just kept them within the building as though it were like a wet playday so we don't cause the children any distress and we keep everything as calm as possible.'\n\nSeveral police cars can also been seen parked on the road. One resident claimed 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine descended on the scene last night\n\nAn officer stands next to a police a car outside the scene of a triple murder in Ashlyn Close, Bushey\n\nA police officer walks down the road at the site of a triple murder in Bushey on Wednesday\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings of the three women who were found in Bushey, Hertfordshire, and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X, formerly Twitter: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nEarlier today police revealed they were looking for Kyle Clifford following the incident and warned members of the public to call 999 immediately if they saw him.\n\nIn a statement released this morning Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n'Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n'This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.'\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: 'We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n'Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n'Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "UK police arrest crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "The three women were killed on Tuesday night in Bushey, near Watford, north of London\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\nMore from this section India Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house',\" she added.\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad "UK police detain crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "The three women were killed on Tuesday night in Bushey, near Watford, north of London\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nMore from this section Astronaut Exposes 'Enormous Lie' About Earth After devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded {"uri": "8220474130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:38:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:38:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:38:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/horror-house-devastated-john-hunt-33218620", "title": "'Horror house' devastated John Hunt returned to after family's brave final act", "body": "BBC commentator John Hunt devastating lost his wife and two daughters in a 'targeted' attack\n\nBBC broadcaster John Hunt experienced every husband and father's worst nightmare.\n\nThe sports commentator, 58, returned home from working for the BBC at Lingfield Park racecourse around 7pm on Tuesday after his wife, Carol, 61, and daughters, Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, had been fatally injured. The three women were victims of a harrowing attack, and despite best efforts from emergency services, they all died at the scene.\n\nThe mother and daughters were \"targeted\" in a brutal attack involving a crossbow in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police said yesterday. Officers located the suspected triple murderer, Kyle Clifford, 26, in an Enfield graveyard on Wednesday following a near day-long manhunt.\n\nIt is believed Clifford had at one point been in a relationship with Mr Hunt's younger daughter, Louise. He was eventually found hiding in headstones in the Lavender Hill Cemetery yesterday, near where the three women died. Officers are waiting to question their main suspect after he was taken to hospital last night with injuries.\n\nWith the search now concluded, disturbing new information has emerged about the circumstances in which the three women were found at their home in Hertfordshire. Sources have claimed that evidence from the scene suggests the mother and daughters may have been gagged and bound before they were killed.\n\nCiting a source, The Guardian reported that while the three members of the Hunt family were not found tied up, there were ligature marks visible on their wrists and faces that suggest they may have been at one point. It was also reported that Carol, a mother of three to Hannah, Louise, and a third daughter called Amy, was found in the hallway of the house with a crossbow bolt in her chest. The publication's source added that evidence of ligatures was found near their bodies.\n\nCarol, Hannah, and Lousie were all still alive when police and emergency services - including two air ambulances - were called to their home before 7pm on July 9. It's understood the trio made a brave attempt to get help in their final moments. The Guardian reports that one of the women called 999 and alerted officers to the attack before the perpetrator fled the scene. The publication has also reported that one of the victims texted her partner, urging them to call the police.\n\nRecalling the moment the quiet cul de sac suddenly turned into a major crime scene, a local resident, 46, said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'That's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'Stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\" The neighbour said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nShe added that it \"happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time\".\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said that, with Clifford now located, \"nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time\". She has asked people to come forward if they have information or footage relating to the incident.\n\nDet Insp Jenkins said: \"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case. We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation. This incident will of course be of concern to local residents.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nia_dalton@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Nia
