"title": "UK police arrest crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "The three women were killed on Tuesday night in Bushey, near Watford, north of London\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n- 'Shocking' -\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nOne neighbour described hearing \"shrill\" screams from the home on Tuesday.\n\nThe 46-year-old who lives near the scene, said \"absolute chaos\" then broke out as armed police put the road into lockdown.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house',\" she added.\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he was trying to kill Queen Elizabeth {"uri": "2024-07-417808301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:34:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:34:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:10:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/suspect-in-triple-murder-case-apprehended-in-cemetery-kyle-clifford-injured-no-shots-fired-by-police/", "title": "Suspect in Triple Murder Case Apprehended in Cemetery: Kyle Clifford Injured, No Shots Fired by Police - Internewscast Journal", "body": "A fugitive accused of murdering three people with a crossbow has been stretchered away from the scene after being caught in a cemetery following a huge manhunt.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, was seen being bundled into the back of an ambulance in the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, north London, by armed police and paramedics on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nWitnesses said they saw the suspect being stretchered away while receiving medical treatment before he was taken to Royal London Hospital.\n\nClifford became Britain's most wanted man after police said they were hunting the ex-soldier in connection with the 'murders' of Carol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, who is the ex-girlfriend of Clifford.\n\nThe women, who are the wife and daughters of BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt, were found fatally injured inside their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nPolice sources said the women had been tied up before they were shot dead with a crossbow in a 'targeted attack' that may have also included 'other weapons'.\n\nChilling doorbell footage emerged of what is believed to be the suspect fleeing the scene on Ashlyn Close in Bushey carrying what appeared to be a crossbow concealed underneath a white sheet shortly before 7pm yesterday.\n\nAs police scoured the area, their attention turned to Clifford's hometown of Enfield, with officers carrying out raids and locking down primary schools in a bid to catch him.\n\nArmed police and paramedics were filmed this afternoon running into Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield as the hunt continued for Clifford, a former soldier and security guard.\n\nLater, armed police closed down the cemetery, a five-minute walk from the house linked to the suspect. Up to four black-clad officers - two carrying automatic rifles - stood guard at the cemetery gates, preventing members of the public from entering.\n\nMeanwhile, an ambulance rushed into the cemetery grounds with blue lights flashing and sirens on. It re-emerged about 20 minute later, still in emergency mode.\n\nTwo helicopters were also spotted hovering- one believed to be an air ambulance which landed in the cemetery grounds.\n\nLocal resident Rae Cresswell, 26, told how she was going for a walk in the cemetery when she saw armed officers.\n\n'They just said have you heard the news, said they were searching and asked if I wanted to leave,' she said.\n\n'I said \"no\", and stayed for a while and they were going around looking around the trees and the graves.\n\n'I wasn't scared, they said first thing this morning that it was a domestic so I didn't think I was in any danger.'\n\nEarlier, officers raided a house where Clifford is known to live, with dramatic footage from today showing officers storming the property.\n\nPolice have found the suspect's car and are now searching a nearby park. Members of the public have been told to immediately call 999 if they see Clifford but not approach him, describing him as dangerous and potentially still armed.\n\nNearby schools have gone into precautionary lockdowns, with teachers at one primary telling parents to collect their children at the end of the day and take them directly home.\n\nThe BBC has called the murders 'utterly devastating', adding in a note to staff: 'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nClifford's neighbours told today how police had put the road into lockdown as a house was searched by armed officers.\n\nThey spoke as two police helicopters hovered above the neighbourhood and two uniformed PCs stood guard at the door of the terraced home.\n\nOne local mother told how she arrived back from dropping her children off at school to find armed police at the house opposite hers.\n\n'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into,' she told MailOnline. 'They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.\n\n'They let me through to get home and they remained there for about an hour before they left. Then there was just the ordinary police there. 'I don't know the family at all. I know the father passed away some time ago but that's about it.'\n\nOne woman who lives across the road from the house said he had been working from home when she heard a commotion.\n\n'I was upstairs, when I heard cars honking and then looked out the window and realised that there were police there,' she said.\n\n'I came down and looked across. And they were saying \"armed police\" and then they went right in. There were dogs barking and everyone realised there was something big going on.'\n\nThe mother added: 'We've now been told that my daughter's school around the corner has gone into an amber lockdown. A few other schools have shut their doors as well. So we're just a little bit worried. I think everyone is really, really concerned.'\n\nThe BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died and messages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote on X: 'No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today.\n\n'Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.'\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nThis morning, the usually quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey where the killings took place was swarming with armed police and forensic officers.\n\nOne neighbour, who lives on the 'serene and quiet road' and did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a 'friendly family'.\n\n'We would see them every day passing by and they would say 'good morning',' she said. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper is being kept 'fully updated' on the killings and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nThe Labour MP said in a post on X: 'The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n'I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support (Hertfordshire Police) with any information about this case.'\n\nOne local resident, who lives on a nearby street, told MailOnline that his friends went to school with some of the victims.\n\nHe said: 'From 7pm there were like 20 police cars coming down, four ambulances and then armed police came and they were here till midnight.\n\n'I know of them (the victims). So a few of them went to school with people that I know. That's all I know. I didn't know them personally.\n\n'I know they went to schools in the area. They didn't go to my school.'\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is 'a typical leafy British suburb'.\n\nHe told the BBC: 'At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n'This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n'We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so (it's a) terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n'That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.'\n\nAnother man who lives close to the murder scene in Bushey said the incident was 'tragic' and claimed the victims were 'a middle class family'.\n\nRiaz, who is in his 50s and declined to give a second name, said: 'At 6 o'clock, my wife called me while I was at work, saying 'there are so many police cars down the road which I've never seen before', and she was distressed.\n\n'I didn't know (what had happened) at that point, then at that very moment my nephew phoned me saying something tragic had happened and was I OK. I came early evening and I saw the cars and realised something tragic had happened.\n\n'This has been an awful situation and I can't even imagine what the family must be going through.\n\n'My wife and I walk down that road often and it is quiet. It is surprising, especially in the magnitude. To have three individuals who have been tragically killed, it is tragic.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nTelecoms specialist Diaz Hussein, who is in his 50s, told The Telegraph he didn't recognise Clifford and had 'not noticed him around here before'.\n\nHe added: 'It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n'This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], No shots were fired by police.\n\nIn an update this afternoon, a police spokesperson said: \"At this stage, he is currently in a serious condition and is yet to speak with officers.\n\n\"A crossbow has been recovered as part of the investigation.\n\n\"Enquiries continue today and as part of this, we have explored if there was any prior police contact between Hertfordshire Constabulary, Kyle Clifford and the victims.\n\n\"We can confirm there had been no previous reports made to police.\"\n\nKyle Clifford. are being supported by specially trained officers.\"\n\nThe detective superintendent thanked members of the public who contacted police and helped with enquiries, while appealing for anyone else who "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/13110563/jockeys-black-armbands-minutes-silence-john-hunt-family/", "title": "Jockeys wear black armbands after horrific 'murder' of John Hunt's family", "body": "JOCKEYS are wearing black armbands and a minute's silence will be held at all meetings on Thursday following the alleged murder of BBC racing commentator John Hunt's wife and two daughters.\n\nA massive manhunt is underway for alleged 'crossbow killer Kyle Clifford', 26, as footage of a man fleeing the Hunt family home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, was obtained by The Sun.\n\nChilling footage appeared to show a fugitive walking towards a car carrying a 3ft crossbow before climbing into a black Seat and driving off.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61 - the wife of 5Live racing commentator John - and their daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found inside the home suffering serious injuries.\n\nSadly they could not be saved after falling victim to what police called a targeted attack.\n\nRacing has rallied round hugely popular presenter and commentator John, whose coverage of the Grand National has been called 'commentary at its finest'.\n\nThe Sky studio host has today also been labelled 'the most wonderful and kind human' by those he knew in the sport.\n\nJockeys are wearing black armbands for tonight's racing and that will carry over into tomorrow, where Newmarket's big July Festival begins.\n\nA statement from the Professional Jockeys' Association said: \"This is an unspeakable tragedy to befall anyone, but to happen to someone as popular and beloved as John is even more heartbreaking.\n\n\"Jockeys will wear black armbands and observe a minute's silence at race meetings tonight and tomorrow.\"\n\nWhile a statement from British Horseracing Authority CEO Julie Harrington read: \"The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends at this shocking and tragic time.\n\n\"It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n\"John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have so many times before when one of our own is faced with great trauma.\"\n\nHertfordshire Police confirmed Clifford, who is from Enfield in North London, may still be armed and urged anyone who sees him to call 999 immediately.\n\nThey also said he may still have the crossbow and other weapons believed to have been used in the attack.\n\nAppealing directly to Clifford today, Detective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact with police via 999.\"\n\nHerts Police have told anyone who was in Ashlyn Close from lunchtime yesterday to come forward to call 101 quoting Op Infauna.\n\nDSI Rob Hall said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. 'It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.'\n\nAnother resident living in the proximity of the attacks described the terrifying police response that descended on the quiet cul-de-sac.\n\nThey said: 'There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n'We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.'\n\nDetective Superintendent Rob Hall from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: 'This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n'Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n'Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away.\n\n'Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n'This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.'\n\nLocal councillors for the area Louise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards said: 'We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n'As North Bushey His tweet came before his family were identified as the Bushey triple murder victims.\n\nOn Saturday, July 6, John tweeted: \"Watching England is like going to Las Vegas, getting a room with an airport view and deciding on an early night after a room service Carbonara and half a lager.\"\n\nShortly after his first post, he shared another which read: \"Can we just fast forward straight to penalties on Wednesday, please.\" Like the rest of the UK, John had been looking forward to seeing England play tonight, but sadly, he is now faced with indescribable tragedy following the loss of his beloved wife and two daughters.\n\nUnderneath John's last posts, his fans have flocked to share their sympathy with the BBC star after his family were identified as the victims. One wrote: \"Man I'm so sorry... I hope you can find some peace. Christ have mercy.\" Another echoed: \"If I can do anything for you in life, John, please tell me. I am so, so sorry for your loss.\"\n\nAnother replied: \"I'm so utterly sorry for this awful tragedy. May their memories be blessings.\" And someone else voiced: \"So sorry to hear the absolute awful news. Deep condolences to you and your family.\" Another one of John's followers wrote: \"I'm so terribly sorry for your loss. Words seem futile right now but in time I hope you can take comfort and strength from the kindness and love being shown towards you.\"\n\nPolice have made a direct appeal to the chief suspect in the \"horrific\" murders of the three women to give himself up. Kyle Clifford is being hunted following the discovery of the fatally-injured women aged 25, 28 and 61 - and police have warned he is believed to armed with a crossbow and other weapons.\n\nThe victims have now been reportedly identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - although official confirmation is still being awaited. John is understood to have been working for BBC Racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned home.\n\nFollowing the tragic news, tributes have flooded in for the family, including for John's daughter, Louise. According to MyLondon, one post on social media read: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nLouise reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow, while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business, the website reported.\n\nToday Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said the attack last night in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire was a \"targeted incident \" and Clifford, 26, was \"wanted in connection with murder\".\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident. We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\" Addressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nThe three women were found in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to to a home in Hertfordshire before 7pm. The trio had suffered serious injuries, but were alive when discovered. However all three women tragically died a short time later.\n\nHunt, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live as a racing commentator for the last 20 years. ITV racing pundit Matt Chapman took to X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday to share his condolences for his co-star. He wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation described the incident which involved the deaths of the wife and daughters of racing commentator John Hunt as \"utterly devastating\". The note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , The BBC said the women killed were the family of well-known radio racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Kyle Clifford, 26, was being sought over the suspected triple murder, which involved a crossbow and potentially other unnamed weapons. The public were urged not to approach Clifford if they see him.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby.\n\nThe Daily Mail newspaper and others reported that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse south of London.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC staff, the broadcaster described the incident as \"utterly devastating\" and that it will provide Hunt \"with all the support we can.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women, but British media reported that he was an ex-boyfriend of one of the daughters. The BBC reported that Clifford left the British Army after a brief period of service in 2022.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb.\"\n\n\"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run,\" he told the BBC.\n\nAddressing the suspect directly, Simpson said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nBritain's new home secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she is being kept \"fully informed\" about the \"truly shocking\" incident.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPeople in Britain do not need a license to own a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nA spokesperson for the Home Office said Cooper will \"swiftly consider\" the findings from a recently launched review into whether further controls on crossbows {"uri": "8219309104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:56:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:56:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:54:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/police-suspected-crossbow-killer-enfield-194533939.html", "title": "Police find suspected crossbow killer in Enfield", "body": "Police have found suspected crossbow killer Kyle Clifford in Enfield following a huge manhunt in North London.\n\nHertfordshire Police said Clifford, 26, was found in the area by officers on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe force said he is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries and confirmed no shots had been fired by police.\n\nA man believed to be Clifford had been seen being stretchered out of Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield.\n\nFollow for more updates\n\nThis blog has now closed. Thank you for following our coverage.\n\nHere is a summary of today's events:\n\nA friend of Louise Hunt, who lives in Bushey, has said the usually \"pretty quiet\" local community is \"completely in shock\" at the triple murder.\n\nHe told BBC News: \"I've lived in Bushey pretty much my whole life, only a couple of roads away, and it is generally a pretty quiet community.\n\n\"We certainly don't hear about any kind of violence of this magnitude.\n\n\"A lot of working professionals, families, and everyone gets on with their day - so it's a pretty quiet community, and completely in shock tonight.\"\n\nThe friend also described Louise as \"always a positive person\" and that he could not think of \"anything bad to say about her\".\n\nHe added: \"I couldn't believe what had happened at first. I'd heard the news from my sister early in the morning before I'd figured out who the victims were and, once I found out, it's been a massive shock, (I've) been in denial.\n\n\"I haven't processed it yet and I feel also angry towards the murder and I can't even begin to imagine what the father's going through - so, mixture of emotions - angry, sad and in shock.\"\n\nA London Ambulance spokesman said ambulance crews and the air ambulance attended an incident in Lavender Hill cemetery this afternoon.\n\nThey said a man was treated at the scene and later taken to a major trauma centre.\n\nPolice said they believe triple murder suspect Kyle Clifford was known to the victims.\n\nHertfordshire Police confirmed Clifford is receiving medical treatment and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\nIn a press conference before Clifford was located, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson told reporters the murders are believed to be \"targeted\".\n\nA friend of the women who were killed in Bushey has remembered them as \"beautiful souls\".\n\nSu Kehinde, 60, who lives nearby, spoke after laying some flowers at a makeshift tribute at the end of the police cordon.\n\nMs Kehinde said: \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They were the meekest human beings. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.\"\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah Hunt \"always had a smile\", adding: \"She was hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle.\"\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"Following extensive inquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nThe force also said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\"\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local resident who filmed police sweeping into Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield earlier, said: \"I saw about 10 officers coming in, it was around 3pm I'd say. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\"\n\nHe added: \"I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.\"\n\nIn a post on Facebook, the Parish of Bushey invited people to offer prayers and light candles at two churches in Bushey after expressing \"deep sadness\" as the \"people of Bushey mourn the tragic loss of three members of our community\".\n\nThey wrote: \"This has made the national news and attention will be focused on where we live. Both the Parish Church of St James on the High Street of Bushey and St Pauls on Bushey Hall Road are open for people to offer prayers and light a candle for those who have died, the family of the victims and those helping with this terrible crime. We also remember the perpetrator who committed this act, that he may come forward to the police.\"\n\nGlyn Nicholas, 77, retired, who has lived on the same road as the victims for 50 years said: \"I know one of the daughters because she's our dog groomer. All our daughters had their dogs groomed with Louise. She knew my wife, but the other daughter I didn't know at all.\"\n\nHe added: \"They were a private family, all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\n\"They used to have a dog themselves and they used to be out and about walking their dog. I'd just say hello, never stopped and talked.\n\n\"A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. With his job they probably could have found a more salubrious house but they'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years. They had a groomer's hut built for the dogs in the garden. I believe they had another daughter who lives away.\n\nHe said that the girls \"were quite young when they came here - they were just young girls when they came here so they've probably been nearer 20 years here\".\n\nThe man being hunted by police on suspicion of a triple crossbow murder has a brother who is serving life in prison for beating a man to death, The Telegraph can disclose.\n\nSix years ago, Clifford's older brother, Bradley, was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey.\n\nBradley Clifford, a plumber, was 23 when he chased and deliberately mowed down Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, on their moped after they struck his prized Ford Mustang car with a bottle.\n\nThe Telegraph's Crime Editor, Martin Evans, has the full story here.\n\nA Metropolitan Police forensics van has just pulled up at the entrance to Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield, the focus of the search for suspected crossbow killer Kyle Clifford.\n\nMeanwhile, the air ambulance has just taken off.\n\nAlthough shielded from view by a thick evergreen hedge, the cemetery is just yards from the residential housing on Cedar Road, which runs adjacent.\n\nThe cemetery is on the northern edge of London, between central Enfield and the M25 motorway.\n\nIn footage from LBC posted on X, dozens of paramedics and police can be seen racing into the cemetery in Hilly Fields, Enfield where the search has been centred.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police have confirmed they are assisting their colleagues in Hertfordshire with the search for Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the triple crossbow murder in Bushey.\n\nA Hertfordshire Constabulary spokesman said: \"Whilst we are asking the public to remain vigilant, people should go about their business as normal at this time. At this stage there is no explicit wider threat to members of the public and no children have been involved.\"\n\nJulie Harrington, the chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority has shared a message of condolence for John Hunt, who she describes as a \"great friend of many in our sport\".\n\nIn a statement, she said: \"The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends at this shocking and tragic time. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n\"John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have seen many times before when one of our number is faced with great trauma.\"\n\nThe Home Secretary is urgently considering the findings of a Home Office review to see if tougher crossbow laws need to be introduced in the wake of the deaths of the wife and two daughters of racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nA department spokesman said: \"This is an appalling incident and the Home Secretary is being kept updated by the police.\n\n\"We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced.\n\n\"The Home Secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.\"\n\nChildren at a primary school in Enfield have been kept indoors as police search for a triple murder suspect.\n\nJade-Simone Bacon, headteacher of St Michael's CofE Primary School in Brigadier Hill, in Enfield, said pupils have not been allowed to go outside.\n\nBut parents will be able to pick up their children at \"the normal time\" at the end of the school day, Mrs Bacon confirmed.\n\nShe said \"We've locked both buildings and just kept the children inside. So we've not had them on the field or the playground. It's not a lockdown as in under the desks or hidden or anything, it's just a lighter lockdown.\n\n\"We have just kept them within the building as though it were like a wet playday so we don't cause the children any distress and we keep everything as calm as possible.\"\n\nMrs Bacon said the police carried out a \"reassurance visit\" to the primary school on Wednesday.\n\nThe Ministry of Defence confirmed on Wednesday that the man wanted in connection with the triple murder in Bushey had served briefly in the Armed Forces.\n\nA Whitehall source said: \"He didn't serve very long and he is no longer a serving member of the armed forces. We're not going to speculate which regiment or unit he was in, but look at his age. He didn't serve very long.\"\n\nA near neighbour of the murdered women said Louise Hunt had been left so upset by a recent break up with her boyfriend she had crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nGlyn Nicholas, 77, suggested that Louise had been in a relationship with the man now wanted in connection with the murders of the three women and that the relationship had ended badly.\n\nHe said: \"Louise split up with her boyfriend a few days ago and she crashed her car into a telegraph pole because she was so upset coming home. She's a lovely, caring girl. She runs a dog grooming business in Bushey.\n\n\"Her sister Hannah and mother Carol are lovely as well. It's all so sad. Louise was a sweet, lovely girl. They all were. This is so sad for everyone,\" he said.\n\nAs part of a note sent to BBC 5 Live staff on Wednesday, the organisation described the incident which involved the deaths of the wife and daughters of racing commentator John Hunt as \"utterly devastating\".\n\nThe note read: \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating. Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.\"\n\nKillings involving a crossbow are typically rare but ministers had considered tightening laws in a bid to stop the weapons being used in violent attacks.\n\nCurrently, there is no requirement to have a licence for a crossbow, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nThe previous government looked at bringing in firearms licensing-style rules in the wake of an attempt to kill the late Queen with a crossbow.\n\nWould-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail was encouraged by an AI chatbot to break into Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 with a loaded crossbow to kill the late Queen.\n\nPlans for crossbow owners to face police checks were mooted as part of efforts to \"step up action to prevent violence on our streets\", the Home Office said earlier this year.\n\nThe department launched an eight-week consultation in February to see if there should be a licensing system to control the use, ownership and supply of crossbows, with anyone looking to buy one facing police checks - similar to regulations already in place for firearms.\n\nMessages of condolence have been posted on social media by figures from the racing world.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in a post on X: \"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.\n\nArmed police have searched an address in Rendlesham Road, Enfield, as the manhunt for Kyle Clifford continues.\n\nThe house, close to Gordon Hill railway station, was swarmed by officers on Wednesday morning, according to neighbours.\n\nTwo officers stood guard outside the property at 1.30pm, after a cordon was removed.\n\nOne neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: \"They kept going in and out of the property carrying guns, the whole road was taped off.\n\n\"It was over quite quickly but there's been helicopters flying around the area all day.\n\n\"I don't recognise the suspect at all, as far as I'm concerned he didn't live in the house.\"\n\nAnother Rendlesham Road resident said: \"It was quite the shock seeing all the guns and dogs, the road went from quiet to manic out of nowhere.\n\n\"They were shouting 'armed police' and pointing their guns so it was clearly quite a serious matter.\n\nSt Michael's Primary School in Enfield is reportedly under lockdown as police search for a suspected crossbow killer.\n\nPupils at the school are being kept inside as the hunt for Kyle Clifford continues, according to its headteacher.\n\nPolice are said to have carried out \"a reassurance visit\", according to Sky News.\n\nTwo helicopters have been seen circling the Hilly Fields Park near Enfield opposite Clifford's home.\n\nA \"co-ordinated search\" is reportedly taking place and a car of possible interest has been found.\n\nOliver Dowden, the Member of Parliament for Hertsmere, has said he is\"deeply concerned\" about the triple murder in Bushey.\n\nPosting on X, formerly Twitter, he said:\n\nJonathan Ash-Edwards, Hertfordshire police and crime commissioner, said: \"My thoughts are with the family and friends of the women who have been shockingly killed in this terrible incident in Bushey.\n\n\"It will no doubt send shockwaves through the local community and across Hertfordshire.\n\n\"I am being kept updated by the police and I urge the public to support the police with any information about the whereabouts of the named suspect.\"\n\nThe wife of BBC 5 Live racing commentator John Hunt, who was the victim of a crossbow attack, has been pictured.\n\nShe and her two daughters were found dead in their family home in Bushey on Tuesday.\n\nMr Hunt is thought to have raised the alarm at around 7pm upon returning to the property on Ashlyn Close.\n\nPolice gave an update on the search for a suspected triple murderer who is thought to be in possession of a crossbow.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, of Hertfordshire Police, spoke at a press conference shortly after 12.30pm on Wednesday.\n\nHe revealed the ages of the victims and made a personal plea to Kyle Clifford to hand himself in.\n\nThe wife and two daughters of the BBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt are thought to be the victims of the triple crossbow murder in Bushey.\n\nEmergency Services were called to the Hunt family home on Tuesday evening following reports that three women had been found with serious injuries.\n\nIt is believed Mr Hunt, who is married with three daughters, had been working for the BBC racing on Tuesday and may have raised the alarm when he returned to the home in Hertfordshire at around 7pm.\n\nThe three women died at the scene shortly after paramedics arrived.\n\nHertfordshire Police has issued an urgent appeal for Clifford, 26, from the Enfield area who is wanted in connection with the incident.\n\nMr Hunt, 58, who is a former police officer, has worked for BBC Radio Five Live for the last 20-years.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, addressed Clifford personally in the press conference.\n\nHe said: \"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nKyle Clifford is believed to be carrying a crossbow but other weapons may also have been used, police said.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, said: \"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nManhunt involves armed police officers and specialist search teams who are responding \"at pace\" to the \"horrific incident\", Jon Simpson, Chief Superintendent said.\n\nHe said: \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\n\n\"We have extensive police resources deployed to various locations in north London and also the Bushey area.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent, said the victims of the Bushey murders were aged 25, 28 and 61-years-old.\n\nA press conference is set to start following the triple murder in Bushey.\n\nJon Simpson, Chief Superintendent of Hertfordshire Police is set to speak.\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass, who lives close by the scene in Bushey, said: \"I didn't know them personally but I knocked on their door, I was canvassing a few days ago for the General Election.\n\n\"I'm sure that their friends will be comforting the remains of the family that are left. These are all my representatives, I know them all.\n\n\"At 7pm last night a helicopter landed on the lawn in the development I live in which is 100 yards away from here, but it was an air ambulance, I'm told, and then rumours started circulating about a crossbow.\n\n\"The worst thing that's ever happened in this part of Bushey is a bit of illegal flytipping and then suddenly we get three murders and we're all a bit shellshocked.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb, we don't get this sort of thing in this area and I want residents to know that the council will be ensuring that the liaison team is down here and doing everything they can to comfort them and make sure that they are reassured that everything is being done.\n\n\"But we're worried that this guy is still floating around somewhere.\"\n\nA resident of Ashlyn Close in Bushey where police are investigating the murders of three women said they heard screaming on Tuesday evening as the \"absolutely traumatic\" incident unfolded.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, told the PA news agency: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\nThe woman said she was upset and stressed to know a man sought in connection with the triple murder is still at large, adding: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nPolice are expected to hold a press conference at 12.30pm.\n\nWe'll be bringing you live updates and a stream of the conference.\n\nThe Home Secretary is being kept \"fully updated\" on the killings of the three women who were found in Bushey, Hertfordshire, and has urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nYvette Cooper said in a post on X, formerly Twitter: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community.\n\n\"I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support [Hertfordshire Police] with any information about this case.\"\n\nAerial footage of the scene show a blue and white forensic tent in the front garden of one of the homes in the cul de sac, with a police officer on guard and several police vehicles parked nearby.\n\nLocal councillor Laurence Brass, who lives nearby, said the area is \"a typical leafy British suburb\".\n\nHe told the BBC: \"At about eight o'clock last night, I was watching the football on television, and suddenly a helicopter landed in the lawn outside my flat, which is at the top of this road, and then my phone started going, and I was told that there was a major incident here in Bushey and we should all keep away because there was somebody apparently on the run.\n\n\"This is not something that happens in Bushey.\n\n\"We can't remember a murder in our rather quiet neck of the woods, so [it's a] terrible shock and our sympathies and prayers and thoughts are with the families of the three women.\n\n\"That really is a terrible thing to happen to anybody, and I've gathered they're all from the same family, which obviously makes it even more tragic, and we'll do everything we can as the local council to add our source of comfort where we can.\"\n\nSarah Fernandez, 52, arrived back home just after 7.30pm to find Ashlyn Close swarming with armed police.\n\nShe said: \" I was the last car allowed into the street before the police closed off access. There were about 15 armed police vehicles parked up. It's really frightening. We've never had anything like this before here.\"\n\nAerial footage of Ashlyn Close in Bushey where three women died on Tuesday.\n\nPolice officers have been pictured at the scene of the crime with a cordon in place on Ashlyn Close.\n\nResidents are \"deeply shocked\" after three women were found dead at a home in Bushey.\n\nRiaz Hussein, a telecoms specialist in his late 50s, told The Telegraph: \"It's absolutely terrifying. Everyone around here is deeply shocked.\n\n\"This is a lovely friendly street where everyone gets on. Lots of professionals live here and we all get on very well. I'm stunned at what's happened.\"\n\nMr Hussein added: \"I don't recognise the man wanted in connection with this from the picture police have released. I've not noticed him around here before.\"\n\nCounty Councillor Laurence Brass echoed the dismay felt by local residents.\n\n\"It's a shock for everyone on the street,\" he said. \"The worst thing that usually happens around here is fly tipping and now we've got three people dead. Utterly shocking.\"\n\nPolice are searching for Kyle Clifford in Enfield, north London, where he lives and Bushey, Hertfordshire, where the three women were found seriously injured and later died.\n\nAn East of England Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called around 7pm on Tuesday July 9 to a property in Ashlyn Close in Bushey.\n\n\"Three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, an ambulance officer vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team, the Essex and Herts Air Ambulance and London Air Ambulance were sent to the scene.\n\n\"Sadly, despite the team's best efforts, three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\"\n\nA neighbour, who did not want to be named, said she did not know the victims well but they were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said.\n\n\"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nLocal councillors have paid tribute to the three women, adding they are \"deeply shocked and saddened\" by the incident.\n\nThey called the deaths \"tragic\" and extended their condolences to those affected.\n\nLouise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards, who are local councillors for the area, said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry to contact police.\"\n\nPolice were called to a property in Ashlyn Close at around 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nOfficers attended the scene alongside the East of England Ambulance Service.\n\nOfficers from Enfield Metropolitan Police are appealing for witnesses following a suspected triple murder.\n\nLocal residents reported a \"huge police presence\" in Bushey overnight and into the morning, with a force helicopter seen in the grounds of the former American University.\n\nOne X user posted: \"It's on my road, Ashlyn Close - It's cordoned off. There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n\"We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.\"\n\nAnother social media user, called Stu, added before details of the attacks emerged: \"Huge police presence in Bushey tonight, and a chopper at the old American University, hope it's nothing too serious.\"\n\nA helicopter has been photographed nearby Ashlyn Close following a suspected triple murder on Tuesday.\n\nRob Hall Detective Superintendent from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away. He may still be in possession of a weapon.\n\n\"Our enquires will continue over the coming days to ascertain the full circumstances of what happened but I would also like to take this opportunity appeal to anyone who was in the area around Ashlyn Close from around lunchtime on Tuesday until 7pm, and believes they may have seen anything that could assist the investigation, to contact us.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Officers from the Neighbourhood Policing Team will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"\n\nOfficers have been searching overnight for Clifford, of Enfield, north London. Hertfordshire Police urged anyone with information to come forward and said the suspect is likely in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nMembers of the public have been told not to approach Clifford.\n\nA neighbourhood policing team has been deployed in the local area to reassure residents.\n\nWe're bringing you the latest updates as police launch a manhunt after three women were found the same car understood to have been found abandoned earlier today.\n\nA full-size crossbow could shoot bolts accurately up to 250ft - raising the terrifying prospect victims may not even see their shooter before being hit.\n\nIn the clip - "title": "UK police detain crossbow attack suspect after three women killed", "body": "The three women were killed on Tuesday night in Bushey, near Watford, north of London\n\nUK police said Wednesday a 26-year-old man was in custody after the wife and two daughters of a radio racing commentator were killed with a crossbow in a suspected \"targeted\" attack.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield in north London, was wanted in connection with the deaths of the three women in the town of Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, the 61-year-old wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters, Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, the broadcasters said.\n\nIn a statement Wednesday, police said Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims\" and no additional suspects were being sought.\n\nClifford was \"receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries,\" police said.\n\nNo formal arrests have yet been made, police later said.\n\nLocal police previously said officers were called to a house in the leafy commuter town where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson called it \"a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\nA primary school in nearby Enfield kept children indoors during the police search.\n\nThere is no licence required to own a crossbow in the UK, but it is illegal to carry one in public without a reasonable excuse.\n\nInterior minister Yvette Cooper called the deaths \"truly shocking\" and said she was being kept updated about the inquiry.\n\nA spokeswoman for her department said legislation was \"under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced\".\n\nShe said the minister would \"swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further\".\n\n- 'Shocking' -\n\nBBC Radio Five Live sent a note to staff calling the incident \"utterly devastating\".\n\nWednesday evening, Hunt's colleague presenter Mark Chapman offered tearful condolences on air, saying, \"This has been a heartbreaking day.\"\n\nSky Sports Racing said on X that the team was \"deeply saddened by the tragic deaths\" and \"our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time\".\n\nNear the Hunt home, neighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who came to lay flowers by the scene of the tragedy, said, \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family.\"\n\nAnother neighbour told reporters the victims were a friendly family.\n\n\"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nIn March, a 47-year-old man was arrested after two people were injured in separate crossbow attacks in London's Shoreditch area.\n\nLast October Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was jailed after being found in the grounds of Windsor Castle, west of London, with a loaded crossbow.\n\nHe broke into the royal residence on Christmas Day 2021 and told police he was trying to kill Queen Elizabeth II.\n\naks/phz/giv/nro\n\nMore from this section\n\nDovenmuehle's Bernadette McDonnell named 2024 Mortgage Star Award Winner by Mortgage Women Magazine\n\nDr. Anju were victims of a deadly crossbow attack at their home.\n\nJohn's wife Carol, 61, and daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were found fatally injured at their \u00a3800,000 detached home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, from Enfield, is being hunted by police and is believed to be armed and dangerous.\n\nBBC stalwart John Hunt has worked at the corporation for 30 years as a racing commentator and previous to this worked as a police officer.\n\nThe BBC stalwart has often spoke lovingly about his family and credited his wife Carol with his broadcasting career after she spotted an advert in the Harrow Observer for a job as a trainee broadcaster.\n\nJohn with his wife Carol, who was found with fatal injuries at their \u00a3800,000 detached house in Bushey, Hertfordshire last night\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nHunt, a regular racetrack caller and frequent presenter on At the Races, is now most widely heard as the commentary voice for the sport on BBC 5Live.\n\nHis work on the national sport's network has widened to occasional football commentary and also coverage of the equestrian events at the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nBefore establishing himself as a race track legend, John had initially been recitent at leaving the police force as he would have to take a paycut.\n\nHowever, it was his devoted wife Carole who pushed him along the path telling him he'd enjoy it as he loved horse racing.\n\nAfter joining BBC Radio Five Live in 2004, he has never looked Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPolice said the three women -- ages 25, 28 and 61 -- were found seriously injured in a house in Bushey, northwest of London, on Tuesday evening. Police and ambulance crews tried to save them, but they were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nBBC Radio 5 Live, the corporation's main news and sports radio channel, said the victims were Carol Hunt, wife of its commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\nJohn Hunt is BBC radio's main horse racing commentator, his voice known to millions through his coverage of the world famous Grand National and The Derby. Carol, Hannah, and Louise Hunt were killed at their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, with the emergency services alerted at 7pm on Tuesday, July 9.\n\nClifford was is being treated for injuries. No shots were fired by police. He has not been arrested\n\nSocial media footage appeared to show emergency services heading towards a cemetery, where armed officers were also spotted. Despite this, Hertfordshire Police were unable to confirm whether they had narrowed their search for the triple murder suspect to the area.\n\nFrst responders arrived at the home of BBC Racing presenter John Hunt at approximately 7pm on Tuesday (July 9). His wife Carol, 61, alongside daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were found dead at the property.\n\nIt is suspected that the victims were subjected to a 'targeted' crossbow assault, although Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson has indicated that additional weapons might have been involved.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\"\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\"\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case. We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. {"uri": "8218801042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:35:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:35:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:33:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/manhunt-launched-u-k-crossbow-131758112.html", "title": "Manhunt launched in the U.K. for crossbow-wielding triple murder suspect", "body": "LONDON -- A manhunt has been launched for a crossbow-wielding suspect Wednesday after three women in the same family were killed in a house north of London, police said.\n\nAuthorities warned the public not to approach Kyle Clifford, 26, who is wanted in connection with the triple murder and may still be armed with the bolt-firing weapon.\n\nInvestigators believe the victims were targeted specifically in this \"horrific incident,\" Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, of Hertfordshire Police, told a news conference. The women, aged 25, 28 and 61, are believed to have been related, he said.\n\nThe BBC identified the victims as Carol Hunt, wife of BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, and two of their daughters.\n\n\"Extensive police resources\" -- including armed police, a relative rarity in largely-unarmed Britain -- have been deployed across the local county of Hertfordshire and adjacent north London, he added.\n\nEarlier police had urged the public to avoid approaching the suspect, warning that he may still be carrying the crossbow. They said other weapons may have been used in the killings which happened at 7 p.m. local time Tuesday (2 p.m. ET) in the small town of Bushey, northwest of London,\n\nThese types of incidents are rare and shocking in Britain, where the murder rate is more than six times lower than in the United States, according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.\n\nThat's largely due to Britain's far stricter gun laws, although knife crime and stabbings have risen in recent years and become a hot-button issue in British politics.\n\nCrossbow killings are very uncommon, with fewer than 10 in the U.K. between 2011 and 2021, the government says. There are no laws on who can buy or own one so long as they are aged 18 or over. But anyone carrying one of these weapons in public without a reasonable excuse can face four years in jail.\n\nIn February, the government said it was exploring toughening those restrictions, citing an incident on Christmas Day 2021 when Jaswant Singh Chail, aged 19, arrived at Windsor Castle with a crossbow and planned to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II.\n\nBritain's newly elected interior minister Yvette Cooper called this week's incident \"truly shocking\" and that she was being kept updated.\n\nOfficers were called to a suburban street lined with generous, detached houses to find three women with serious injuries, police said in a statement. Despite efforts by paramedics to save the women, all three died at the scene.\n\n\"This is an incredibly difficult incident for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" Det. {"uri": "8219386936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "21:12:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T21:12:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T21:11:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/piercing-screams-then-silence-how-crossbow-killer-terrorised-quiet-cul-de-sac-by-slaying-his-ex-girlfriend-her-sister-and-her-mother-after-a-messy-breakup-before-seemingly-shooting-himself-in-a-c/", "title": "Piercing screams, then silence: How crossbow killer terrorised quiet cul-de-sac by slaying his ex-girlfriend, her sister and her mother after a 'messy breakup' before seemingly shooting himself in a cemetery following huge police manhunt", "body": "It was a scene of unimaginable horror that left even hardened detectives shaken. A defenceless mother and her two daughters tied up in their own home and shot dead with a 3ft-long crossbow in a bloody rampage.\n\nAround 6.30pm on Tuesday, neighbours of a \u00a3800,000 suburban home in a quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey, Hertfordshire, heard piercing screams which were initially mistaken for that of a distressed child.\n\nLater they were to realise that it was a woman's desperate cries for help coming from the home where Louise Hunt, 25, her sister Hannah, 28, and mother Carol, 61, were ambushed by a crossbow-wielding killer.\n\nSoon after the screams fell silent, the assailant fled the property, by which time the police had been alerted and were on their way.\n\nIt is believed that on finding his wife and daughters fatally wounded, officers were able to contact BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, a voice known to millions, who was returning from working at Lingfield Park course.\n\nLouise Hunt, 25, (pictured) was the ex-girlfriend of suspect Kyle Clifford and was one of the three women found dead in the family home\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, and her mother Carol Hunt, 61, were also found dead in the family home\n\nBBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured) is a voice known to millions\n\nAlthough police and ambulance had rushed to the house, they were unable to save the three victims who died at the scene.\n\nBut it wasn't long before detectives were on the trail of a suspect after a figure was seen darting out of an alleyway directly behind the murder scene. Clad in black, the man was captured on camera calmly striding away with what appeared to be a crossbow tucked under his arm hidden beneath a white sheet.\n\nFootage from a nearby doorcam showed the bearded figure carrying a heavy bag, which police feared may be a cache of weapons he used to carry out the brutal attack.\n\nChillingly, he passed within feet of a female neighbour, who stood alone on her driveway stroking a cat and seemed startled by the sight of the barely concealed weapon at 6.50pm.\n\nWithin hours, a national manhunt was under way for former soldier Kyle Clifford, who was named by police in a highly unusual step. The 26-year-old had previously served in the Queen's Dragoon Guards for a short time before dropping out having failed to impress superiors, it was said last night.\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left her so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nHannah, 28, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago\n\nA huge manhunt is underway to find suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, who is the ex-boyfriend of John's daughter Louise\n\nA police car is parked by Ashley Close in Bushey in the borough of Hertfordshire, north of London\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house. I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it.\n\n'A friend of Louise's told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.'\n\nHe added: 'Carol was a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'They were all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\n'A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. They'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years.'\n\nMrs Hunt, a mother of three, had recently told friends at her local gym that her youngest daughter was involved in a 'messy break-up' with her boyfriend.\n\nOne suggested her daughter's relationship had turned nasty.\n\nA friend said: 'She said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nPolice yesterday warned the public not to approach the suspect, who was last seen driving off from the cul-de sac in a grey vehicle the previous evening.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left Louise so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home\n\nThe man received medical assistance before being taken to Royal London Hospital\n\nKyle Clifford dropped out of the army weeks before he is alleged to have murder three people\n\nArmed police searching Lavender Hill cemetery in Enfield as the hunt for fugitive Kyle Clifford took a new turn\n\nOne neighbour said 'absolute chaos' broke out as armed police arrived. She said: 'It was between 6.30pm and 7pm and it sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'That's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n'We had armed police running down, screaming, 'Stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.' Police searches predominantly focused yesterday on Hertfordshire and North London because the police did not believe their suspect had the time to get much further.\n\nPassengers arriving at London Victoria railway station during the morning rush hour, before news of the tragedy became public, found their exit slowed as they were unusually marshalled through the barriers, allowing ranks of police on the opposite side to scan the crowd, checking every face.\n\nLater, local schools were put into lockdown when armed police raided the suspect's home in Enfield, North London, some 14 miles from the crime scene.\n\nOne mother said: 'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into. They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.'\n\nDozens of officers from Scotland Yard and Hertfordshire Police flooded the area a short time later after finding Clifford's abandoned car. But within hours, the hunt had moved to a nearby cemetery just a few minutes' walk away. The former security guard was later found with self-inflicted injuries at Lavender Hill Cemetery just after 4.30pm after seemingly shooting himself with the crossbow.\n\nIn a burst of intense activity, armed police closed down the cemetery, as eyewitnesses saw paramedics running into the grounds.\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local who filmed the commotion, said: 'I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\n\n'I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.'\n\nAround 20 minutes later Clifford was stretchered from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he was receiving medical treatment last night.\n\nPolice confirmed no shots had been fired by officers and nobody else was being sought.\n\nMr Hunt, himself a former police officer before he took up radio and became a much-loved personality on the horse racing circuit, was said to be inconsolable last night. In a note to staff, the BBC said: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nJulie Harrington, chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority, said: 'The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n'John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have seen many times before when one of our number is faced with great trauma.'\n\nLast night neighbours and friends continued to lay flowers at the scene. One friend, Su Kehinde, 60, who lives nearby, said she would remember them as 'beautiful souls'. She said: 'They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.'\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'.\n\nShe added: 'She was hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle.'\n\nSix years ago, Clifford's older brother was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey.\n\nBradley Clifford, a plumber, was 23 when he mowed down Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, on their moped after they struck his 'prized' Ford Mustang car with a bottle.\n\nBoth teenagers were flung from the moped by the impact, and Bradley Clifford beat Mr Khan as he lay on the ground injured.\n\nThe incident followed a row outside a bar in Enfield in which Clifford's car received superficial damage. He flew into a rage and pursued the pair in a 20-minute high speed chase before crashing into the moped.\n\nClifford was jailed for life and told to serve at least 23 years for the murder of Mr Khan
