{"uri": "2024-07-417961467", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "22:27:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T22:27:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T22:17:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/07/10/bbc-commentator-john-hunt-wife-daughters-crossbow-killings-suspect-captured/", "title": "Suspect nabbed in crossbow killings of BBC commentator John Hunt's wife and daughters", "body": "The man suspected of killing BBC commentator John Hunt's wife and his two adult daughters with a crossbow on Tuesday was captured by police after nearly 24 hours on the run.\n\nKyle Clifford, 26, who's believed to be the former boyfriend of one of the daughters, was found in North London \"following an extensive search,\" the local constabulary said.\n\nThe man was taken into custody without incident and is being treated for injuries sustained prior to his discovery. No shots were fired when he was apprehended.\n\n\"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,\" Major Crime Unit Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins said.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\"\n\nThe three women were killed in the attack around 7 p.m. local time Tuesday night in Bushey, a town north of London, spurring a manhunt. They have only been officially identified by their ages, 25, 28 and 61, but police described the incident as \"targeted.\"\n\nAccording to Sky News, those ages match the ages of Hunt's wife, Carol, and daughters Hannah and Louise.\n\nThe BBC reported Hunt's wife, Carol, and two daughters were slain, while a third daughter was not harmed.\n\nClifford was found at Lavender Hill Cemetery in Enfield and carried away in a stretcher, Sky News reported. Enfield is about 20 miles east of Bushey, where the murders occurred.\n\nPrior to locating Clifford, a large police presence descended on the area, including several officers in tactical gear carrying long guns.\n\nPolice had earlier warned the public to stay away from Clifford if they came into contact with him as the British Army vet was believed to still have the weapon used in the killings.\n\nCrossbows are legal in the U.K., albeit with strict stipulations for use and display. In the wake of the murders, the Home Office is now weighing whether tougher crossbow laws should be enacted, the BBC reported. The office had started considering new laws earlier this year in response to a spate of other crimes committed with crossbows.\n\n\"The home secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further,\" a spokesperson said Wednesday.\n\nJohn Hunt is a radio horse racing commentator for BBC Racing and for Sky Sports Racing.\n\n\"The news today about John Hunt's family {"uri": "8218972408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:23:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:23:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:23:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/manhunt-under-way-after-3-women-killed-with-crossbow-5683535", "title": "Manhunt Under Way After 3 Women Killed With Crossbow", "body": "A manhunt is under way after three woman were killed in a crossbow attack at their home in Bushey, on the outskirts of London on Tuesday night.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, and her two daughters, aged 25 and 28, were killed at their home in Hertfordshire.\n\nThe BBC has confirmed Ms. Hunt was married to horse racing commentator John Hunt.\n\nHertfordshire Police, assisted by other forces, has launched a manhunt for the 26-year-old suspect, Kyle Clifford, who is believed to still be in possession of the crossbow.\n\nPolice say he is believed to be in Hertfordshire or north London.\n\nArmed police searched a house in Enfield, north London on Wednesday morning but there was no trace of the suspect.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson from Hertfordshire Police told a press conference the victims had been \"targeted\" and there was no reason to believe the suspect posed a threat to the general public.\n\nHe said, \"Our overarching objective today is to protect public safety and to locate Kyle Clifford, who is wanted in connection with the murder of the three women in what we believe is a targeted incident.\"\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used,\" he added.\n\nThe danger from crossbows has been highlighted several times over the years.\n\nIn November 2018 Ramanodge Unmathallegadoo, 51, used one of the weapons to kill his pregnant ex-wife, Devi, 35, at her home in Ilford, east London. Her unborn baby miraculously survived.\n\nThe then-Prime Minister Theresa May said her government would \"consider the risk to public safety and whether further measures are needed.\"\n\nWhen would-be assassin Jaswant Singh Chail, armed with a loaded crossbow, was arrested in the grounds of Windsor Castle on Christmas Day 2021 the then-Home Secretary Priti Patel promised to review the law surrounding crossbows.\n\nLast year Chail was jailed for nine years after admitting an offence under the Treason Act.\n\nBryce Hodgson, 30, had pleaded guilty to a stalking offence at Croydon Crown Court in July 2023 and was given a suspended prison sentence of 16 weeks.\n\nThen in February this year the government finally unveiled plans to outlaw the sale of crossbows except under strict conditions.\n\nBuyers would be subject to strict police checks, as are already in place for firearms.\n\nThe Home Office completed the work in April but no legislation was introduced before the general election campaign began.\n\nSeveral figures from the horse racing world have posted condolences on social media platform X.\n\nITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to [Mr. Hunt] and family today.\n\n\"Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you,\" he added.\n\nThe Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain also sent their sympathies on X.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", The tragic incident, which the police termed 'targeted', happened Tuesday as the Hertfordshire Police were called to the murder site just before 7 pm local time. The police found the three women, aged 25, 28 and 61, with critical injuries.\n\nEmergency services were rushed to the scene, including a Hazardous Area Response Team and two air ambulances. However, the ladies were pronounced dead on the scene by the doctors.\n\nPolice have identified the suspect as Kyle Clifford and issued an appeal to the public regarding his whereabouts. The authorities have advised people not to approach Clifford as he may still be in possession of the crossbow that he may have used in the murder. Police didn't rule out the possibility of the use of some other weapon.\n\nMeanwhile, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said she was constantly being briefed about the situation by the officials. She also urged members of the public with any information to hand it over to police.\n\n\"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family & friends of those who have been killed & with the community,\" she said.\n\nLocal city councillor Laurence Brass told local media that the incident had left him \"very shocked.\"\n\nAlso read: UK faces fiscal tightrope: IMF urges reforms amid high debt\n\n\"We're not used to this in this area, it's a very typical, leafy Bushey suburb... and suddenly we're told there are three murders. We had a helicopter landing at the top of my road last night, police all over the place. So, I'm concerned for residents, who I think are a little bit traumatised by what's going on here,\" he said.\n\nNotably, people can carry crossbows legally in the UK without having to obtain any government approval. They died at the scene.\n\nHertfordshire triple murder: Where is Kyle Clifford?\n\nLocal top detective Rob Hall asked those who know Kyle Clifford to contact police, and not to approach him as he may still be carrying arms.\n\nAlso read: Human plague case reported in Colorado, US: Know about bubonic plague - cause, symptoms, treatment\n\n\"Whilst we are still in the early stages of this investigation, we are actively seeking Kyle Clifford who we believe could be in the areas of Hertfordshire or North London,\" Hall said.\n\n\"Given the serious nature of the incident, I would ask anyone who knows where he is to contact police immediately. three women killed every three days.\n\nEverard, 33, was kidnapped and killed by a serving police officer on 3 March 2021.\n\nIn February this year, a United Nations human rights expert said the UK {"uri": "2024-07-417449027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:51:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:51:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:47:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/29089308/kyle-clifford-manhunt-three-women-murdered-hertfordshire-update/", "title": "Dramatic moment cops storm home in search for 'crossbow killer' as car found", "body": "One horrified local told how armed cops swarmed the quiet residential street last night\n\nA DOZEN cops have raided a property amid the manhunt for Kyle Clifford after three women were \"murdered\" in a \"targeted incident\".\n\nTwo helicopters were spotted circling the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, North London, as armed police stormed a home amid their search for the 'murder' suspect.\n\nFootage obtained by The Sun showed police dogs and around 12 specialist cops raided the terraced home on Rendlesham Road in North London, at 11.30am this morning.\n\nOne officer can be heard screaming: \"Armed Police, come to the door and raise your hands\" as cops barrage through the front of the property.\n\nIt is unclear who or what cops discovered in the home but at least two officers are still at the scene of the raid.\n\nA source said: \"It's a really heavy response -- and shocking for everyone to see.\n\n\"They charged in and spent quite a while in the home. It didn't seem like anyone was there\".\n\nResidents claimed they've been told a \"coordinated search\" is underway in the area and local primary schools have been urged to keep children inside.\n\nNearby St Michael's Primary School has been put under lockdown after the triple murder.\n\nA \"car of possible interest\" has also been located at the Hilly Fields scene.\n\nIt is understood cops have found Clifford's vehicle, a black Seat hatchback.\n\nThe manhunt suspect is believed to have driven from the scene was found abandoned earlier.\n\nHertfordshire Constabulary have warned the public \"not to approach\" suspect Clifford, 26, as their specialist search continues.\n\nIt comes after three women were discovered seriously injured at a property in Bushey, Hertfordshire, yesterday evening.\n\nThe victims, aged 25, 28 and 61-years-old, sadly could not be saved despite the best efforts of paramedics.\n\nIn their latest update, Superintendent Jon Simpson confirmed the force believe the horror was \"a targeted incident\" involving \"what is believed to be a crossbow but other weapons may also have been used\".\n\n\"If any members of the public see Kyle Clifford they are urged not to approach him at any point and dial 999 immediately,\" urged the Supt.\n\nHe also issued a personal message to Clifford, and urged the suspect to contact police.\n\n\"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact with police via 999,\" he said.\n\nClifford, from Enfield in North London, may still be in possession of a crossbow, police warned earlier.\n\nThe force urged anyone who sees him to call 999 immediately.\n\n'SIRENS AND SHOUTING'\n\nOne horrified local told how armed cops swarmed the quiet residential street last night.\n\nFrancis Turner, who was watching the Spain v France game at the time, told how she heard shouting outside.\n\nShe told The Sun: \"My husband and I were watching the football when we heard sirens and shouting. There were around 30 policemen outside.\n\n\"There were armed police. They came and knocked on our door and told us to stay inside and keep our doors shut.\n\n\"My heart goes out to them. I feel very sad for the family, my heart goes out to them.\"\n\nAnother local Dereck Turner, who took a photo of armed police outside, said: \"It's a very quiet and peaceful area, it's close to everything, when a house comes up it's gone.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Simon Powler, 49, a tennis coach who lives nearby to the scene in Bushey, added: \"I got told to go inside because a man might be on the loose with a crossbow.\"\n\n'HUGE POLICE PRESENCE'\n\nOther stunned residents told how more than a dozen emergency vehicles were scrambled to the quiet residential street last night.\n\nOne person said: \"It's on my road Ashlyn Close It's cordoned off. There were 11 police cars, an armed response unit, 4 ambulances and a fire engine.\n\n\"We're not allowed to park on our driveway and have had to park round the corner. Whatever happened, it's really bad and everyone is shaken up.\"\n\nAnother resident said there was a \"huge police presence\" in the area.\n\nSomeone else who lives in Ashlyn Close said they heard screaming as the \"absolutely traumatic\" horror unfolded.\n\nThe 46-year-old, who did not wish to share their name, said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors.\n\n\"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help,\" she added.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone.\n\n\"I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nEast of England Ambulance Service confirmed three ambulances, a rapid response vehicle, the Hazardous Area Response Team and two air ambulances were sent to the scene.\n\nLouise Nicolas, Alan Matthews and Paul Richards, who are local councillors for the area, paid tribute to the women.\n\nThey said: \"We are deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news that three women have lost their lives in a violent incident which took place in the heart of our local community.\n\n\"As North Bushey councillors, we extend our thoughts and condolences to their families and all those affected.\n\n\"We would encourage anyone who has information relevant to the inquiry "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/29120562/bbc-star-found-wife-two-daughters-crossbow-dead/", "title": "BBC star 'found wife & two daughters tied up and shot dead with crossbow'", "body": "BBC racing commentator John Hunt found his wife and two of his daughters \"tied up and shot with a crossbow\" when he got home from work.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61 and daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28, were tragically found dead inside their home last night.\n\nAfter discovering the horrific scene at 7pm on Tuesday, BBC Radio 5 Live and Sky TV correspondent Mr Hunt dialled 999 and police and ambulances raced to the cul-de-sac in Bushey, Herts.\n\nParamedics and cops tried to save the three victims but they were all pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nPolice launched a huge manhunt and tonight a man aged 26 was arrested in a cemetery in Enfield, North London, on suspicion of the triple murder.\n\nDetectives had earlier named former soldier Kyle Clifford as their prime suspect.\n\nHe was seen being bundled into the back of an ambulance this afternoon after armed police and paramedics swooped on a cemetery in Hilly Fields in Enfield, North London.\n\nThey warned anyone who saw him not to approach but to call 999 immediately.\n\nIt is understood Clifford had until recently been in a relationship with younger daughter Louise.\n\nCCTV footage obtained by The Sun showed a suspect walking away from the murder scene with a large object under a sheet.\n\nThe man, dressed in black, also carried a bag which he placed in the rear of a Seat car along with a large crossbow-shaped item.\n\nHe appeared calm as he made his apparent getaway.\n\nOne local said: \"You can see clearly from the outline of what is under the sheet that it is in the shape of a crossbow -- it's massive.\"\n\nThe car was later found abandoned in Enfield, close to Clifford's family home.\n\nArmed police carried out a swoop at the address as a massive search of the area's parks and woodland was also carried out.\n\nAround 12 gun cops with dogs burst into the terraced property at 11.30am.\n\nOne officer can be heard screaming: \"Armed police, come to the door and raise your hands.\"\n\nA source said: \"It's a really heavy response -- and shocking for everyone to see. They charged in and spent quite a while in the home. It didn't seem like anyone was there.\"\n\nA primary school in the area was also put into lockdown.\n\nHead Jade-Simone Bacon said: \"We've locked both buildings and just kept the children inside.\"\n\nDog units, helicopters and drones were deployed amid fears Clifford, who served as a Queen's Dragoon Guards trooper, could use military skills to hide out in the area on the edge of green belt land.\n\nA search of the Hilly Fields Park was carried out as armed officers from the Met and City of London Police joined the hunt.\n\nCops also scoured Lavender Hill Cemetery with mourners being turned away.\n\nHertfordshire Police Chief Supt Jon Simpson earlier urged Clifford to give himself up.\n\nAddressing Clifford directly, he said: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nSources confirmed that Clifford had recently broken up with Louise.\n\nShe ran a dog grooming business called Groom and Glow from the family's detached home while sister Hannah had her own cosmetics business.\n\nNeighbours described them as beautiful girls, while one local said Louise was so upset at the recent break-up that she crashed her car.\n\nGlyn Nicholas, 77, said: \"Louise was a very nice girl.\n\n\"She ran a dog grooming business from the house. I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it.\n\n\"So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house.\"\n\nSources said Clifford served for two years with the Queen's Dragoon Guards, a light cavalry regiment but has now been working in private security.\n\nMr Hunt and a surviving daughter are being comforted by family and friends.\n\nHe was working at a race meeting at Lingfield Park in Surrey on Tuesday before returning home to find the horror scene.\n\nYesterday, friends left floral tributes outside the house.\n\nNeighbours told how at least 20 police and ambulance vehicles had descended on the road.\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass, who lives 100 yards away, said: \"We're all a bit shell-shocked.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb, we don't get this sort of thing in this area.\"\n\nFrancis Turner, who lives nearby, said: \"My husband and I were watching the football when we heard sirens and shouting. There were around 30 police outside.\n\n\"There were armed police. They came and knocked on our door and told us to stay inside and keep our doors shut.\n\n\"I feel very sad for the family. My heart goes out to them.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she was being kept \"fully updated\" on the killings and urged anyone with information about the case to contact police.\n\nShe tweeted: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking.\n\n\"My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community.\"\n\nThe Home Kyle Clifford was sought in connection with the murders of three women in Bushey, north of London, on Tuesday night.\n\nThe victims were Carol Hunt, wife of BBC radio and Sky Sports racing commentator John Hunt, and their daughters, Louise and Hannah.In a statement on Wednesday, police reported that Clifford, who was found by officers in Enfield, \"was known to the victims,\" and no other suspects are being sought.\n\nClifford is \"receiving medical treatment after being found with injuries,\" UK police said.\n\nLocal authorities earlier said that officers were called to a house in the suburban town, where the three women were pronounced dead at the scene. British media say that he found the bodies early Tuesday evening after returning home from reporting at Lingfield Park racecourse, which is just south of London.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Herfordshire Police said the incident involved a crossbow and other weapons.\n\n\"The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been an horrific incident,\" Simpson said.\n\nPolice did not say whether Clifford, who is from London, was connected to the women.\n\nClifford may still be armed and the public was warned not to approach him. Supt. Rob Hall, from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, in a statement.\n\n\"If you believe you see him, please do not approach him and dial 999 straight away,\" he added, referring to the United Kingdom's emergency number. \"He may still be in possession of a weapon.\"\n\nThese types of incidents are rare and shocking in Britain, where the murder rate is more than six times lower than in the United States, according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.\n\nThat's largely due to Britain's far stricter gun laws, although knife crime and stabbings have risen in recent years and become a hot-button issue in British politics.\n\nCrossbow killings are very uncommon, with fewer than 10 in the U.K. between 2011 and 2021, the government says. There are no laws on who can buy or own one so long as they are aged 18 or over. But anyone carrying one of these weapons in public without a reasonable excuse can face four years in jail.\n\nIn February, the government said it was exploring toughening those restrictions, citing an incident on Christmas Day 2021 when Jaswant Singh Chail, aged 19, arrived at Windsor Castle with a crossbow and planned to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II.\n\nBritain's newly elected interior minister Yvette Cooper called this week's incident \"truly shocking\" and that she was being kept updated.\n\nThe triple murder happened at 7 p.m. local time Tuesday (2 p.m. ET) in the small town of Bushey, northwest of London, according to the Hertfordshire Constabulary, the local police force.\n\nOfficers were called to a suburban street lined with generous, detached houses to find three women with serious injuries, police said in a statement. (Image: Contribtuion)\n\nShe described how \"roughly 20\" emergency vehicles closed off the road as officers ran down to the house.\n\n\"We were told to stay inside and told to close our doors,\" the neighbour added.\n\n\"They knocked on the door and asked us, 'did we hear anything?'.\n\n\"We never heard anything because we were watching the TV. I think by the time police arrived he was gone.\"\n\nEmergency vehicles in Bushey Hall Road, near the entrance to Ashlyn Close and Grove Hall Road. (Image: Watford Observer Camera Club/Rob Cross)\n\nThe three women are believed to be related. Ashlyn Close is a very small road it's really shocking...absolutely shocking and I feel sorry for the family.\n\n\"I'm so sad for the family. It's a shocking thing to happen. It's just a quiet little area.\"\n\nOther members of the public described seeing a helicopter landing at The Royal Connaught Park and police cars lining Bushey Hall Road, near the entrance to Ashlyn Close and Grove Hall Road.\n\nKyle Clifford. {"uri": "8219439934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "22:09:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T22:09:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T22:08:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/grief-washes-over-quiet-leafy-212248132.html", "title": "Grief washes over quiet, leafy Bushey as three women murdered in own home in 'tremendous tragedy'", "body": "Horror, shock and grief have engulfed a quiet, leafy community in Hertfordshire after three women were murdered in their own home in a terrifying attack involving a crossbow.\n\nTributes have been pouring in for the \"gentle, beautiful, friendly\" Hunt family after mother Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were killed in a \"targeted\" incident in their usually peaceful cul-de-sac Ashlyn Close in Bushey on Tuesday evening.\n\nArmed police have now captured suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, following a major manhunt. Detectives said the 26-year-old was found with injuries and was receiving medical treatment after he was apprehended in the Enfield area of north London on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nBBC racing commentator John Hunt - husband of Carol and father to beautician Hannah and Louise, a dog groomer - has been left behind to grapple with the devastating loss of three family members, whose identities were confirmed by the broadcaster. He and Carol are understood to have a third daughter.\n\nShocked and distraught local residents paid tribute to the three victims as \"beautiful souls\" and told The Independent of often seeing the family out walking their dogs together in the local area.\n\nAmong them are Simon and Tracey Bowler, who described the Hunts as \"nice and friendly\" neighbours who would always wave and say \"hello\" as they walked their dogs past the Bowler family's house.\n\nFighting back tears, Ms Bowler, who has lived in Bushey for more than a decade and knows Mr Hunt through the local gym, spoke of how \"emotional\" and \"overwhelming\" it has been. Describing the area as \"quiet and residential\", Mr Bowler said: \"The neighbourhood hasn't stopped being a neighbourhood - it's just really sad.\"\n\nNeighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who laid flowers at a makeshift tribute in the area on Wednesday, said: \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They were the meekest human beings. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.\"\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah \"always had a smile\" and was \"hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle\".\n\nA friend of Louise Hunt, who knew her from their time at school, praised her as \"really sweet, very kind, always a positive person\". He told BBC News: \"I can't think of anything bad to say about her - a really lovely person all round, a super hard-working person.\"\n\nDerek Turner, a neighbour on Ashlyn Close, described the three women's deaths as a \"tremendous tragedy\".\n\nAfter having lived in \"peaceful and quiet\" Bushey for more than 30 years, Mr Turner said the incident has sparked concern. \"We don't really have things like this happen round here,\" he said, describing the area as one with a tight-knit community, beloved by residents, many of whom have lived in the town for years. \"You can never imagine that would happen in your street,\" he said.\n\nAnother neighbour said she grew up with the Hunt family and played with Louise and Hannah when they were all children. Describing the family as \"super nice and friendly\", the 22-year-old woman, who did not want to be named, added that, more recently, she would see John and Carol out dog-walking. \"I feel so bad for the dad,\" said the family friend. \"I saw him just two weeks ago.\"\n\nFloral tributes were piling up by the Ashlyn Close road sign on Wednesday, as mourners arrived crying and holding hands before placing their bouquets and messages at the scene. One tribute addressed to the three women read: \"I wish none of this was real. I wish I could hug you all, and tell you how much you meant to me. I wish you could hug each other. Love you forever.\" Another message said: \"Words cannot express how devastated I am that you're gone. The most gentle beautiful family. Forever loved.\"\n\nPolice officers looked on from the edge of the cordon at the top of the victims' road, with one also seen leaving a flower tribute. Police cars and vans were parked along Ashlyn Close as the triple murder investigation continues.\n\nOfficers were called to the cul-de-sac just before 7pm on Tuesday after neighbours heard screams from the four-bedroom detached family home. The three women were found seriously injured and later pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nA man walking close to the scene with his two young children on Wednesday said: \"It's just devastating. It's shocking to hear in an area where you just want to raise your children and have a nice, happy life.\"\n\nDescribing Bushey as \"so peaceful and quiet\", another local resident said: \"It's just heartbreaking. It's frightening to have it at the doorstep.\"\n\nHertfordshire Constabulary hunted overnight for Clifford, from the Enfield area. Detectives had issued a direct plea to Clifford to contact police on Wednesday as they warned members of the public not to approach him and dial 999.\n\nArmed officers were seen raiding a flat in Enfield and swarming a cemetery, with a nearby primary school put on lockdown, before police confirmed he had been located that afternoon. The force said no shots were fired by police in the search for Clifford, who was feared to be armed with a crossbow.\n\nFootage captured by Sky News appeared to show him being stretchered out of Lavender Hill cemetery before being loaded into an ambulance.\n\nClifford, who is said to be known to the Hunt family, left the British Army in 2022 following a brief period of service, The Independent understands.\n\nA former army boss told The Sun that he was \"immature for his age and had a bit of a chip on his shoulder\", adding that he worked in private security after leaving the force.\n\nIn a note to Mr Hunt's colleagues at BBC 5 Live, the broadcaster offered its condolences and described the tragedy as \"utterly devastating\".", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowling_(cricket)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bowling (cricket)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition_game", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Exhibition game"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bushey", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bushey"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Bushey"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Dog"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_end_(street)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Dead end (street)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Clifford", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kyle Clifford"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._M._W._Turner", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. No shots were fired by officers.\n\nThe Guardian have reported that the three women had ligatures (evidence of being tied up) found near them, as well as ligature marks around their wrists and faces, suggesting that they were initially gagged and bound before the ligatures were removed.\n\nIt is understood that one of the three women had raised the alarm and called 999 as the suspect fled, with one source adding to the Guardian that the women may have been held hostage for a number of hours before their deaths.\n\nClifford, who reportedly served in the British Army for a year and was the ex-boyfriend of Louise, was found in a cemetery in Enfield on Wednesday afternoon, with police bringing him to a 'major trauma centre' after he was apprehended.\n\nFollowing news that a crossbow may have been used in the killings, the UK government's new Home Secretary Yvette Cooper has begun urgently considering the findings of a Home Office review in 2021, which called for tougher laws surrounding the ownership of crossbows.\n\n'We keep legislation under constant review and a call for evidence was launched earlier this year to look at whether further controls on crossbows should be introduced,' a Home Office spokesperson said.\n\n'The home secretary will swiftly consider the findings to see if laws need to be tightened further.'\n\n'This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened,' DI Justine Jenkins, Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said in a statement.\n\n'This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. Carol, Hannah and Louise Hunt were killed in their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, with the alarm raised at 7pm last night (Tuesday, July 9).\n\nHe is receiving medical treatment having been found with injuries. No shots were fired by police. He has not been arrested\n\nFootage posted on social media appeared to show emergency services rushing towards the cemetery. His wife, Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nLIVE: Tributes pour in for John Hunt's wife and 2 daughters\n\nThey are believed to have been attacked with a crossbow in a 'targeted' attack, but Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson said other weapons may have been used.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place. The premature naming of potential victims has caused great upset to the family when they should've been given the space to come to terms with their sudden loss.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case. We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. A defenceless mother and her two daughters tied up in their own home and shot dead with a 3ft-long crossbow in a bloody rampage.\n\nAround 6.30pm on Tuesday, neighbours of a \u00a3800,000 suburban home in a quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey, Hertfordshire, heard piercing screams which were initially mistaken for that of a distressed child.\n\nLater they were to realise that it was a woman's desperate cries for help coming from the home where Louise Hunt, 25, her sister Hannah, 28, and mother Carol, 61, were ambushed by a crossbow-wielding killer.\n\nSoon after the screams fell silent, the assailant fled the property, by which time the police had been alerted and were on their way.\n\nIt is believed that on finding his wife and daughters fatally wounded, officers were able to contact BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, a voice known to millions, who was returning from working at Lingfield Park course.\n\nLouise Hunt, 25, (pictured) was the ex-girlfriend of suspect Kyle Clifford and was one of the three women found dead in the family home\n\nHannah Hunt, 28, and her mother Carol Hunt, 61, were also found dead in the family home\n\nBBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured) is a voice known to millions\n\nAlthough police and ambulance had rushed to the house, they were unable to save the three victims who died at the scene.\n\nBut it wasn't long before detectives were on the trail of a suspect after a figure was seen darting out of an alleyway directly behind the murder scene. Clad in black, the man was captured on camera calmly striding away with what appeared to be a crossbow tucked under his arm hidden beneath a white sheet.\n\nFootage from a nearby doorcam showed the bearded figure carrying a heavy bag, which police feared may be a cache of weapons he used to carry out the brutal attack.\n\nChillingly, he passed within feet of a female neighbour, who stood alone on her driveway stroking a cat and seemed startled by the sight of the barely concealed weapon at 6.50pm.\n\nWithin hours, a national manhunt was under way for former soldier Kyle Clifford, who was named by police in a highly unusual step. The 26-year-old had previously served in the Queen's Dragoon Guards for a short time before dropping out having failed to impress superiors, it was said last night.\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left her so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nHannah, 28, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago\n\nA police car is parked by Ashley Close in Bushey in the borough of Hertfordshire, north of London\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house. I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it.\n\n'A friend of Louise's told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.'\n\nHe added: 'Carol was a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'They were all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\n'A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. They'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years.'\n\nMrs Hunt, a mother of three, had recently told friends at her local gym that her youngest daughter was involved in a 'messy break-up' with her boyfriend.\n\nOne suggested her daughter's relationship had turned nasty.\n\nA friend said: 'She said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nPolice yesterday warned the public not to approach the suspect, who was last seen driving off from the cul-de sac in a grey vehicle the previous evening.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left Louise so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home\n\nOne neighbour said 'absolute chaos' broke out as armed police arrived. She said: 'It was between 6.30pm and 7pm and it sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'That's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n'We had armed police running down, screaming, 'Stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.' Police searches predominantly focused yesterday on Hertfordshire and North London because the police did not believe their suspect had the time to get much further.\n\nPassengers arriving at London Victoria railway station during the morning rush hour, before news of the tragedy became public, found their exit slowed as they were unusually marshalled through the barriers, allowing ranks of police on the opposite side to scan the crowd, checking every face.\n\nLater, local schools were put into lockdown when armed police raided the suspect's home in Enfield, North London, some 14 miles from the crime scene.\n\nOne mother said: 'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into. They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.'\n\nDozens of officers from Scotland Yard and Hertfordshire Police flooded the area a short time later after finding Clifford's abandoned car. But within hours, the hunt had moved to a nearby cemetery just a few minutes' walk away. The former security guard was later found with self-inflicted injuries at Lavender Hill Cemetery just after 4.30pm after seemingly shooting himself with the crossbow.\n\nIn a burst of intense activity, armed police closed down the cemetery, as eyewitnesses saw paramedics running into the grounds.\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local who filmed the commotion, said: 'I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\n\n'I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.'\n\nAround 20 minutes later Clifford was stretchered from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he was receiving medical treatment last night.\n\nPolice confirmed no shots had been fired by officers and nobody else was being sought.\n\nMr Hunt, himself a former police officer before he took up radio and became a much-loved personality on the horse racing circuit, was said to be inconsolable last night. In a note to staff, the BBC said: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nJulie Harrington, chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority, said: 'The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n'John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have seen many times before when one of our number is faced with great trauma.'\n\nLast night neighbours and friends continued to lay flowers at the scene. One friend, Su Kehinde, 60, who lives nearby, said she would remember them as 'beautiful souls'. She said: 'They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.'\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'.\n\nShe added: 'She was hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle.'\n\nSix years ago, Clifford's older brother was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey.\n\nBradley Clifford, a plumber, was 23 when he mowed down Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, on their moped after they struck his 'prized' Ford Mustang car with a bottle.\n\nBoth teenagers were flung from the moped by the impact, and Bradley Clifford beat Mr Khan as he lay on the ground injured.\n\nThe incident followed a row outside a bar in Enfield in which Clifford's car received superficial damage. He flew into a rage and pursued the pair in a 20-minute high speed chase before crashing into the moped.\n\nClifford was jailed for life and told to serve at least 23 years for the murder of Mr Khan {"uri": "8218864264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:14:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:14:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:13:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/armed-polices-terrifying-four-word-33212453", "title": "Armed police's terrifying 4 word order to locals after 3 women found dead", "body": "A resident has told how they were given a four-word warning by armed police following the murders of BBC racing commentator John Hunt's wife and two daughters in Bushey with a manhunt now for suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nA resident has told how armed police shouted \"Stay in your house\" as they were put into \"lockdown\" following the murder of three women in Bushey.\n\nThe 46-year-old, of Ashlyn Close, who did not wish to share her name said she heard screaming on Tuesday evening as the \"absolutely traumatic\" incident unfolded. A manhunt is now underway following the deaths of Carol Hunt, 61, the wife of BBC 5 Live commentator John Hunt, and their two daughters.\n\nSuspect Kyle Clifford, 26, is believed by police to be armed and in Hertfordshire or north London. The BBC confirmed that Mr Hunt's wife and two daughters had died, in a post on the broadcaster's news website.\n\nThe local resident described how the leafy suburb was suddenly turned into a major police scene. \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos,\" she said. \"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell them to stay indoors. The woman said she was upset and stressed to know a man sought in connection with the triple murder is still at large, adding: \"It's really, really stressful now to think that that happened in such a close vicinity and none of us were aware and none of us could help.\n\n\"It's just absolutely traumatic, I think, for the family involved, for everyone. I think that's the stressful thing, that it happened at peak family time between 6pm and 7pm, when people were probably cooking for their kids and getting their kids ready for bed, and all of us in a tight little road, completely unaware of the trauma and tragic circumstances that other people were going through at that particular time.\"\n\nMessages of condolence were posted on social media by figures from the racing world for the Hunt family. ITV racing commentator Matt Chapman wrote in an entry on X, formerly Twitter: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\" The Amateur Jockeys Association of Great Britain and Beverley Racecourse were among others sending their sympathies.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", {"uri": "8219407730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "21:34:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T21:34:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T21:33:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/bushey-murder-hunt-family-kyle-clifford-crossbow-b2577651.html", "title": "Grief washes over quiet, leafy town as three women murdered in 'tremendous tragedy'", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nHorror, shock and grief have engulfed a quiet, leafy community in Hertfordshire after three women were murdered in their own home in a terrifying attack involving a crossbow.\n\nTributes have been pouring in for the \"gentle, beautiful, friendly\" Hunt family after mother Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, were killed in a \"targeted\" incident in their usually peaceful cul-de-sac Ashlyn Close in Bushey on Tuesday evening.\n\nArmed police have now captured suspect Kyle Clifford, 26, following a major manhunt. Detectives said the 26-year-old was found with injuries and was receiving medical treatment after he was apprehended in the Enfield area of north London on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nBBC racing commentator John Hunt - husband of Carol and father to beautician Hannah and Louise, a dog groomer - has been left behind to grapple with the devastating loss of three family members, whose identities were confirmed by the broadcaster. He and Carol are understood to have a third daughter.\n\nShocked and distraught local residents paid tribute to the three victims as \"beautiful souls\" and told The Independent of often seeing the family out walking their dogs together in the local area.\n\nAmong them are Simon and Tracey Bowler, who described the Hunts as \"nice and friendly\" neighbours who would always wave and say \"hello\" as they walked their dogs past the Bowler family's house.\n\nFighting back tears, Ms Bowler, who has lived in Bushey for more than a decade and knows Mr Hunt through the local gym, spoke of how \"emotional\" and \"overwhelming\" it has been. Describing the area as \"quiet and residential\", Mr Bowler said: \"The neighbourhood hasn't stopped being a neighbourhood - it's just really sad.\"\n\nNeighbour Su Kehinde, 60, who laid flowers at a makeshift tribute in the area on Wednesday, said: \"They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They were the meekest human beings. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.\"\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah \"always had a smile\" and was \"hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle\".\n\nA friend of Louise Hunt, who knew her from their time at school, praised her as \"really sweet, very kind, always a positive person\". He told BBC News: \"I can't think of anything bad to say about her - a really lovely person all round, a super hard-working person.\"\n\nDerek Turner, a neighbour on Ashlyn Close, described the three women's deaths as a \"tremendous tragedy\".\n\nAfter having lived in \"peaceful and quiet\" Bushey for more than 30 years, Mr Turner said the incident has sparked concern. \"We don't really have things like this happen round here,\" he said, describing the area as one with a tight-knit community, beloved by residents, many of whom have lived in the town for years. \"You can never imagine that would happen in your street,\" he said.\n\nAnother neighbour said she grew up with the Hunt family and played with Louise and Hannah when they were all children. Describing the family as \"super nice and friendly\", the 22-year-old woman, who did not want to be named, added that, more recently, she would see John and Carol out dog-walking. \"I feel so bad for the dad,\" said the family friend. \"I saw him just two weeks ago.\"\n\nFloral tributes were piling up by the Ashlyn Close road sign on Wednesday, as mourners arrived crying and holding hands before placing their bouquets and messages at the scene. One tribute addressed to the three women read: \"I wish none of this was real. I wish I could hug you all, and tell you how much you meant to me. I wish you could hug each other. Love you forever.\" Another message said: \"Words cannot express how devastated I am that you're gone. The most gentle beautiful family. Forever loved.\"\n\nPolice officers looked on from the edge of the cordon at the top of the victims' road, with one also seen leaving a flower tribute. Police cars and vans were parked along Ashlyn Close as the triple murder investigation continues.\n\nOfficers were called to the cul-de-sac just before 7pm on Tuesday after neighbours heard screams from the four-bedroom detached family home. The three women were found seriously injured and later pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nA man walking close to the scene with his two young children on Wednesday said: \"It's just devastating. It's shocking to hear in an area where you just want to raise your children and have a nice, happy life.\"\n\nDescribing Bushey as \"so peaceful and quiet\", another local resident said: \"It's just heartbreaking. It's frightening to have it at the doorstep.\"\n\nHertfordshire Constabulary hunted overnight for Clifford, from the Enfield area. Detectives had issued a direct plea to Clifford to contact police on Wednesday as they warned members of the public not to approach him and dial 999.\n\nArmed officers were seen raiding a flat in Enfield and swarming a cemetery, with a nearby primary school put on lockdown, before police confirmed he had been located that afternoon. The force said no shots were fired by police in the search for Clifford, who was feared to be armed with a crossbow.\n\nFootage captured by Sky News appeared to show him being stretchered out of Lavender Hill cemetery before being loaded into an ambulance.\n\nClifford, who is said to be known to the Hunt family, left the British Army in 2022 following a brief period of service, The Independent understands.\n\nA former army boss told The Sun that he was \"immature for his age and had a bit of a chip on his shoulder\", adding that he worked in private security after leaving the force.\n\nIn a note to Mr Hunt's colleagues at BBC 5 Live, the broadcaster offered its condolences and described the tragedy as \"utterly devastating\".", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowling_(cricket)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bowling (cricket)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition_game", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Exhibition game"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bushey", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bushey"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Bushey"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Dog"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_end_(street)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Dead end (street)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Clifford", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kyle Clifford"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._M._W._Turner", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "2024-07-418032263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "00:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T00:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T23:42:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/bushey-crossbow-murderer-kyle-clifford-caused-fear-in-a-peaceful-neighborhood-by-murdering-his-former-girlfriend-her-sister-and-her-mother-after-a-tumultuous-breakup-before-apparently-shooting-hi/", "title": "Bushey crossbow murderer, Kyle Clifford, caused fear in a peaceful neighborhood by murdering his former girlfriend, her sister, and her mother after a tumultuous breakup, before apparently shooting himself in a graveyard following an extensive police search. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "It was a scene of unimaginable horror that left even hardened detectives shaken. A defenceless mother and her two daughters tied up in their own home and shot dead with a 3ft-long crossbow in a bloody rampage.\n\nAround 6.30pm on Tuesday, neighbours of a \u00a3800,000 suburban home in a quiet cul-de-sac in Bushey, Hertfordshire, heard piercing screams which were initially mistaken for that of a distressed child.\n\nLater they were to realise that it was a woman's desperate cries for help coming from the home where Louise Hunt, 25, her sister Hannah, 28, and mother Carol, 61, were ambushed by a crossbow-wielding killer.\n\nSoon after the screams fell silent, the assailant fled the property, by which time the police had been alerted and were on their way.\n\nIt is believed that on finding his wife and daughters fatally wounded, officers were able to contact BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt, a voice known to millions, who was returning from working at Lingfield Park course.\n\nAlthough police and ambulance had rushed to the house, they were unable to save the three victims who died at the scene.\n\nBut it wasn't long before detectives were on the trail of a suspect after a figure was seen darting out of an alleyway directly behind the murder scene. Clad in black, the man was captured on camera calmly striding away with what appeared to be a crossbow tucked under his arm hidden beneath a white sheet.\n\nFootage from a nearby doorcam showed the bearded figure carrying a heavy bag, which police feared may be a cache of weapons he used to carry out the brutal attack.\n\nChillingly, he passed within feet of a female neighbour, who stood alone on her driveway stroking a cat and seemed startled by the sight of the barely concealed weapon at 6.50pm.\n\nWithin hours, a national manhunt was under way for former soldier Kyle Clifford, who was named by police in a highly unusual step. The 26-year-old had previously served in the Queen's Dragoon Guards for a short time before dropping out having failed to impress superiors, it was said last night.\n\nYesterday neighbours revealed that Clifford had been in a relationship with the Hunts' youngest daughter, Louise, but she split up with him a week ago.\n\nTheir parting is said to have left her so shaken that she recently crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: 'Louise was a very nice girl. She ran a dog grooming business from the house. I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it.\n\n'A friend of Louise's told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.'\n\nHe added: 'Carol was a nice, polite and quiet lady. She was at home a lot of the time.\n\n'They were all very nice, a private family. They all did their own things. Louise started a business a couple of years ago, and it was a thriving business - we all took our dogs there to be groomed.\n\n'A very close-knit family and they used to love the street. They'd had a lot of work done on their house over the years.'\n\nMrs Hunt, a mother of three, had recently told friends at her local gym that her youngest daughter was involved in a 'messy break-up' with her boyfriend.\n\nOne suggested her daughter's relationship had turned nasty.\n\nA friend said: 'She said her daughter's split with her boyfriend was messy. Carol did not go into too much detail, but you could see she was concerned.'\n\nPolice yesterday warned the public not to approach the suspect, who was last seen driving off from the cul-de sac in a grey vehicle the previous evening.\n\nOne neighbour said 'absolute chaos' broke out as armed police arrived. She said: 'It was between 6.30pm and 7pm and it sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'That's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n'We had armed police running down, screaming, 'Stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.' Police searches predominantly focused yesterday on Hertfordshire and North London because the police did not believe their suspect had the time to get much further.\n\nPassengers arriving at London Victoria railway station during the morning rush hour, before news of the tragedy became public, found their exit slowed as they were unusually marshalled through the barriers, allowing ranks of police on the opposite side to scan the crowd, checking every face.\n\nLater, local schools were put into lockdown when armed police raided the suspect's home in Enfield, North London, some 14 miles from the crime scene.\n\nOne mother said: 'They had cordoned off the road and were ushering people away from the house they were going into. They had the full protective gear on, guns, shields and helmets - the kind you'd expect to see in riots.'\n\nDozens of officers from Scotland Yard and Hertfordshire Police flooded the area a short time later after finding Clifford's abandoned car. But within hours, the hunt had moved to a nearby cemetery just a few minutes' walk away. The former security guard was later found with self-inflicted injuries at Lavender Hill Cemetery just after 4.30pm after seemingly shooting himself with the crossbow.\n\nIn a burst of intense activity, armed police closed down the cemetery, as eyewitnesses saw paramedics running into the grounds.\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local who filmed the commotion, said: 'I saw about ten officers coming in. I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\n\n'I asked them if they wanted me to leave but they said it was fine to stay. They started checking the area so I left shortly after and came back to see all these vehicles.'\n\nAround 20 minutes later Clifford was stretchered from the scene and taken by ambulance to Royal London Hospital, where he was receiving medical treatment last night.\n\nPolice confirmed no shots had been fired by officers and nobody else was being sought.\n\nMr Hunt, himself a former police officer before he took up radio and became a much-loved personality on the horse racing circuit, was said to be inconsolable last night. In a note to staff, the BBC said: 'The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating.\n\n'Our thoughts are with John and his family at this incredibly difficult time and we will provide him with all the support we can.'\n\nJulie Harrington, chief executive of the British Horseracing Authority, said: 'The thoughts of everyone at the BHA are with John Hunt, his family and friends. It is impossible to comprehend the horror that has been inflicted upon them by this dreadful event.\n\n'John is a great friend to many in our sport and I am sure that in this time of unimaginable grief for him, the racing family will rally around as we have seen many times before when one of our number is faced with great trauma.'\n\nLast night neighbours and friends continued to lay flowers at the scene. One friend, Su Kehinde, 60, who lives nearby, said she would remember them as 'beautiful souls'. She said: 'They were the loveliest, gentlest family. They did not deserve this. They were beautiful souls.'\n\nHer daughter April, 32, said that Hannah, who worked nearby as a beautician, 'always had a smile'.\n\nShe added: 'She was hard-working, a hard grafter and really gentle.'\n\nSix years ago, Clifford's older brother was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey.\n\nBradley Clifford, a plumber, was 23 when he mowed down Soban Khan, 18, and Jahshua Francis, 19, on their moped after they struck his 'prized' Ford Mustang car with a bottle.\n\nBoth teenagers were flung from the moped by the impact, and Bradley Clifford beat Mr Khan as he lay on the ground injured.\n\nThe incident followed a row outside a bar in Enfield in which Clifford's car received superficial damage. He flew into a rage and pursued the pair in a 20-minute high speed chase before crashing into the moped.\n\nClifford was jailed for life and told to serve at least 23 years for the murder of Mr Khan and attempted GBH with intent on Mr Francis.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Police have warned members of the public that Clifford, who is still at large, 'may be in possession of a crossbow' and other weapons.\n\nIn the weeks before the triple murder, which occurred yesterday evening (June 9), dog grooming business owner Louise had reportedly been dealing with the painful aftermath of a break-up.\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, told the Mail Online that Louise had been left so distraught by the recent split that she ended up crashing her car in the week before her tragic death.\n\nGlyn said: \"Louise was a very nice girl. I believe Hannah, Louise's sister, was also killed along with their mother Carol.\"\n\nThis comes as Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson calls upon Clifford to come forward, addressing him during during a press conference. The manhunt also involves armed police officers and specialist search teams responding at pace in the wake of what has been a horrific incident involving what is currently believed to be a crossbow, but other weapons may also have been used.\"\n\nHe continued: \"Kyle, if you are seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nCarol, Hannah, and Lousie were discovered in the early evening after police and ambulance vehicles - including two air ambulances - were called to their home before 7pm. Armed officers rounded on the location, with the new footage showing them walking alongside paramedics before he was carted to a trauma centre for treatment.\n\nThe brief video, taken by Sky News cameras from a helicopter, shows the small group of emergency responders walking alongside a man, who can be seen lying on a stretcher. Three paramedics clad in orange hi-vis jumpsuits walk out in front, with police officers in black combat gear pass alongside, flanking them en route out of the cemetery.\n\nThe group is then seen trudging onto the tarmac, where they load the stretcher into the back of an ambulance. as hunt for ex-soldier ends", "body": "CROSSBOW murder suspect Kyle Clifford's older brother is already behind bars for life after killing a teenager, The Sun can reveal.\n\nClifford, 26, from Enfield, north London, was arrested today in connection with the deaths of the wife and two of the daughters of John Hunt, the BBC Five Live racing commentator.\n\nCarol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, were tragically pronounced dead at their home in Bushey, Hertfordshire, last night.\n\nDetectives launched an urgent manhunt for suspect Clifford with armed police capturing him today after swarming a cemetery.\n\nIt has now emerged that, Clifford's older brother, Bradley, was convicted of murder after a trial at the Old Bailey six years ago, reports the Telegraph.\n\nBradley Clifford was handed a 23-year prison term after he mowed down and killed a moped rider for smashing a bottle on his \"prized\" Ford Mustang car.\n\nBradley, now 30, became enraged and gave chase to a scooter being ridden by Soban Khan, 18, and his friend Jahshua Francis, 19.\n\nMr Francis and his passenger were flung into the air after Bradley drove his mustang into the moped during a relentless pursuit through Enfield in the early hours of August 5 2017.\n\nLying motionless and catastrophically injured, Mr Khan was then beaten up by Bradley who had got out of his car when it became entangled with the moped.\n\nBradley told the teenager he \"deserved\" it and punched him hard nine times, the Old Bailey heard.\n\nHe was found guilty of murdering Mr Khan and of attempted GBH with intent on Mr Francis.\n\nBradley was jailed for life, and the judge told him he would have to serve at least 23 years before he would be eligible to apply for parole.\n\nPals say after the attack current manhunt suspect Kyle became \"obsessed with murder and death\" and believed he was \"untouchable\".\n\nA friend said: \"After Bradley was jailed Kyle developed this weird power complex.\n\n\"He thought having a brother who was behind bars was something to show-off about.\n\n\"Kyle used to go up to people and say 'don't f*** with my family'. He thought he was untouchable.\n\n\"He had no problem threatening people. And people were definitely afraid of him.\"\n\nClifford, who dropped out of the army, was apprehended by armed cops at a cemetery in Hilly Fields in Enfield, North London, after nearly 24 hours on the run.\n\nThe 26-year-old suspect was caught with no shots having been fired by armed police.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\n\n\"Following extensive enquiries, the suspect has been located and nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time.\n\n\"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us.\n\n\"We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents.\"\n\nIt comes as a haunting photo also emerged showing Clifford with ex-girlfriend Louise.\n\nDramatic footage obtained exclusively by The Sun this afternoon appeared to show Clifford stalking the streets last night with a crossbow under his arm.\n\nThe clip shows a man carrying a three-foot object under his right arm - covered by a sheet - as he strides from an alleyway leading to the property where the women were killed.\n\nAnother video obtained exclusively by us showed cops storming a home in the hunt for the suspect.\n\nTwo helicopters were spotted circling the Hilly Fields area of Enfield, North London, as armed police stormed a home.\n\nOne officer can be heard screaming: \"Armed Police, come to the door and raise your hands\" as cops barrage through the front of the Kyle Clifford, who is a former British Army soldier who had at one point been in a relationship with Mr Hunt's younger daughter, was found in the Lavender Hill Cemetery, near where the three women died.\n\nWith the search now concluded, new information has emerged about the circumstances in which the bodies of the three women were found at their home in Bushey on Tuesday evening. Sources have claimed that evidence from the scene suggests they may have been gagged and bound before they were killed.\n\nCiting a source, The Guardian reported that while the three were not found gagged and bound, there were ligature marks visible on their wrists and faces that suggest they may have been at one point. The publication's source added that evidence of ligatures was found near their bodies.\n\nNeither Hertfordshire Police nor their London Met colleagues have confirmed how the women died, and formal identification of the victims is still taking place, detectives have said. Meanwhile officers are waiting to question Clifford, 26, who was taken to hospital with injuries understood to be self-inflicted.\n\nThe BBC has pledged to provide BBC Five Live commentator Mr Hunt with \"all the support we can\", and police have urged the urged the public to give the family space \"as they come to terms with what has happened\". Detective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit, said that, with Clifford now located, \"nobody else is being sought in connection with the investigation at this time\".\n\nShe has asked people to come forward if they have information or footage relating to the incident.\n\nShe said: \"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us.
