cul-de-sac, just as people were starting to come home from work, leading neighbours to rush towards the modern detached house from where the chilling cry had emerged.\n\nAt 7pm, John Hunt, the BBC Five Live racing commentator, had returned home from a day's working at Lingfield racecourse to make an unimaginable discovery.\n\nIn the house, his wife Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, had all been critically injured after being violently attacked.\n\nThe three women died at the scene shortly after paramedics arrived.\n\nA 46-year-old neighbour, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, recalled the moment.\n\n\"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos,\" they said.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene at high speed, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, requesting doorbell camera footage and urging them to stay indoors.\n\nSarah Fernandez, 52, arrived at home just after 7.30pm to find Ashlyn Close swarming with armed police.\n\nShe said: \"I was the last car allowed into the street before the police closed off access. There were about 15 armed police vehicles parked up. It's really frightening. We've never had anything like this before here.\"\n\nOn Wednesday morning, police issued the name of a man they wanted to speak to in connection with the grisly discovery.\n\nOfficers said the man in question, Kyle Clifford, a 26-year-old former serviceman from Enfield, north London, was armed and dangerous.\n\nClifford was believed to be carrying a crossbow but officers said other weapons may also have been used.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace\", police said.\n\nAt a press conference held at 12.30pm at Hertfordshire Police HQ in Hatfield, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, addressed Clifford personally, urging him to hand himself in.\n\nAddressing the assembled TV cameras he said: \"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nAs the police manhunt spread across Hertfordshire and north London, with officers focusing their searches on properties in Enfield, details began to emerge that threw a potentially troubling light on one of Louise Hunt's recent relationships.\n\nA near neighbour of the Hunts said Louise had been left so upset by a recent break-up with her boyfriend she had crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nHe suggested that Louise had been in a relationship with the man now wanted in connection with the murders of the three women and that the relationship had ended badly.\n\nIn a telling gesture, just days before the incident, Louise had shared a tweet in which the author praised \"women who leave\" for having the \"strength\" to choose themselves.\n\nIt stated: \"I admire women who leave. IDGAF if you left after the 1st time or the 12th time I admire that s---! IDGAF if ppl were calling you d\u00fcmb for 11 years but in the 12th year you decided you was done.\n\n\"It takes a lot of strength to break a tie. It takes a lot of self-love to choose yourself.\"\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: \"Louise split up with her boyfriend a few days ago and she crashed her car into a telegraph pole because she was so upset coming home. She's a lovely, caring girl. She runs a dog grooming business in Bushey.\n\n\"Her sister Hannah and mother Carol are lovely as well. It's all so sad. Louise was a sweet, lovely girl. They all were. This is so sad for everyone,\" he said. \"And to think I only heard John's voice on the radio yesterday morning, commentating from Lingfield, a few hours before all this happened.\"\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass, who lives close by the scene, echoed the shock felt by those living nearby. He said: \"The worst thing that's ever happened in this part of Bushey is a bit of illegal fly tipping and then suddenly we get three murders and we're all a bit shellshocked.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb, we don't get this sort of thing in this area and I want residents to know that the council will be ensuring that the liaison team is down here and doing everything they can to comfort them and make sure that they are reassured that everything is being done.\n\n\"But we're worried that this guy is still floating around somewhere.\"\n\nPolice were worried too - and as the hours ticked by it became increasingly clear that a peaceful suburb of Enfield was the focus of their manhunt.\n\nFootage emerged from earlier in the day of armed officers raiding a house close to Gordon Hill railway station, the last address of Clifford's older brother Bradley, who is currently serving a life sentence for murder.\n\nHelicopters buzzed overhead and larger and larger numbers of officers could be seen patrolling the streets.\n\nA \"coordinated search\" was being undertaken, police said, with a car of possible interest found.\n\nAt least one primary school, St Michael's, went into a form of lockdown, according to reports.\n\nAs the day wore on they appeared to be increasingly interested in the Hilly Fields Park area, a bucolic haven just to the north of the residential area popular with dog walkers.\n\nOfficers could be seen teaming up with the London Fire Brigade to use a drone to search the area.\n\nAll at once, the search for the former soldier seemed to narrow - activity was seen in and around Lavender Hill cemetery on the edge of the park.\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local resident who filmed police sweeping into the graveyard, said: \"I saw about 10 officers coming in, it was around 3pm I'd say.\n\n\"I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\"\n\nAbout an hour later, police abruptly started moving back the members of the public and press who had gathered near the cemetery.\n\nThen aerial footage emerged appearing to show a person being stretchered through the graveyard, accompanied by multiple armed officers.\n\nPolice announced that the suspect had been found alive but injured. No shots had been fired and police said he was receiving medical treatment. No one else is being sought in connection with the case.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\"\n\nShe added: \"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], The family are understood to be that of BBC racing commentator, John Hunt.\n\nBBC Five Live racing commentator John Hunt is reported to have returned to his \u00a3800,000 Bushey, Hertfordshire home to the horror scene of his wife Carol Hunt, 61, and two daughters Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25, seriously injured. All three of them were later pronounced dead despite the best efforts of medics.\n\nHertfordshire Police are now hunting their suspected killer, 26-year-old Kyle Clifford who allegedly fled the house in Ashyn Close, Bushey, before 7pm on Tuesday evening (July 9). Clifford is understood to be the ex-boyfriend of Louise.\n\nHusband and father John's employers BBC Sport noted to staff, the deaths are \"utterly devastating\".\n\nMembers of the public have been urged to dial 999 \"straight away\" if they see Clifford but warned against approaching him as he may still be armed.\n\nTributes have been pouring in for the daughters of John and wife Carol, 61. Dog groomer Louise, has been described as \"gorgeous\" and \"hardworking\" by a neighbour.\n\nShe launched a Groom and Glow during the coronavirus lockdown while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business.\n\nLocal resident William Nourallah spoke about 25-year-old Louise, saying: \"She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father.\n\n\"She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. "title": "Revealed: Crossbow attack suspect's brother is convicted killer", "body": "Bradley Clifford was jailed in 2018 for killing a teenager with his car\n\nThe older brother of fugitive suspect Kyle Clifford is already in prison for murder, it can be revealed.\n\nBradley Clifford was handed a 23-year prison term after he mowed down and killed a moped rider for smashing a bottle on his 'prized' Ford Mustang car.\n\nClifford, now 30, became enraged when his \u00a335,000 car was hit with a bottle and gave chase to a scooter being ridden by Soban Khan, 18, and his friend Jahshua Francis, 19.\n\nMr Francis and his passenger drove into oncoming traffic and tried to mount the pavement but were flung into the air following the relentless pursuit through Enfield, north London, in the early hours of August 5 2017.\n\nLying motionless and catastrophically injured, Mr Khan was then beaten up by Clifford who had got out of his car when it became entangled with the moped.\n\nClifford told the teenager he 'deserved' it and punched him hard nine times, the Old Bailey heard.\n\nBradley Clifford chased a scooter at nearly double the speed limit on the wrong side of the road after a bottle was thrown at his high-powered sports car\n\nKyle Clifford, younger brother of Bradley, is wanted in connection with the murders of three women in Bushey\n\nClifford, who worked as an air conditioning firm manager, denied murder but was convicted by an Old Bailey jury in May 2018, aged 24.\n\nHis younger brother Kyle, 26, from Enfield, is currently wanted by detectives over the deaths of three women who were found fatally injured in a house in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, just after 7pm on Tuesday.\n\nHertfordshire Police warned that he may still be in possession of a weapon - possibly a crossbow used to slay the victims - and that members of the public should dial 999 if they see him.\n\nSoban Khan (pictured) was the victim of Bradley Clifford, who is crossbow killer suspect Kyle's brother\n\nProsecutor Aftab Jafferjee KC said Mr Khan's moped was no match for the power of the Mustang\n\nSpeaking during the trial of Kyle's older brother, also from Enfield, prosecutor Aftab Jafferjee KC said Mr Khan's moped was no match for the power of the Mustang.\n\nThe prosecutor said: 'It was rapid, it was brutal and it was unrelenting. He pursued the moped down a straight stretch of road at speed. Not to apprehend the two people on it, but to mow them down for daring to damage his prized vehicle.\n\n'As Soban Khan lay virtually motionless, totally defenceless and fatally injured, such was this defendant's rage that he went over to him and beat him.'\n\nPolice and paramedics rushed to the scene and found the two moped riders seriously hurt.\n\nVictim Louise Hunt is the ex-girlfriend of crossbow suspect Kyle Clifford\n\nHannah Hunt, sister of Louise and daughter of John, also died after being shot with a crossbow at the family's \u00a3800,000 home\n\nCarol Hunt, who was married to BBC horse racing commentator John Hunt (pictured together), was found fatally injured along with her two daughters at her home last night\n\nMr Khan was pronounced dead at 4.38am while Mr Francis 'miraculously survived' and was taken to hospital for treatment.\n\nThe incident began when Clifford got into a row with one of Mr Khan's friends in a dispute over his girlfriend.\n\nThe two men agreed to go to a car park for a fist fight, but as Clifford loitered in his Mustang his rival instead drove away from the scene.\n\nMr Jafferjee said Mr Khan then 'stupidly, and indeed criminally' smashed a bottle on the side of the car, provoking a 'rapid, brutal, and unrelenting' response from Clifford.\n\nIn an emotional impact statement Mr Khan's father Najam, said: 'Soban Khan was a very sensible, friendly and popular individual in both school and later in college.\n\n'We all had such high hopes for Soban for his life and what was proving to be a very promising future.\n\n'Soban's younger sister is still at school and comes home asking to see her big brother every day.\n\n'He was a great son and a great brother. Unfortunately with boundless pain we will never see him become anything more, not a husband, not a father and the successful man he wanted to be.'\n\nMr Khan's death was the 'end of a generation', his father said.\n\nA paramedic can be seen talking into his radio at the crime scene while a police officer stands guard at one of the houses\n\nPolice in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Hertfordshire, where three women, who police believe to be related, died last night\n\n'We will continue to grieve for the rest of our lives. His smile and words will never leave us.'\n\nJudge Sarah Munro KC said: 'In the early hours of 5 August last year having worked your way up into a rage at the words and actions of a group of teenagers you made a decision to drive your powerful Ford Mustang car into Jahshua Francis intending that he and his pillion passenger Soban Khan would be seriously injured.\n\n'Soban was a rising star with a promising future. As Mr Khan says no parent should have to bury their child.'\n\nThe court heard how, on July 31, Clifford sent a WhatsApp message to a 18-year-old woman in which he said: 'Your boyfriend say he is gonna go after my car! I'll put a f***ing knife down the c***'s throat.'\n\nThis showed how seriously he took any threats made to his vehicle, the judge said.\n\n'Six days after you sent that message your car was threatened,' she told him.\n\n'The two young teenagers who got onto the moped didn't know how enraged you were or what you were capable of. Your actions thereafter were a gross overreaction.\n\n'You were already in a violent temper and the actions by those teenagers on the moped turned you into a murderer.'\n\nClifford had become 'determined' that Mr Khan should die as he 'rained blows' upon him as he lay by a lamppost, the judge said.\n\nAfter attacking Mr Khan in an 'intense rage', Clifford had the presence of mind to lie to police about what happened, she said.\n\nBut the jury was shown 'compelling' CCTV footage and saw through his 'false defence', in which he claimed it was an accident.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8218898237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:35:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:35:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:34:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/bbc-star-john-hunts-slain-33212035", "title": "BBC John Hunt's slain family - 'quiet wife, daughter's painful suspect split'", "body": "BBC racing commentator John Hunt with his supportive wife Carol\n\nBroadcaster John Hunt harrowingly lost his wife and two daughters in a tragic triple killing at their home - and their suspected murderer is still on the run.\n\nThe three fatally injured women in Hertfordshire have today been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - the partner and two children of the BBC sports commentator. Mr Hunt, 58, is said to have been working for the BBC at Lingfield Park race course on Tuesday when he returned home around 7pm to discover the three of them seriously injured.\n\nEmergency services, including two air ambulances, were sent to the property, and despite their best efforts to save the women, they all died at the scene. The mother and daughters were \"targeted\" and attacked with a crossbow and other weapons in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police has said.\n\nPolice are looking for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, in connection with the deaths, and have warned he is believed to be armed. It is believed that victim Louise was his ex-girlfriend. Directly appealing to the main suspect, Chief Sup Simpson said: \"Kyle if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact.\" Investigators believe he could also be in Hertfordshire or around his home in north London.\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nThe youngest of the sisters, Louise, reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow - which was run out of the family home - while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business called Hannah Grace Aesthetics. One comment on Louise's business Instagram account was written by her supportive sister Hannah, who said: \"The best dog groomer ever.\"\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, told the Daily Mail that he believed Louise had split from Clifford just a week prior and had crashed her car in a state of distress. \"I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it. So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house,\" he said.\n\n\"Another dog groomer - who is a friend of Louise's - told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.\"\n\nA neighbour, who didn't want to be named, said she didn't know the victims well but said they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nSpeaking about Louise, local resident William Nourallah told the Daily Mail: \"She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father. She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. She was a beautiful young girl. It's a waste of a life.'\n\nJohn's wife Carol was the one who helped him get into journalism. Over two decades ago, she pointed out an advert in the evening Harrow Observer for a trainee broadcaster at Ladbrokes. According to The Telegraph, Carol's casual suggestion to apply for the job, paired with his interest in horseracing, led to his racing reporting.\n\nFormer police officer John was in Snaresbrook Crown Court on the Friday, and started at Ladbrokes on the Monday, a day before Royal Ascot, the publication reports. For the last 20 years, he has worked for BBC Radio 5 Live as a racing commentator and is beloved by fans and colleagues alike.\n\nSpeaking about Carol, another neighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, described her as a 'quaint, a nice, polite and quiet lady' who was 'at home a lot of the time'.\n\nITV racing pundit Matt Chapman took to X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday to share his condolences for his co-star. He wrote: \"No words needed for what has happened to @HuntyCaller and family today. Impossible to comprehend the pain. Just know we are all here for you John. We love you pal - racing loves you.\"\n\nAnother resident living near the family said they heard screams from the house located in the quiet cul de sac where three women died. The 46-year-old said: \"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'That's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'Stay in your house'... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\" They said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene quickly, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, request doorbell camera footage and tell broke out in suburban cul-de-sac", "body": "Neighbours heard piercing scream before 'absolute chaos' broke out in suburban cul-de-sac\n\nHenry Bodkin\n\n10 July 2024 at 10:48 pm\n\nThe first indication that something truly awful had happened in Ashlyn Close came when a scream pierced the still suburban surroundings.\n\nIt echoed across the quiet cul-de-sac, just as people were starting to come home from work, leading neighbours to rush towards the modern detached house from where the chilling cry had emerged.\n\nAt 7pm, John Hunt, the BBC Five Live racing commentator, had returned home from a day's working at Lingfield racecourse to make an unimaginable discovery.\n\nIn the house, his wife Carol, 61, and daughters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25, had all been critically injured after being violently attacked.\n\nThe three women died at the scene shortly after paramedics arrived.\n\nA 46-year-old neighbour, who did not wish to share their name but works in the media, recalled the moment.\n\n\"It was between 6.30pm and 7pm last night and it literally just sounded like kids, somebody, screaming, and then it was more shrill and I was like, 'that's definitely a woman screaming', and within 15 minutes, it was absolute chaos,\" they said.\n\n\"We had armed police running down, screaming 'stay in your house'.... they shut us off and basically put us into lockdown.\"\n\nThe resident said multiple ambulances, helicopters and \"at least 16 police cars\" arrived at the scene at high speed, with armed police going from house to house to question locals, requesting doorbell camera footage and urging them to stay indoors.\n\nSarah Fernandez, 52, arrived at home just after 7.30pm to find Ashlyn Close swarming with armed police.\n\nShe said: \"I was the last car allowed into the street before the police closed off access. There were about 15 armed police vehicles parked up. It's really frightening. We've never had anything like this before here.\"\n\nOn Wednesday morning, police issued the name of a man they wanted to speak to in connection with the grisly discovery.\n\nOfficers said the man in question, Kyle Clifford, a 26-year-old former serviceman from Enfield, north London, was armed and dangerous.\n\nClifford was believed to be carrying a crossbow but officers said other weapons may also have been used.\n\nArmed police officers and specialist search teams were \"responding at pace\", police said.\n\nAt a press conference held at 12.30pm at Hertfordshire Police HQ in Hatfield, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson, addressed Clifford personally, urging him to hand himself in.\n\nAddressing the assembled TV cameras he said: \"Kyle, if you're seeing or hearing this, please make contact with the police.\"\n\nAs the police manhunt spread across Hertfordshire and north London, with officers focusing their searches on properties in Enfield, details began to emerge that threw a potentially troubling light on one of Louise Hunt's recent relationships.\n\nA near neighbour of the Hunts said Louise had been left so upset by a recent break-up with her boyfriend she had crashed her car into a telegraph pole outside the family home.\n\nHe suggested that Louise had been in a relationship with the man now wanted in connection with the murders of the three women and that the relationship had ended badly.\n\nIn a telling gesture, just days before the incident, Louise had shared a tweet in which the author praised \"women who leave\" for having the \"strength\" to choose themselves.\n\nIt stated: \"I admire women who leave. IDGAF if you left after the 1st time or the 12th time I admire that s---! IDGAF if ppl were calling you d\u00fcmb for 11 years but in the 12th year you decided you was done.\n\n\"It takes a lot of strength to break a tie. It takes a lot of self-love to choose yourself.\"\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, said: \"Louise split up with her boyfriend a few days ago and she crashed her car into a telegraph pole because she was so upset coming home. She's a lovely, caring girl. She runs a dog grooming business in Bushey.\n\n\"Her sister Hannah and mother Carol are lovely as well. It's all so sad. Louise was a sweet, lovely girl. They all were. This is so sad for everyone,\" he said. \"And to think I only heard John's voice on the radio yesterday morning, commentating from Lingfield, a few hours before all this happened.\"\n\nLocal councillor Lawrence Brass, who lives close by the scene, echoed the shock felt by those living nearby. He said: \"The worst thing that's ever happened in this part of Bushey is a bit of illegal fly tipping and then suddenly we get three murders and we're all a bit shellshocked.\n\n\"This is a very traditional, quiet, leafy suburb, we don't get this sort of thing in this area and I want residents to know that the council will be ensuring that the liaison team is down here and doing everything they can to comfort them and make sure that they are reassured that everything is being done.\n\n\"But we're worried that this guy is still floating around somewhere.\"\n\nPolice were worried too - and as the hours ticked by it became increasingly clear that a peaceful suburb of Enfield was the focus of their manhunt.\n\nFootage emerged from earlier in the day of armed officers raiding a house close to Gordon Hill railway station, the last address of Clifford's older brother Bradley, who is currently serving a life sentence for murder.\n\nHelicopters buzzed overhead and larger and larger numbers of officers could be seen patrolling the streets.\n\nA \"coordinated search\" was being undertaken, police said, with a car of possible interest found.\n\nAt least one primary school, St Michael's, went into a form of lockdown, according to reports.\n\nAs the day wore on they appeared to be increasingly interested in the Hilly Fields Park area, a bucolic haven just to the north of the residential area popular with dog walkers.\n\nOfficers could be seen teaming up with the London Fire Brigade to use a drone to search the area.\n\nAll at once, the search for the former soldier seemed to narrow - activity was seen in and around Lavender Hill cemetery on the edge of the park.\n\nRae Cresswell, 26, a local resident who filmed police sweeping into the graveyard, said: \"I saw about 10 officers coming in, it was around 3pm I'd say.\n\n\"I was quite worried because they were armed and there were dogs with them.\"\n\nAbout an hour later, police abruptly started moving back the members of the public and press who had gathered near the cemetery.\n\nThen aerial footage emerged appearing to show a person being stretchered through the graveyard, accompanied by multiple armed officers.\n\nPolice announced that the suspect had been found alive but injured. No shots had been fired and police said he was receiving medical treatment. No one else is being sought in connection with the case.\n\nDetective Inspector Justine Jenkins from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit said: \"This continues to be an incredibly difficult time for the victims' family and we would ask that their privacy is respected as they come to terms with what has happened.\n\n\"This investigation is moving at pace and formal identification of the victims is yet to take place.\"\n\nShe added: \"We have had an overwhelming number of calls and would like to express our gratitude to the members of the public who have contacted us. We would still appeal for anyone with information or footage to please contact police directly and refrain from commenting on social media as this could affect the progress of the case.\n\n\"We have set up an information portal where people can submit any information, photos or video footage which they feel could assist us with our investigation.\n\n\"This incident will of course be of concern to local residents. Additional local officers will be in the area today so please do speak to them if you need to.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8218609991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:37:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:37:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:37:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/crossbow-laws-uk-explained-everything-33210430", "title": "Everything to know about UK crossbow laws as Kyle Clifford search continues", "body": "Hertfordshire Police have launched a manhunt for Clifford following the deaths of three women in Bushey, with members of the public warned not to approach the crossbow-wielding man\n\nPolice have warned that a man wanted in connection with the deaths of three women in Bushey, Hertfordshire \"may still be in possession\" of a crossbow.\n\nHertfordshire Police are \"actively seeking\" Kyle Clifford, 26, who is from Enfield, North London, with members of the public urged to come forward with any potential sightings. People have also been warned not to approach the crossbow-wielding suspect while he is at large, as police attend the scene of the killings on a \"serene, quiet\" road.\n\nAs police investigate, Labour's newly minted Home Secretary Yvette Cooper has spoken out on Twitter, stating that she is being kept updated on the situation as it progresses. In a Tweet, she said that her thoughts were with the family and friends of the victims, and urged people to support investigating police.\n\nShe wrote: \"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community. I am being kept fully updated. I urge people to support [Hertfordshire Police] with any information about this case.\"\n\nAre crossbows illegal in the UK?\n\nLabour's Conservative predecessors were responsible for updating guidance on crossbow possession in the UK. While it is acknowledged as a weapon, the item is not severely restricted in the same way as other tools, like guns, that can shoot projectiles.\n\nIn a note issued under then-Home Secretary James Cleverly in February this year, the Home Office specified that adults over the age of 18 can legally own crossbows. Even if people meet the age requirements, the guidance adds that they cannot carry the weapon \"without reasonable excuse\", with penalties including prison terms of up to four years.\n\nAre crossbows allowed for hunting?\n\nHunting any live quarry in the UK with either a bow and arrow, or crossbow and arrow is illegal under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981. Section 5(1)(c)(i) for wild birds and s 11(1)(b) for wild animals. However, no licence or registration is required to own a crossbow in the United Kingdom.\n\nWhat has the government said about the use of crossbows?\n\nAt the time, the government said it was \"considering going further\" and had launched a call for evidence to ask whether the rules are \"tough enough\". Officials proposed that strengthened laws could eventually reflect those in place for guns, including a \"licensing scheme to protect public safety police checks for anyone looking to purchase a crossbow\".\n\nLaura Farris, the government's then Safeguarding Minister, said that, while crossbows are \"used rarely\" in violent crime, they \"can be highly dangerous\". She said: \"Crossbows are used rarely in violent crime in this country but they can be highly dangerous.\"\n\n\"We're doing all we can to ensure we have the appropriate measures in place against any risks these potentially dangerous weapons may pose. I encourage the public and those in the industry to come forward to share their views so we can have the most accurate picture and take any necessary action to keep our streets safe.\"", "source": {"uri": "8219065327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:26:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:26:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:25:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/bbc-star-john-hunts-slain-33214554", "title": "BBC star John Hunt's slain family: devoted wife and daughter who 'dated' suspect", "body": "Broadcaster John Hunt harrowingly lost his wife and two daughters in a tragic triple killing at their home - and their suspected murderer is still on the run.\n\nThe three fatally injured women in Hertfordshire have today been identified as Carol Hunt, 61, Hannah Hunt, 28, and Louise Hunt, 25 - the partner and two children of the BBC sports commentator. Mr Hunt, 58, is said to have been working for the BBC at Lingfield Park race course on Tuesday when he returned home around 7pm to discover the three of them seriously injured.\n\nEmergency services, including two air ambulances, were sent to the property, and despite their best efforts to save the women, they all died at the scene. The mother and daughters were \"targeted\" and attacked with a crossbow and other weapons in Ashlyn Close, Bushey, Chief Superintendent Jon Simpson of Hertfordshire Police has said.\n\nREAD MORE:BBC issue heartbreaking statement after colleague's wife and daughters found dead at home\n\nREAD MORE: 'Crossbow-armed suspect' wanted after murder of 'BBC star's wife and daughters'\n\nPolice are looking for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford, from Enfield, north London, in connection with the deaths, and have warned he is believed to be armed. It is believed that victim Louise was his ex-girlfriend. Directly appealing to the main suspect, Chief Sup Simpson said: \"Kyle if you are seeing or hearing this please make contact.\" Investigators believe he could also be in Hertfordshire or around his home in north London.\n\nA heartbreaking tribute to Louise on social media reads, according to MyLondon: \"No words can describe the loss I feel after today's horrific news. You were so loved and Scooby adored you...you built up an amazing business and were always so kind and gentle. May you RIP with your sister and mum xxx.\"\n\nThe youngest of the sisters, Louise, reportedly launched a dog grooming service during Covid lockdown named Groom and Glow - which was run out of the family home - while her sister Hannah owned a beauty business called Hannah Grace Aesthetics. One comment on Louise's business Instagram account was written by her supportive sister Hannah, who said: \"The best dog groomer ever.\"\n\nNeighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, told the Daily Mail that he believed Louise had split from Clifford just a week prior and had crashed her car in a state of distress. \"I heard that she split from a boyfriend last week and was very upset about it. So much so that she was driving home at some point last week and drove into a wooden telegraph pole not far from the house,\" he said.\n\n\"Another dog groomer - who is a friend of Louise's - told me that her car door had caved in because of the crash.\"\n\nA neighbour, who didn't want to be named, said she didn't know the victims well but said they were a friendly family. \"We would see them every day passing by and they would say good morning,\" she said. \"It's really sad what's happened, very shocking.\"\n\nSpeaking about Louise, local resident William Nourallah told the Daily Mail: \"She was a gorgeous girl. She really was a young, hardworking girl. I met the mum once or twice because she opened the door for me. I met the father. She was happy every time I saw her. We would have a laugh and a joke. She was a beautiful young girl. It's a waste of a life.'\n\nJohn's wife Carol was the one who helped him get into journalism. Over two decades ago, she pointed out an advert in the evening Harrow Observer for a trainee broadcaster at Ladbrokes. According to The Telegraph, Carol's casual suggestion to apply for the job, paired with his interest in horseracing, led to his racing reporting.\n\nFormer police officer John was in Snaresbrook Crown Court on the Friday, and started at Ladbrokes on the Monday, a day before Royal Ascot, the publication reports. For the last 20 years, he has worked for BBC Radio 5 Live as a racing commentator and is beloved by fans and colleagues alike.\n\nSpeaking about Carol, another neighbour Glyn Nicholas, 77, described her as a 'quaint, a nice, polite and quiet lady' who was 'at home a lot of the time'.\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8219066605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:27:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:27:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:27:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-crossbow-murders-britain-bushey-manhunt/", "title": "Manhunt under way in England for 26-year-old man believed to have killed 3 women using crossbow", "body": "Police in Hertfordshire north of London are hunting for a 26-year man who officers believe murdered three women in a targeted attack using a crossbow.\n\nThe BBC confirmed that the victims were Carol Hunt, the wife of horse racing broadcaster John Hunt, and their two daughters Louise, 25, and Hannah, 28. The women were killed at the family's home in Bushey, a leafy London suburb.\n\nMr. Hunt is a well-known racing commentator on the BBC and Sky Sports. He was working at the Lingfield Park Racecourse in Surrey on Tuesday.\n\nA manhunt covering much of north London has been under way since Tuesday night and police are looking for 26-year-old Kyle Clifford who lives in nearby Enfield. He is believed to have been the ex-boyfriend of Louise.\n\nChief Superintendent Jon Simpson described the attack as a \"horrific incident\" and he confirmed that it involved a crossbow and possibly other weapons.\n\n\"Kyle, if you are hearing or seeing this, please make contact with police,\" Ch. Supt. Simpson said in a direct appeal to Mr. Clifford on Wednesday.\n\nEnfield council said that there was no perceived threat to the public and that residents should carry on as normal. \"There will be an enhanced police presence in the area and around some schools to provide reassurance to pupils and parents,\" the council said in a statement.\n\nThe case has raised questions about the easy access to crossbows in the U.K.\n\nThere are no restrictions on the purchase of crossbows by adults and owners don't have to register the weapons with police. Crossbows can be bought online for as little as \u00a350 pounds, with the only requirement that the buyer prove they are over 18.\n\nThere have been calls for tighter regulations ever since the death of Shane Gilmer in 2021.\n\nMr. Gilmer, 30, was killed after he was shot with a crossbow by his neighbour Anthony Lawrence in North Yorkshire. Mr. Gilmer's partner, Laura Sugden, was also shot but she survived along with their unborn child.\n\nPaul Marks, the coroner who oversaw an inquest into Mr. Gilmer's death, said in his report to the Home Secretary \"that there was a risk that future deaths would occur because the possession of crossbows was not recorded, unlike the use and possession of shotguns and other firearms.\"\n\nMr. Marks called on the government to introduce tougher regulations on crossbows.\n\nAt the time, Home Secretary Priti Patel said that while the misuse of crossbows was tragic, \"these incidents are fortunately very rare.\" She added that existing laws were sufficient to cover any crimes committed with crossbows.\n\nThe Labour government, which took office last week, has vowed to tighten the laws governing crossbows.\n\n\"The loss of three women's lives in Bushey last night is truly shocking. My thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have been killed and with the community,\" the new Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said on X.\n\nA spokesperson for the department added that Ms. Cooper would be considering possible changes to the regulations as soon as possible.\n\nMr. Hunt has worked at the BBC and Sky for 20 years, covering mainly horse racing but also the Olympics and soccer. \"The news today about John Hunt's family is utterly devastating,\" the BBC said in a statement on Wednesday.\n\nSky Sports said: \"Everyone at Sky Sports Racing is deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in Hertfordshire and our thoughts are with our colleague John Hunt, his family and friends at this awful time.\"\n\nBBC racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght said he was speechless at the news.\n\n\"Like everyone else I feel numb and sick on John's behalf at such incomprehensible evil,\" Mr. Lysaght said in a statement. \"Everyone who knows John knows he is the absolute archetypal
